verse.text: [note]1[/note]Then Jehovah [note]2[/note]spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, in the [note]2[/note]Tent of Meeting, on the first day of the second month, in the [xref]a[/xref]second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt, saying,
verse.note: In the picture portrayed in Numbers, God's move was in the Ark with the tabernacle, i.e., in Christ, the God-man, the mingling of God and man (see note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 25[/link]), as the embodiment of God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]), with the church, the enlargement, the increase, of Christ (see notes on [link]Exo. 26:15[/link]) as God's dwelling place on the earth ([link]1 Cor. 3:16[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:21-22[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]). The picture in Numbers shows the Triune God and His chosen people mingled together as one entity that God may move on the earth and conquer His enemy in order to regain the earth for the fulfillment of His eternal purpose (cf. [link]Acts 1:8[/link]).
See notes [link book="Lev." chapter="1"]1[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in Lev. 1[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Take the sum of all the assembly of the children of Israel, by their [note]1[/note]families, by their fathers' households, according to the [xref]b[/xref]number of names, every male, head by head.
verse.note: The children of Israel were formed into a fighting army by being numbered by their families (by their fathers' households) and leaders ([link]vv. 1-16[/link]), i.e., by the source of life (cf. [link]1 Cor. 4:15[/link]) and fellowship of life ([link]1 John 1:3[/link]) and under the leadership (authority) in life (cf. [link]Heb. 13:17[/link]), and according to their age ([link]vv. 20-46[/link]), i.e., according to the maturity in life (cf. [link]1 John 2:13[/link]). In order to be numbered the children of Israel were required to be in the fellowship of the life of their fathers' households and had to grow in life unto maturity.

verse.text: From [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]twenty years old and upward, all who are able to go forth [note]2[/note]for military service in Israel, you and Aaron shall [note]3[/note]number them by their companies.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 30[/link]. For a vow to God, an Israelite male of the highest valuation was required to be between twenty and sixty years old ([link]Lev. 27:3[/link]), but for fighting, an Israelite male was required to be twenty years old or above, without limit. Even at the age of eighty-five, Caleb was still a warrior, able to fight for the nation of Israel ([link]Josh. 14:10-11[/link]).
Lit., to war, or, to the army. The Hebrew word tsaba is also translated service (for the priestly work) in [link]4:3[/link].
Or, visit; muster.

verse.text: These are the ones who were [xref]a[/xref]called from the assembly, the [xref]b[/xref]leaders of the tribes of their fathers; they were the heads of the thousands of Israel.
And [note]1[/note]Moses and Aaron took these men who had been designated by name.
verse.note: The numbering of Israel was recognized by the authorities in three aspects: first, by Moses, signifying Christ as the Head ([link]Eph. 1:22[/link]; [link]Col. 1:18a[/link]) in His exercising His authority; second, by Aaron, signifying Christ as the High Priest ([link]Heb. 2:17[/link]) in His carrying out His priesthood; and third, by the leaders of the twelve tribes ([link]vv. 4-16[/link]), signifying the elders of the churches ([link]Acts 14:23[/link]) in their taking the lead among God's people under the headship of Christ. The deputy authorities, those delegated by God, were to recognize the things that were done according to God's regulations.

verse.text: Even all the numbered men were [xref]a[/xref]six hundred three thousand five hundred fifty.
But the [note]1[/note]Levites were [xref]a[/xref]not numbered among them by their fathers' tribe.
verse.note: The Levites were not numbered among the army ([link]vv. 47-49[/link]; [link]2:33[/link]). They were appointed to minister to the Tabernacle of the Testimony and encamp around it to keep it from being touched by the children of Israel ([link]vv. 50-53[/link]).[br][br]The fighting Israelites were the outward protection for the serving Levites, who were for the testimony of God. The formed Israelites were a type of the church as a corporate warrior fighting the battle for God's testimony ([link]Eph. 6:10-20[/link]). The Levites also typify the church in the aspect of its service to God. For fighting, the believers are a corporate warrior, and for serving, they are the Levites, even the priests ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link], [link]9[/link]).

chapter.verse: For Jehovah had spoken to Moses, saying,
Only the tribe of Levi you shall not number, nor shall you take the sum of them among the children of Israel;

verse.text: But you, appoint the [xref]a[/xref]Levites over the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Tabernacle of the Testimony and over all its furnishings and over all that belongs to it. They shall carry the tabernacle and all its furnishings; and they shall minister to it and shall encamp around the tabernacle.
verse.note: For the meeting of God's people with God, the tabernacle was called the Tent of Meeting ([link]1:1[/link]); for the testimony of God, it was called the Tabernacle of the Testimony ([link]vv. 50[/link], [link]53[/link]). In the New Testament both Christ and the church, the enlargement of Christ, are the reality of the tabernacle in these two aspects.

verse.text: And when the tabernacle sets out, the Levites shall take it down; and when the tabernacle encamps, the Levites shall set it up. But the [note]1[/note]stranger who comes near shall be put to death.
verse.note: I.e., a layman, someone who was not a Levite.

verse.text: And the children of Israel shall [xref]a[/xref]encamp, each one by his own camp and each one by his own standard, according to their companies.

chapter.verse: But the Levites shall encamp around the Tabernacle of the Testimony, that there be no wrath upon the assembly of the children of Israel. And the Levites shall keep the charge of the Tabernacle of the Testimony.
Thus did the children of Israel do; according to all that Jehovah had commanded Moses, so they did.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,

verse.text: The children of Israel shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]encamp each by his own [note]2[/note]standard with the ensigns of their fathers' households; they shall encamp [note]3[/note]facing the Tent of Meeting on every side.
verse.note: The children of Israel encamping in array typifies God's redeemed people being consummated in the New Jerusalem. The New Jerusalem has twelve gates, three gates on each of the four sides, with the names of the twelve tribes of Israel on them ([link]Rev. 21:12-13[/link]). In Numbers the twelve tribes were arranged into an array, in which three tribes, each tribe being an army, were encamped on each of the four sides of the tabernacle ([link]vv. 2-31[/link]). Four camps of three armies each yields the number twelve. This number, composed of three multiplied by four, signifies the Triune God (three) mingled with His creatures (four), forming a unit of eternal and perfect government (cf. note [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 21[/link]).

Every man encamping by his own standard with the ensign of his father's house signifies that God's people were arranged not by their choice according to their preference but according to God's ordination and arrangement (cf. [link]1 Cor. 12:18[/link], [link]28[/link]).

Or, a distance from. That the children of Israel were encamped facing the Tent of Meeting indicates that the testimony of God — the Ark within the tabernacle, which contained the law as God's testimony ([link]Exo. 25:16[/link]) — was their unique center and goal (see notes [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 20[/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 25[/link]). This signifies that Christ, the embodiment of God, is the center and goal of God's people, who are journeying and fighting for God's testimony.[br][br]The children of Israel encamping around the Tent of Meeting indicates that they were formed into an army to fight for the protection of God's testimony (the Ark in the tabernacle, typifying Christ and His Body, the church, as the incarnated and embodied God). In the same way, the church today is fighting for the protection of the incarnated God. God in Himself needs no protection, but God in His embodiment needs to be protected by the fighting of the church as a formed, coordinated Body ([link]Matt. 16:18[/link] and note 6; [link]John 1:14[/link] and note 2; [link]Eph. 6:10-20[/link] and note [link]11[sup]2[/sup][/link], par. 2).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And those who encamp on the east side toward the sunrise shall be [i]of[/i] the standard of the camp of Judah, according to their companies; and the leader of the children of Judah: Nahshon the son of Amminadab;

And his company, that is, his numbered men: fifty-seven thousand four hundred.

verse.text: All who were numbered of the camp of Judah: one hundred eighty-six thousand four hundred, according to their companies. They shall set out [note]1[/note]first.
verse.note: The sequence of the four camps was not according to birth but according to spiritual condition. Reuben was the firstborn ([link]Gen. 29:31-32[/link]), but because he committed fornication he lost the birthright ([link]Gen. 49:3-4[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 5:1-2[/link]) and here set out second ([link]v. 16[/link]). Judah was born fourth ([link]Gen. 29:31-35[/link]), but he set out first because he was an overcoming lion among the twelve brothers ([link]Gen. 49:8-9[/link]), typifying Christ as the overcoming fighter, the Lion of the tribe of Judah ([link]Rev. 5:5[/link]), the One who defeated God's enemy ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]). Ephraim, the son of Joseph, set out third ([link]v. 24[/link]) because of Joseph ([link]Gen. 48:8-20[/link]). Among the camps, Dan set out last ([link]v. 31[/link]), for he was a "serpent" ([link]Gen. 49:17[/link]) and was the first to rebel against God's kingdom and set up a second worship center ([link]1 Kings 12:26-30[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]On the south side shall be the standard of the camp of Reuben according to their companies; and the leader of the children of Reuben: Elizur the son of Shedeur;

And his company, that is, those who were numbered of them: thirty-five thousand four hundred.

chapter.verse: Thus did the children of Israel do. According to all that Jehovah commanded Moses, so they encamped by their standards and so they set out, every one by their families, according to their fathers' households.

verse.text: Now these are the [xref]a[/xref]generations of Aaron and Moses at the time when Jehovah spoke with Moses on Mount Sinai.
And these are the names of the sons of Aaron: [xref]a[/xref]Nadab the firstborn and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar;
These are the names of the sons of Aaron, the [xref]a[/xref]anointed priests, [note]1[/note]who were consecrated to serve as priests.
verse.note: Lit, whose hands were filled.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Nadab and Abihu died before Jehovah when they offered strange fire before Jehovah in the wilderness of Sinai, and they had no children. So Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests in the presence of Aaron their father.
verse.note: See [link]Lev. 10:1-2[/link] and notes.

chapter.verse: And Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Bring the tribe of Levi near and set them before Aaron the priest, that they may minister to him.

chapter.verse: And they shall keep his charge and the charge of the whole assembly before the Tent of Meeting to do the service of the tabernacle.

verse.text: And they shall keep all the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]furnishings of the Tent of Meeting and the charge of the children of Israel to do the service of the tabernacle.
verse.note: The Tabernacle of the Testimony with all its furnishings and the altar ([link]vv. 25-26[/link], [link]31[/link], [link]36-37[/link]), to which the priests ministered, are types of Christ in all His rich aspects, whom the New Testament believers minister to others ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:3[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 4:6[/link]). The altar, signifying the cross ([link]Heb. 13:10[/link]), refers to Christ's redemption, and the tabernacle refers to Christ as the embodiment of God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]), through whom God dwells among men ([link]John 1:14[/link]) and through whom men can enter into God to enjoy all that He is ([link]John 14:2[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]20[/link]). To minister is to serve, and to serve is to supply people by ministering to them. The New Testament believers serve others the cross of Christ for redemption ([link]1 Cor. 1:23[/link]; [link]2:2[/link]) and the riches of Christ for the life supply ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]; [link]Col. 1:27-28[/link]).

verse.text: And you shall [xref]a[/xref]give the Levites to Aaron and to his sons; they are wholly given to him from among the children of Israel.
And you shall [note]1[/note]appoint Aaron and his sons, and they shall keep their priesthood; but the [note]2[/note]stranger who comes near shall be put to death.
verse.note: Or, number. See note [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
I.e., a layman, someone who was not a priest.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: As for Me, I have now [xref]a[/xref]taken the [note]1[/note]Levites from among the children of Israel instead of every firstborn who opens the womb among the children of Israel. So the Levites shall be Mine.
verse.note: The Levites replaced the firstborn of Israel ([link]vv. 5-9[/link], [link]11-37[/link], [link]39-51[/link]). Through the passover all the firstborn of Israel were redeemed, saved, and replaced ([link]Exo. 12:12-13[/link], [link]23[/link]; [link]13:11-15[/link]). Because of this, in succeeding generations all the firstborn males among the children of Israel were to be replaced by the Levites, the serving ones. Hence, the number of Levites had to equal the number of firstborn, and any shortage had to be redeemed. This replacing of the firstborn by the Levites, the serving ones, indicates that everyone who has been redeemed, saved, and replaced — all the believers in Christ — must serve (cf. [link]Matt. 25:14-30[/link]).

verse.text: For all the [xref]a[/xref]firstborn are Mine; on the day that I struck all the firstborn in the land of Egypt I sanctified to Myself all the firstborn in Israel, both man and beast. They shall be Mine; I am Jehovah.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai, saying,

verse.text: Number the children of Levi by their fathers' households, by their families; every male from a [xref]a[/xref]month old and upward you shall number.

chapter.verse: And Moses numbered them according to the word of Jehovah, as he was commanded.

verse.text: And these were the [note]1[/note]sons of Levi by their names: [xref]a[/xref]Gershon and Kohath and Merari.
verse.note: God gave Jacob twelve sons so that there could be twelve tribes encamped around the tabernacle, three tribes on each of the four sides ([link]ch. 2[/link]). God gave Levi three sons to camp around three sides of the tabernacle in the midst of the four camps ([link]2:17[/link]) — the Gershonites on the west ([link]v. 23[/link]), the Kohathites on the south ([link]v. 29[/link]), and the sons of Merari on the north ([link]v. 35[/link]). Moses, Aaron, and Aaron's sons camped on the east, in front of the tabernacle ([link]v. 38[/link]). Only God could provide the persons needed to have such an array. None of those involved in this array was hired; all were born. Likewise, the building up of the Body of Christ has nothing to do with hired persons; it is altogether a matter of the divine life through the divine birth and is therefore organic ([link]Eph. 4:11-16[/link]).

verse.text: And these are the names of the [xref]a[/xref]sons of Gershon according to their families: Libni and Shimei.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Kohath by their families: Amram and Izhar, Hebron and Uzziel.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Merari according to their families: Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the Levites according to their fathers' households.

chapter.verse: Of Gershon was the family of the Libnites and the family of the Shimeites; these are the families of the Gershonites.
Those who were numbered of them, according to the number of all the males, from a month old and upward, even those who were numbered of them were seven thousand five hundred.
The families of the Gershonites shall encamp behind the tabernacle on the west.
And the leader of the father's household of the Gershonites shall be Eliasaph the son of Lael.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And the charge of the sons of Gershon in the Tent of Meeting shall be the tabernacle and the [xref]b[/xref]tent, its [xref]c[/xref]covering and the [xref]d[/xref]screen for the entrance of the Tent of Meeting,

And the [xref]a[/xref]hangings of the court, and the [xref]b[/xref]screen for the entrance of the court, which is around the tabernacle and around the altar, and its [xref]c[/xref]cords for all its service.

chapter.verse: And of Kohath was the family of the Amramites and the family of the Izharites and the family of the Hebronites and the family of the Uzzielites; these are the families of the Kohathites.
According to the number of all the males, from a month old and upward, there were eight thousand six hundred, keeping the charge of the sanctuary.
The families of the sons of Kohath shall encamp on the side of the tabernacle to the south.
And the leader of the father's household of the families of the Kohathites shall be Elizaphan the son of Uzziel.

verse.text: And their [note]1[/note]charge shall be the [xref]a[/xref]Ark and the [xref]b[/xref]table and the [xref]c[/xref]lampstand and the [xref]d[/xref]altars and the utensils of the sanctuary with which they minister and the [xref]e[/xref]screen and all its service.
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup][/link]. The Kohathites were to take care of the contents of the tabernacle ([link]vv. 30-31[/link]; [link]4:15[/link]). Spiritually, this signifies taking care of Christ, i.e., ministering Christ to others by presenting to them all the aspects of the rich Christ signified by the Ark, the table of the bread of the Presence, the lampstand, the altar of burnt offering, the incense altar, the vessels of the sanctuary, and the veil. The principle is the same in caring for all the items related to the tabernacle. See notes in [link]Exo. 25-30[/link] concerning the different parts of the tabernacle.

chapter.verse: And Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest shall be leader of the leaders of the Levites [i]and have[/i] the oversight of those who keep the charge of the sanctuary.
Of Merari was the family of the Mahlites and the family of the Mushites; these are the families of Merari.
And those who were numbered of them, according to the number of all the males, from a month old and upward: six thousand two hundred.
And the leader of the father's household of the families of Merari was Zuriel the son of Abihail. They shall encamp on the side of the tabernacle to the north.

verse.text: And the appointed charge of the sons of Merari shall be the [xref]a[/xref]boards of the tabernacle and its [xref]b[/xref]bars and its [xref]c[/xref]pillars and its [xref]d[/xref]sockets and all its equipment and all the service [i]pertaining[/i] to it,
And the [xref]a[/xref]pillars around the court and their sockets and their [xref]b[/xref]pegs and their cords.

And those who encamp before the tabernacle to the east, before the Tent of Meeting toward the sunrise, shall be Moses and Aaron and his sons, keeping the [note]1[/note]charge of the sanctuary for the charge of the children of Israel; and the stranger who comes near shall be put to death.
verse.note: Aaron and his sons, the priests, were to keep the charge of the sanctuary ([link]vv. 32[/link], [link]38b[/link]), i.e., to be held responsible for the entire sanctuary — the tabernacle with its two sections, the Holy Place and the Holy of Holies — and everything related to it. They were to do this "for the charge of the children of Israel," meaning that if the children of Israel could not keep the charges given to them by God concerning the tabernacle, the priests were held responsible to correct the people or keep them away from the sanctuary or fulfill the charges for them. In principle those who serve as New Testament priests ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link], [link]9[/link]) bear the same responsibility for others' service.

chapter.verse: All who were numbered of the Levites, whom Moses and Aaron numbered at the commandment of Jehovah, by their families, all the males from a month old and upward were twenty-two thousand.
And Jehovah said to Moses, Number all the firstborn males of the children of Israel from a month old and upward, and take the number of their names.

verse.text: And you shall [xref]a[/xref]take the Levites for Me — I am Jehovah — instead of all the firstborn among the children of Israel, and the cattle of the Levites instead of all the firstborn among the cattle of the children of Israel.

chapter.verse: And Moses numbered, just as Jehovah commanded him, all the firstborn among the children of Israel.
And all the firstborn males according to the number of names, from a month old and upward, of those who were numbered of them were twenty-two thousand two hundred seventy-three.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Take the Levites instead of all the firstborn among the children of Israel, and the cattle of the Levites instead of their cattle; and the Levites shall be Mine; I am Jehovah.

verse.text: And for the [xref]a[/xref]redemption of the two hundred seventy-three of the firstborn of the children of Israel over and above [i]the number of[/i] the Levites,
You shall take [xref]a[/xref]five shekels apiece per head; according to the shekel of the sanctuary you shall take [i]them.[/i] (The shekel is twenty gerahs.)

chapter.verse: And you shall give the money, by which the excess number of them is redeemed, to Aaron and to his sons.
So Moses took the redemption money from those who were over and above those who were redeemed by the Levites;
From the firstborn of the children of Israel he took the money, a thousand three hundred sixty-five [i]shekels[/i] according to the shekel of the sanctuary.
And Moses gave the redemption money to Aaron and to his sons, according to the word of Jehovah, as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,
Take the sum of the sons of Kohath from among the sons of Levi, by their families, by their fathers' households,

verse.text: From [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]thirty years old and upward even to fifty years old, all who enter into the [note]2[/note]service to perform the skilled work in the Tent of Meeting.
verse.note: To serve as a Levite, one had to be between thirty and fifty years old ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]30[/link], [link]35[/link], [link]43[/link], [link]47[/link]). Likewise, the Lord Jesus did not reach the full age for God's service until He was thirty ([link]Luke 3:23[/link]). To be counted in the service to God, one had to be one month old and above — those at that age needed to grow and mature ([link]3:39[/link], [link]43[/link]). To be counted in the warfare for God's testimony, one had to be twenty years old or above — those at that age were mature and strong, without limit ([link]1:3[/link]). To be counted in the service that was close to God, one had to be between thirty and fifty years old — those at that age were more mature and were stronger, without deterioration.

See note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. So also in [link]vv. 23[/link], [link]30[/link], [link]35[/link], [link]39[/link], and [link]43[/link]. The holy service of the priests and the Levites was considered a warfare. Likewise, the service of the New Testament priests of the gospel of God ([link]Rom. 1:1[/link]; [link]15:16[/link]) for the building up of the Body of Christ is a warfare ([link]2 Cor. 10:3-5[/link]; [link]Eph. 6:12[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:18[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:7a[/link]).

chapter.verse: This is the service of the sons of Kohath in the Tent of Meeting [i]concerning[/i] the most holy things.

verse.text: When the camp [note]1[/note]sets out, [note]2[/note]Aaron and his sons shall go in, and they shall take down the [xref]a[/xref]veil of the screen and cover the [xref]b[/xref]Ark of the Testimony with it,
verse.note: The holy service of the priests and the Levites was for God's move. The tabernacle moved on the shoulders of the descendants of the three sons of Levi. This moving was in a very good sequence, with no confusion. In the same manner Christ, the embodiment of God for God's expansion, moves through those who love Him (cf. [link]Acts 1:8[/link]; [link]13:1-4[/link]).
See note [link]19[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And they shall put on it a covering of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]porpoise skin, and shall spread over [i]it[/i] a cloth all of [xref]b[/xref]blue [i]strands,[/i] and shall put in its [xref]c[/xref]poles.
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain. It probably refers to the skin of a sea animal such as the porpoise or sea cow. So throughout the chapter.

verse.text: And over the [xref]a[/xref]table [i]of the bread of[/i] the Presence they shall spread a blue cloth, and put on it the [xref]b[/xref]plates and the cups and the bowls and the pitchers of the [note]1[/note]drink offering; and the continual [xref]c[/xref]bread shall be on it.
verse.note: See note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in Lev. 23[/link].

verse.text: And they shall spread over them a [xref]a[/xref]scarlet cloth, and cover it with a covering of porpoise skin, and shall put in its [xref]b[/xref]poles.
And they shall take a blue cloth, and cover the [xref]a[/xref]lampstand of the light and its lamps and its tongs and its firepans and all its oil vessels with which they minister to it.

chapter.verse: And they shall put it and all its utensils within a covering of porpoise skin, and shall put it on the carrying frame.

verse.text: And over the golden [xref]a[/xref]altar they shall spread a blue cloth, and cover it with a covering of porpoise skin, and shall put in its poles.

And they shall take all the [xref]a[/xref]utensils of ministry with which they minister in the sanctuary, and put them in a blue cloth, and cover them with a covering of porpoise skin, and shall put them on the carrying frame.
And they shall remove the ashes from the altar, and spread a [xref]a[/xref]purple cloth over it.

chapter.verse: And they shall put upon it all its utensils with which they minister at it, the firepans, the forks, and the shovels, and the basins — all the utensils of the altar; and they shall spread over it a covering of porpoise skin, and put in its poles.

verse.text: And when Aaron and his sons have finished covering the sanctuary and all the furnishings of the sanctuary, whenever the camp sets out, then the sons of Kohath shall come to [xref]a[/xref]carry [i]them;[/i] but they shall not touch the holy things, or they will die. These things are the burden of the sons of Kohath in the Tent of Meeting.

And the oversight of Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest shall be the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]oil for the light and the fragrant [xref]b[/xref]incense and the continual meal offering and the [xref]c[/xref]anointing oil, the oversight of all the tabernacle and all that is in it, the sanctuary and its furnishings.
verse.note: All the items over which Eleazar was responsible signify different aspects of the rich Christ. See notes [link book="Num." chapter="3"]8[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link], and notes in [link]Exo. 25-30[/link] concerning the items of the tabernacle.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,
Do not let the tribe of the families of the Kohathites be cut off from among the Levites;

verse.text: But do this to them that they may live and not die when they approach the most holy things: Aaron and his sons shall go in and [note]1[/note]assign each one of them to his service and to his burden;
verse.note: In addition to carrying out their own duties in the setting out of the tabernacle ([link]vv. 5-14[/link]), the priests appointed the Levites to do their service ([link]vv. 19[/link], [link]27-28[/link], [link]33[/link]). In the Old Testament there was a distinction between the priests and the Levites. However, in the New Testament there is only one class, that of the priests ([link]Rom. 15:16[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:6[/link]; [link]5:10[/link]), which includes the Levites. Hence, what the Levites did in the Old Testament in type, the believers as the New Testament priests should also do in reality. The fact that the service of the Levites was under the supervision of the priests indicates that when the New Testament priests do the outward Levitical work, they must do it under the supervision of the inward, spiritual view of the New Testament priesthood. The Levitical service should never be separated from the priestly view. The outward service must become a spiritual activity that ministers life to others.

verse.text: But [note]1[/note]the Kohathites shall not go in to [xref]a[/xref]see the sanctuary even for a moment; otherwise they will die.
verse.note: Lit., they.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Take the sum of the sons of Gershon also, by their fathers' households, by their families;
From thirty years old and upward to fifty years old you shall number them, everyone who enters to carry out the service to do the work in the Tent of Meeting.

verse.text: This is the [xref]a[/xref]service of the families of the Gershonites, in serving and in bearing burdens:

They shall carry the [xref]a[/xref]curtains of the tabernacle, and the Tent of Meeting, its [xref]b[/xref]covering, and the covering of porpoise [i]skin[/i] that is on top of it, and the [xref]c[/xref]screen for the entrance of the Tent of Meeting,

And the [xref]a[/xref]hangings of the court, and the [xref]b[/xref]screen for the entrance of the gate of the court, which is around the tabernacle and around the altar, and their [xref]c[/xref]cords, and all the equipment for their service; and whatever is to be done with them, so shall they do.

chapter.verse: All the service of the sons of the Gershonites shall be at the command of Aaron and his sons, in all their burden and in all their service; and you shall assign to them the charge of all they are to carry.
This is the service of the families of the sons of the Gershonites in the Tent of Meeting, and their charge shall be under the direction of Ithamar the son of Aaron the priest.
As for the sons of Merari, you shall number them by their families, by their fathers' households;
From thirty years old and upward even to fifty years old you shall number them, everyone who enters into the service to do the work of the Tent of Meeting.

verse.text: And this is the [xref]a[/xref]charge of what they are to carry, according to all their service in the Tent of Meeting: the [xref]b[/xref]boards of the tabernacle and its [xref]c[/xref]bars and its pillars and its [xref]d[/xref]sockets,

And the [xref]a[/xref]pillars around the court and their sockets and their pegs and their cords, with all their equipment and with all their service; and you shall assign by name the equipment they have been charged to carry.

chapter.verse: This is the service of the families of the sons of Merari, according to all their service in the Tent of Meeting, under the direction of Ithamar the son of Aaron the priest.
And Moses and Aaron and the leaders of the assembly numbered the sons of the Kohathites by their families and by their fathers' households,
From thirty years old and upward even to fifty years old, everyone who entered into the service for work in the Tent of Meeting.
And those who were numbered of them by their families were two thousand seven hundred fifty.
These are those who were numbered of the families of the Kohathites, all who served in the Tent of Meeting, whom Moses and Aaron numbered according to the commandment of Jehovah through Moses.
And those who were numbered of the sons of Gershon by their families and by their fathers' households,
From thirty years old and upward even to fifty years old, everyone who entered into the service for work in the Tent of Meeting,
Even those who were numbered of them, by their families, by their fathers' households were two thousand six hundred thirty.
These were those who were numbered of the families of the sons of Gershon, everyone who served in the Tent of Meeting, whom Moses and Aaron numbered according to the commandment of Jehovah.
And those who were numbered of the families of the sons of Merari, by their families, by their fathers' households,
From thirty years old and upward even to fifty years old, everyone who entered into the service for work in the Tent of Meeting,
Even those who were numbered of them by their families were three thousand two hundred.
These were those who were numbered of the families of the sons of Merari, whom Moses and Aaron numbered according to the commandment of Jehovah through Moses.
All those who were numbered of the Levites, whom Moses and Aaron and the leaders of Israel numbered, by their families and by their fathers' households,
From thirty years old and upward even to fifty years old, everyone who entered to do the work of service and the work of bearing burdens in the Tent of Meeting,
Even those who were numbered of them were eight thousand five hundred eighty.

According to the commandment of Jehovah through Moses they were numbered, everyone according to his service and according to his burden; thus they were numbered by him, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Command the children of Israel that they send out of the camp every [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]leper and everyone that has a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]discharge and everyone who is unclean because of a [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref][i]dead[/i] person.
verse.note: The three kinds of defilement dealt with in the camp of Israel typify all the uncleanness that needs to be dealt with in the church. Leprosy signifies the evil issues of the natural man, especially in rebellion (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 13[/link]). Spiritually, discharges are the excessive, abnormal, and unrestrained issues of the natural man, signifying one's being without control, unbridled, in relation to one's self, temper, preferences, likes, and dislikes (see notes [link book="Lev." chapter="15"]2[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 15[/link]). Uncleanness through contact with the dead signifies the defilement of spiritual deadness that issues from contacting those who are spiritually dead (see notes on [link]Lev. 11:31[/link]). God is righteous, holy, and living. Thus, these three kinds of defilement cannot be allowed to remain in God's dwelling place, army, and priesthood.

verse.text: You shall send out both male and female; you shall send them outside the camp so that they will not defile their camp, where [xref]a[/xref]I dwell in their midst.

chapter.verse: And the children of Israel did so and sent them outside the camp; just as Jehovah had spoken to Moses, so the children of Israel did.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to the children of Israel, When a man or woman commits any sin that men [i]commit,[/i] so as to act unfaithfully toward Jehovah, and that person realizes [i]his[/i] guilt,

verse.text: Then they shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]confess their sin which they have committed, and he shall [note]1[/note]make restitution according to its principal for his wrong and add to it [xref]b[/xref]one-fifth of it and give [i]it[/i] to the one whom he has wronged.
verse.note: To deal with the guilt of our sinning against God is to deal with the defilement of unrighteousness, of being guilty before man and condemned before God. After making a thorough confession of our sins to God ([link]1 John 1:9[/link]), we should go to the one we have wronged to make restitution in full for our trespass, even adding something to what we owe ([link]Luke 19:8b[/link]).

verse.text: But if the man has no [note]1[/note]kinsman to whom restitution may be made for the wrong, the restitution which is made for the wrong [i]goes[/i] to Jehovah for the priest, in addition to the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]ram of the expiation, by which expiation is made for him.
verse.note: If the wronged one is deceased, then the restitution should go to his relative. If the deceased one has no relatives, the restitution becomes holy, like a holy portion given to God for the priest. In this case we may give the restitution to the church or to one who serves God as a priest and lives by faith.

The ram of the expiation here typifies Christ as the propitiation for our sins ([link]1 John 2:2[/link]; [link]4:10[/link]; see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 16[/link]). In dealing with the defilement of unrighteousness, first we confess our sin to God and then go to make restitution (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Afterward, we come back to God to offer Christ as our propitiatory sacrifice. This process shows how fine and detailed God is.

verse.text: And every [xref]a[/xref]heave offering of all the holy things of the children of Israel, which they present to the priest, shall be his.

chapter.verse: And everyone's holy things shall be his; whatever anyone gives to the priest, it becomes his.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to the children of Israel and say to them, If any man's wife goes astray and acts unfaithfully toward him,

And a man lies with her [i]and has[/i] sexual relations, and it is hidden from the eyes of her husband, and she is undetected, and she is defiled, and there is no witness against her since she was not caught in the act;

verse.text: And a spirit of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]jealousy comes upon him, and he is jealous of his wife, and she has defiled herself; or if a spirit of jealousy comes upon him, and he is jealous of his wife, and she has not defiled herself;
verse.note: The dealing with a wife over whom her husband was jealous typifies Christ's jealousy over His believers and His church ([link]2 Cor. 11:2-3[/link]). Christ's fighting army is composed of His overcomers, who are a fighting wife to match Christ ([link]Rev. 19:7-9[/link], [link]11-14[/link]). In order to be a part of the Lord's fighting army, we must be chaste toward Him. Our seeking and pursuing anything other than Christ is spiritual adultery in the eyes of God (cf. [link]James 4:4[/link]). Those who commit spiritual adultery will be judged and cursed by God ([link]1 Cor. 16:22[/link]) and will not be able to fight for God and serve God.

verse.text: Then the man shall bring his wife to the [note]1[/note]priest and bring her offering for her, a tenth of an ephah of barley meal. He shall pour [xref]a[/xref]no oil upon it nor put frankincense on it; for it is a [note]2[/note]meal offering of jealousy, a meal offering of remembrance, bringing iniquity to remembrance.
verse.note: The priest here may signify Christ or someone who is very close to God.

The meal offering signifies Christ in His humanity offered to God that God's people may be acceptable (see notes in [link]Lev. 2[/link]). In this case, the meal offering was of barley meal (the resurrected Christ — see note [link]9[sup]2[/sup], par. 2, in John 6[/link]) with no oil (the Holy Spirit) or frankincense (resurrection) upon it. Such a meal offering of jealousy brought iniquity to remembrance.

chapter.verse: And the priest shall bring her near and set her before Jehovah.
And the priest shall take holy water in an earthen vessel, and the priest shall take some of the dust that is on the floor of the tabernacle and put [i]it[/i] into the water.

verse.text: And the priest shall set the woman before Jehovah and let the [note]1[/note]hair of the woman's head go loose and put the meal offering of remembrance in her hands, which is the meal offering of jealousy, and in the hand of the priest shall be the water of bitterness that brings the curse.
verse.note: The letting of the woman's hair go loose shows that she had not subjected herself to the headship (cf. [link]1 Cor. 11:10[/link], [link]15[/link]).

chapter.verse: And the priest shall make her take an oath and shall say to the woman, If no man has lain with you and if you have not gone astray to uncleanness while under [i]the authority of[/i] your husband, be immune to this water of bitterness that brings the curse.
But if you have gone astray while under [i]the authority of[/i] your husband and if you have defiled yourself, and a man besides your husband has lain with you —

Then the priest shall make the woman take an oath with the oath of cursing, and the priest shall say to the woman — Jehovah make you a curse and an oath among your people, when Jehovah makes your thigh waste away and your womb swell;

verse.text: And this water that brings the curse shall go into your bowels and make your womb swell and your thigh waste away. And the woman shall say, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Amen, Amen.
verse.note: A Hebrew adjective meaning [i]firm, steadfast.[/i]

chapter.verse: And the priest shall write these curses in a book, and he shall wash them off into the water of bitterness.
And he shall make the woman drink the water of bitterness that brings the curse; and the water that brings the curse shall enter into her [i]and become[/i] bitter.

verse.text: And the priest shall take the meal offering of jealousy out of the woman's hand, and he shall [note]1[/note]wave the meal offering before Jehovah and bring it to the altar.
verse.note: The waving of the meal offering signifies resurrection (see note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 29[/link]). The handful of the meal offering that was burned on the altar was offered to God as a memorial portion ([link]v. 26[/link]).

chapter.verse: And the priest shall take a handful of the meal offering as its memorial portion and burn [i]it[/i] upon the altar, and afterward he shall make the woman drink the water.

verse.text: And when he has made her drink the water, then if she has defiled herself and has acted unfaithfully to her husband, the water that brings the curse will enter into her [i]and become[/i] bitter, and her [note]1[/note]womb will swell, and her [note]1[/note]thigh will waste away; and the woman shall be a curse among her people.
verse.note: For the womb (abdomen) to swell meant that it became abnormal. For the thigh to waste away meant that the woman's strength was decreasing. Such a dealing was surely miraculous.

chapter.verse: But if the woman has not defiled herself and is clean, then she will be immune and able to conceive seed.
This is the law of jealousy when a wife, while under [i]the authority of[/i] her husband, goes astray and defiles herself,
Or when the spirit of jealousy comes upon a man, and he is jealous of his wife. He shall set the woman before Jehovah, and the priest shall apply to her all this law.
And the man shall be free from iniquity, but that woman shall bear her iniquity.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel and say to them, When a man or a woman [note]1[/note]makes a [xref]a[/xref]special vow, the vow of a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Nazarite, to [note]3[/note]separate himself to Jehovah,
verse.note: Lit., shall be wonderful to vow a vow. A Nazarite was sanctified by making a special vow to separate himself to God. The priests, who were such by birth, were ordained by God out of His initiation, whereas the Nazarite, who became such by a vow, was separated to God by himself out of his initiation. God's ordaining of one family (Aaron's) to be the priests excluded all others from this opportunity. But the vow of the Nazarite opens the gate, affording all the people of God an equal opportunity to be absolutely for God as a warrior ([link]Judg. 13:5[/link]) or as a priest ([link]1 Sam. 1:11[/link]; [link]2:11[/link]). Whoever is willing may take this opportunity on his own initiative. The accomplishing of God's purpose requires man's cooperation to complement God's ordination, as illustrated by the case of Samuel, who as a Nazarite fulfilled the duty of a priest, complementing the deficient Eli, a priest ordained by God ([link]1 Sam. 1-3[/link]).

God desires that all His people be Nazarites. To be a Nazarite is to be sanctified, separated, absolutely and ultimately to God, i.e., to be for nothing other than God. Cf. note [link]19[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 6[/link].[br][br]According to typology, among the human race the unique Nazarite is the Lord Jesus Christ. Hence, a Nazarite is a type of Christ in His living absolutely for God in His humanity ([link]John 5:30[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:8[/link]).

Heb. [i]nazar;[/i] the root of the noun [i]Nazarite.[/i] Separation unto God is on the negative side, and sanctification to God is on the positive side. Such a separating and sanctifying of oneself to God should follow the dealing with all the defilements and the test of chastity ([link]ch. 5[/link]).

verse.text: He shall separate himself from [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]wine and strong drink; he shall drink no vinegar of wine or vinegar of strong drink, nor shall he drink any juice of grapes, nor eat fresh or dried grapes.
verse.note: Abstaining from wine and anything related to its source ([link]vv. 3-4[/link]) signifies abstaining from all kinds of earthly enjoyment and pleasure (cf. [link]Psa. 104:15[/link]; [link]Eccl. 10:19[/link]) and from anything that issues in earthly enjoyment or pleasure. A Nazarite, one who is absolutely for God, is altogether separated from anything of earthly pleasures (cf. [link]Matt. 8:20[/link]; [link]James 4:4[/link]; [link]1 John 2:15[/link]).

chapter.verse: All the days of his separation he shall eat nothing that is produced by the grape vine, from the seeds even to the skin.

verse.text: All the days of his vow of separation [xref]a[/xref]no [note]1[/note]razor shall pass over his head. He shall be holy until the days are fulfilled for which he separated himself to Jehovah; he shall let the locks of the hair of his head grow long.
verse.note: Not shaving the head signifies not rejecting but being absolutely subject to the headship of the Lord (cf. [link]1 Cor. 11:3[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]15[/link]) as well as to all deputy authorities appointed by God ([link]Rom. 13:1-2a[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:21[/link], [link]23[/link]; [link]6:1[/link]; [link]Heb. 13:17[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 5:5[/link]). Cf. note [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]All the days that he separates himself to Jehovah he shall not come near a [note]1[/note]dead person.
verse.note: The most hateful thing in the eyes of God is death. A Nazarite must not touch anything dead so that he might not be defiled. See note [link]31[sup]2[/sup] in Lev. 11[/link].

verse.text: He shall not make himself unclean for his father or for his mother, for his brother or for his sister, when they die, because [note]1[/note]his separation to God is upon his head.
verse.note: Or, separation to his God. A Nazarite should not be defiled by the death of his blood relatives, the relatives closest to him, but should remain in his separation to be holy to God. This signifies that we should not be defiled by the deadness that comes through natural affection, but should keep ourselves clean in our sanctification (cf. [link]Matt. 12:46-50[/link]). The defilement of death will make void our Nazarite vow.

chapter.verse: All the days of his separation he is holy to Jehovah.

verse.text: And if anyone dies very [note]1[/note]suddenly beside him so that he defiles the head of his separation, then he shall shave his head on the day he becomes clean; on the seventh day shall he [xref]a[/xref]shave it.
verse.note: If the head of a Nazarite's separation was defiled by the sudden death of one beside him, he was to be cleansed on the seventh day (the last day of his separation — [link]Acts 21:27[/link]) by shaving his head. This indicates that if we are defiled by some unexpected deadness, we should be cleansed by reseparating ourselves to the Lord.

verse.text: And on the [note]1[/note]eighth day he shall bring [xref]a[/xref]two turtledoves or two young pigeons to the priest at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting,
verse.note: The first day of a new week, signifying the day of resurrection ([link]John 20:1[/link]). On the eighth day the Nazarite was to have a new beginning by bringing two turtledoves or two young pigeons to the priest, one for a sin offering ([link]Lev. 4[/link]) and the other for a burnt offering ([link]Lev. 1[/link]), to make expiation for him ([link]vv. 10-11[/link]). This signifies that we should offer Christ as both the sin offering and the burnt offering, in resurrection, for our forgiveness through His redemption ([link]Eph. 1:7[/link]).

verse.text: And the priest shall offer one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering, and make expiation for him because he sinned by reason of the [i]dead[/i] person. And he shall [note]1[/note]sanctify his head that same day.
verse.note: The Nazarite's sanctifying his head means that he was to have a new consecration for his subjection under the headship.

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]separate to Jehovah the days of his separation and shall bring a male lamb a year old for a trespass offering, but the former days shall be void because his separation was defiled.
verse.note: This was a new vow of consecration for the Nazarite to separate himself to God again. For this he needed a lamb for a trespass offering. His failure in his vow was a sin, for which he needed a sin offering ([link]vv. 10-11[/link]). His mistake in touching something dead was a trespass, for which he needed a trespass offering. Once our former separation has been made void, we should reseparate ourselves to God by taking Christ as our trespass offering.

verse.text: Now this is the law of the Nazarite when the [note]1[/note]days of his separation are [xref]a[/xref]fulfilled: He shall be brought to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
verse.note: The Nazarite's separation lasted for seven days ([link]Acts 21:27[/link]), signifying a full course, even a lifetime (cf. note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 5[/link]). Each of the offerings brought to God by the Nazarite was a type of Christ. The enjoyment of Christ as these offerings indicates the overcoming of natural affection, earthly pleasure, rebellion, and death (see notes [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link] through [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: And he shall present his offering to Jehovah: one [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]male lamb a year old without blemish for a burnt offering, and one [note]2[/note]female lamb a year old without blemish for a sin offering, and one [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]ram without blemish for a peace offering,
verse.note: Here [i]male[/i] signifies strong, [i]lamb[/i] signifies meek, [i]a year old[/i] signifies fresh, and [i]without blemish[/i] signifies without defects. The lamb for a burnt offering typifies Christ as our burnt offering that we may be acceptable to God in Him and live to God by Him (see notes on the burnt offering in [link]Lev. 1[/link]). In offering the burnt offering, the offerer laid his hands on the offering ([link]Lev. 1:4[/link]), thus identifying himself with the offering and making himself one with the offering. This signifies our offering not only Christ Himself but also ourselves identified with Christ. The completion of the Nazarite's days of separation signifies not an ending but a beginning of a life of the burnt offering, a life absolutely, utterly, and ultimately for God.

Here a female lamb signifies submission. It typifies Christ as our sin offering for our redemption. Because we are still in the old creation, at the beginning of our Nazarite life we need God's redemption, which has been completed in Christ ([link]Heb. 9:12[/link]).

The ram here signifies being strong for enjoyment. It typifies Christ as our peace offering for our mutual enjoyment with God in fellowship with peace. The result of the burnt offering and the sin offering is the peace offering. Cf. note [link]37[sup]2[/sup] in Lev. 7[/link].

verse.text: And a [note]1[/note]basket of [xref]a[/xref]unleavened bread, cakes of fine flour mingled with oil, and unleavened wafers anointed with oil, and their meal offering and their [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]drink offerings.
verse.note: In this verse [i]a basket[/i] signifies fullness, [i]unleavened[/i] signifies without sin, [i]bread[/i] signifies formed, [i]cakes[/i] signifies more formed, [i]fine[/i] signifies even and balanced, [i]flour[/i] signifies Christ ground in His humanity, [i]with oil[/i] signifies with the Holy Spirit (divinity), [i]wafers[/i] signifies easy to eat, [i]anointed[/i] signifies poured upon, [i]meal offering[/i] signifies holy food, and [i]drink offerings[/i] signifies holy drinks for God. All this typifies Christ in His humanity with His divinity offered to God for us as food both to God and to us and also as holy drinks to God.
See note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in Lev. 23[/link].

chapter.verse: And the priest shall present them before Jehovah and offer his sin offering and his burnt offering.
And he shall offer the ram for a sacrifice of peace offerings to Jehovah, with the basket of unleavened bread. The priest shall also offer its meal offering and its drink offering.

verse.text: And the Nazarite shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]shave the head of his separation at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, and take the hair of the head of his separation and put [i]it[/i] on the fire that is under the sacrifice of peace offerings.
verse.note: The shaving of the head did not mean that the Nazarite put away the headship and gave up his submission. The Nazarite had offered the burnt offering ([link]v. 14[/link]), which was a promise to God that he would continue for his whole life to live as in the days of his separation.

verse.text: And the priest shall take the boiled [note]1[/note]shoulder of the ram and one unleavened cake out of the basket and one unleavened wafer, and shall put [i]them[/i] into the hands of the Nazarite after he has shaved [i]the head of[/i] his separation;
verse.note: In [link]vv. 19-20[/link] the shoulder signifies strength to bear, to wave signifies to offer in resurrection, the breast signifies love to embrace, the wave offering signifies resurrection, and the heave offering signifies ascension. All of the above refer to Christ in different aspects. The types here signify that the believer who separates himself by a vow to be a Nazarite and becomes a serving one of God will be supplied by Christ with Himself as the life supply in different aspects in His resurrection and ascension.

verse.text: And the priest shall wave them for a [xref]a[/xref]wave offering before Jehovah. It is holy for the priest, together with the breast of the wave offering and thigh of the heave offering. And afterward the Nazarite may drink wine.

chapter.verse: This is the law of the Nazarite who vows, [i]that is, of[/i] his offering to Jehovah for his separation, in addition to what he can afford; according to his vow which he vows, so he must do according to the law of his separation.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to Aaron and to his sons, saying, Thus you shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bless the children of Israel; you shall say to them,
verse.note: The blessing in [link]vv. 23-27[/link] comes after the dealing with defilement ([link]5:1-10[/link]), the test for chastity ([link]5:11-31[/link]), and the Nazarite vow ([link]vv. 1-21[/link]). This blessing, like that in [link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link], is not outward and material. Rather, it is the eternal blessing of the Triune God, which is the Triune God dispensing Himself in His Divine Trinity into us for our enjoyment. In the entire universe the unique blessing is the Triune God, and this blessing comes to us through the dispensing of the divine Being into us in His Divine Trinity — in the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. [link]Ephesians 1[/link] gives us a record of how the Triune God blesses His chosen, redeemed, and transformed people in His Divine Trinity, issuing in the church as the Body of Christ, the fullness of the One who fills all in all (see notes in [link]Eph. 1[/link]). As the consummation of the entire record of the Bible, the New Jerusalem is the very God in His Divine Trinity — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit — mingled with His chosen, redeemed, transformed, and glorified people as their eternal blessing. Such a blessing is the ultimate fulfillment of God's blessing to Israel in [link]Num. 6[/link].[br][br]"Jehovah bless you and keep you" ([link]v. 24[/link]) can be ascribed to the Father; "Jehovah make His face shine upon you and be gracious to you" ([link]v. 25[/link]) can be ascribed to the Son; and "Jehovah lift up His countenance upon you and give you peace" ([link]v. 26[/link]) can be ascribed to the Holy Spirit. The Father blesses us, the Son shines upon us, and the Holy Spirit lifts up His countenance upon us. As a result, we are kept, we receive grace, and we have peace.

verse.text: Jehovah [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bless you and [xref]b[/xref]keep you;
verse.note: The Father blesses us in every way and in every aspect in His love (cf. [link]Eph. 1:3[/link]), and He keeps us in every way and in every aspect in His power (cf. [link]John 17:11[/link], [link]15[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:5[/link]).

verse.text: Jehovah make His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]face [note]2[/note]shine upon you and be [xref]b[/xref]gracious to you;
verse.note: The word [i]face[/i] here signifies presence. As the One whose face shines upon us, Christ the Son is the visible presence of the invisible God (cf. [link]John 14:7-9[/link]). God and His presence are invisible, but through His incarnation He became the shining sun ([link]Luke 1:78[/link]; cf. [link]Matt. 4:16[/link]; [link]John 8:12[/link]). This shining sun is God's invisible presence becoming visible.

Jehovah's face shining on us and His being gracious to us are equivalent to God's incarnation as the shining of His presence, which was accompanied by grace ([link]John 1:14[/link], [link]16-17[/link]). For the Lord to be gracious to us means that He is continually grace to us. This grace is the grace of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 13:14a[/link]), which is actually Christ Himself.

verse.text: Jehovah lift up His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]countenance upon you and give you [xref]b[/xref]peace.
verse.note: The face ([link]v. 25[/link]) denotes the presence of the person, and the countenance denotes the expression of the person. To lift up one's countenance upon a person means to confirm, assure, promise, and give everything to that person. Jesus, the Son, came as the face of God (see note [link]25[sup]1[/sup][/link]), and the Holy Spirit comes as the countenance of God (cf. [link]Eph. 4:30[/link]). When the Triune God is dispensed into us, we have the face of the Triune God and also His countenance. Eventually, we are kept in the Triune God, the Triune God becomes grace to us, and we have peace.

verse.text: So shall they put My [xref]a[/xref]name upon the children of Israel, that I Myself may bless them.

And on the day that Moses had finished setting up the [xref]a[/xref]tabernacle, and had [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]anointed it and sanctified it and all its furnishings and the altar and all its utensils, and had anointed them and sanctified them,
verse.note: The anointing oil, a compound of olive oil and four spices, typifies the compound, all-inclusive Spirit as the consummation of the processed Triune God, who includes Christ's divinity, humanity, incarnation, human living, death, resurrection, and ascension ([link]Exo. 30:23-25[/link] and note [link]25[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Hence, to anoint signifies to apply the processed and consummated Triune God with all His elements and processes as a whole to the object of the anointing, thus making this object absolutely one with the compounded, consummated God. For us to be anointed ([link]2 Cor. 1:21[/link]) means that the processed Triune God is put into us and upon us and even mingled with us to make us God-men, those who are one with God. See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 30[/link].

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]leaders of Israel, the heads of their fathers' households (they were the leaders of the tribes, who were over those who had been numbered), presented [i]their offering.[/i]

And they brought their offering before Jehovah: [note]1[/note]six covered wagons and twelve oxen, a wagon for [i]every[/i] two of the leaders and an ox for each one; and they presented them before the tabernacle.
verse.note: The offering of six wagons and twelve oxen was for the transporting of the tabernacle (not including its furnishings — [link]v. 9[/link]) and the altar ([link]vv. 7-8[/link]), and it was to match God's move in His dwelling place on the earth. According to His New Testament economy, God will not move, act, or do anything by Himself. He needs man's cooperation and coordination. In Numbers the omnipotent God moved in a portable home in wagons drawn by oxen. Similarly, today God needs His people to offer themselves to Him as the means for His move.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Take [i]these[/i] from them that they may be used in doing the service of the Tent of Meeting; and you shall give them to the Levites, to each according to his service.
And Moses took the wagons and the oxen, and gave them to the Levites.

verse.text: Two wagons and four oxen he gave to the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Gershon according to their service;
And four wagons and eight oxen he gave to the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Merari according to their service, under the direction of Ithamar the son of Aaron the priest.
But to the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Kohath he gave none, because the service of the sanctuary belonged to them; they bore [i]this[/i] upon their shoulder.
And the leaders presented [note]1[/note][i]offerings[/i] for the [xref]a[/xref]dedication of the altar in the day that it was anointed; that is, the leaders presented their offering before the altar.
verse.note: In their cooperating with God for His service, the leaders of the twelve tribes of Israel offered twelve silver plates, twelve silver basins, and twelve gold cups full of incense ([link]vv. 84-86[/link]), signifying Christ in His redemption (silver) and His divine nature (gold) as a fragrant satisfaction (incense) to God. Because the offerers were sinful, in their coordinating with God they also offered twelve oxen, twelve rams, twelve lambs a year old, and their meal offering for the burnt offering; twelve male goats for a sin offering; and twenty-four oxen, sixty rams, sixty male goats, and sixty male lambs a year old for the peace offering ([link]vv. 87-88[/link]). These offerings signify Christ as our sin offering to redeem us from sin, Christ as our burnt offering for our living to God, and Christ as our peace offering, through which we and God enjoy Christ mutually in peace. All these offerings were for the worship of God, signifying that in order to worship God, we must offer ourselves to Him; then we must offer Christ as our sin offering, burnt offering, and peace offering so that we and God may enjoy Christ in mutuality and be satisfied with Him.[br][br]Twelve is the number of absolute perfection and eternal completion in God's administration (see notes [link book="Rev." chapter="21"]12[sup]2[/sup][/link], [link book="Rev." chapter="21"]16[sup]2[/sup][/link], and [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 21[/link]). The offerings were offered by the twelve tribes in twelve days, and the number of the sacrifices was twelve multiplied either by one (twelve), two (twenty-four), or five (sixty), signifying that the offering time, the offering people, and the offerings were absolutely perfect and eternally complete in God's administration.

verse.text: This was the [xref]a[/xref]dedication of the altar, in the day when it was anointed, by the leaders of Israel: twelve silver plates, twelve silver bowls, twelve golden cups;

chapter.verse: Each silver plate [i]weighing[/i] one hundred thirty shekels, and each bowl seventy; all the silver of the vessels was two thousand four hundred [i]shekels,[/i] according to the shekel of the sanctuary;
The twelve golden cups, full of incense, [i]weighing[/i] ten [i]shekels[/i] each, according to the shekel of the sanctuary; all the gold of the cups was one hundred twenty [i]shekels;[/i]
All the livestock for the burnt offering: twelve bulls, twelve rams, twelve male lambs a year old and their meal offering; and twelve males of the goats for a sin offering;
And all the livestock for the sacrifice of peace offerings: twenty-four bulls, sixty rams, sixty male goats, sixty male lambs a year old. This was the dedication of the altar, after it was anointed.

verse.text: And when Moses went into the Tent of Meeting to [xref]a[/xref]speak with Him, he heard the voice speaking to him from above the expiation cover that was upon the Ark of the Testimony, from between the two [xref]b[/xref]cherubim; and [note]1[/note]he spoke to Him.
verse.note: Or, He (Jehovah) spoke to him (Moses).

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to Aaron and say to him, When you set up the lamps, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]seven lamps will give light in front of the lampstand.
verse.note: The seven lamps, signifying the seven Spirits ([link]Rev. 4:5[/link]), gave light in front of the lampstand, shining toward the middle of the tabernacle. Thus, the shining of the lamps was in the right direction for serving and moving. At this point God's people could begin to render their spiritual service to Him.

chapter.verse: And Aaron did so; he set up its lamps [i]to give light[/i] in front of the lampstand, as Jehovah had commanded Moses.

verse.text: Now this was the workmanship of the lampstand, [xref]a[/xref]beaten work of gold; from its base to its flowers it was beaten work. According to the [note]1[/note]pattern which Jehovah had shown Moses, so he made the lampstand.
verse.note: Or, vision; thing seen (different from the word used in [link]Exo. 25:9[/link], [link]40[/link]). For the workmanship of the lampstand, see notes in [link]Exo. 25:31-40[/link].

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Take the Levites from among the children of Israel and cleanse them.

verse.text: And thus you shall do to them to [note]1[/note]cleanse them: Sprinkle the [xref]a[/xref]water of purification upon them, and let them pass a [xref]b[/xref]razor over all their flesh and wash their clothes and cleanse themselves.
verse.note: Concerning the cleansing of the Levites, sprinkling the water of purification upon the Levites signifies the application of the effectiveness of the redemption of Christ upon the serving believers; shaving off all the hair of the body signifies the cutting off of all the natural strength; washing their clothes and cleansing themselves signify dealing with their conduct and their person; and offering the sin offering, the burnt offering, and the meal offering ([link]vv. 8[/link], [link]12[/link]) indicates that the Levites needed Christ to be their offerings and their replacement because they were sinful, because they should live for God, and because they should live as Christ lived in His humanity (see notes in [link]Lev. 1-5[/link] for the significance of the offerings).

chapter.verse: Then let them take a bull of the herd and its meal offering, fine flour mingled with oil; and a second bull of the herd you shall take for a sin offering.

verse.text: And you shall present the Levites before the [xref]a[/xref]Tent of Meeting and gather the whole [xref]b[/xref]assembly of the children of Israel.
And you shall present the Levites before Jehovah, and the children of Israel shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lay their hands upon the Levites.
verse.note: The services of the tabernacle should have been taken care of by the sons of Israel, yet God chose the Levites to replace the sons of Israel ([link]vv. 16-18[/link]; [link]3:12[/link] and note; see note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 32[/link]). The laying on of hands here signifies that the sons of Israel identified themselves with the Levites, meaning that in the presenting of the Levites, all the sons of Israel were presented to God.

verse.text: And Aaron shall offer the Levites before Jehovah as a [note]1[/note]wave offering from the children of Israel, that they may do the service of Jehovah.
verse.note: A wave offering typifies the resurrected Christ (see note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 29[/link]). The Levites as living persons were offered as a wave offering that they might do the service of God (cf. [link]Rom. 12:1[/link], [link]4-6a[/link]).

verse.text: And the Levites shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lay their hands upon the heads of the bulls, and you shall offer the one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering to Jehovah to make expiation for the Levites.
verse.note: For the Levites to lay their hands on the bulls meant that they identified themselves with the bulls. Through the laying on of hands three parties — the sons of Israel ([link]v. 10[/link]), the Levites, and the bulls — were identified with one another.

chapter.verse: And you shall set the Levites before Aaron and before his sons, and offer them as a wave offering to Jehovah.

verse.text: Thus you shall [xref]a[/xref]separate the Levites from among the children of Israel, and the Levites shall be Mine.

chapter.verse: Then after this the Levites may go in to do the service of the Tent of Meeting. So you shall cleanse them and offer them as a wave offering.

verse.text: For they are wholly given to Me from among the children of Israel; I have [xref]a[/xref]taken them for Myself instead of everyone who opens the womb, the firstborn of all the children of Israel.
For all the [xref]a[/xref]firstborn among the children of Israel are Mine, both human and animal. On the day that I struck down all the firstborn in the land of Egypt I sanctified them for Myself.

chapter.verse: And I have taken the Levites instead of all the firstborn among the children of Israel.

verse.text: And I have given the Levites as a [xref]a[/xref]gift to Aaron and to his sons from among the children of Israel, to do the service of the children of Israel in the Tent of Meeting, and to make expiation for the children of Israel, that there may be no plague among the children of Israel, when the children of Israel come near to the sanctuary.

chapter.verse: Thus did Moses and Aaron and the whole assembly of the children of Israel do to the Levites; according to all that Jehovah had commanded Moses concerning the Levites, so did the children of Israel do to them.
And the Levites purified themselves from sin and washed their clothes. Then Aaron offered them as a wave offering before Jehovah, and Aaron made expiation for them to cleanse them.
And after this the Levites went in to do their service in the Tent of Meeting before Aaron and before his sons; as Jehovah had commanded Moses concerning the Levites, so they did to them.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: This is what [i]applies[/i] to the Levites: [xref]a[/xref]From [note]1[/note]twenty-five years old and upward they shall go in to perform the service in the work of the Tent of Meeting.
verse.note: According to [link]4:3[/link], a Levite had to be thirty years old to be qualified to carry out the service in the tabernacle. Based on this verse, at the age of twenty-five a Levite must have begun a five-year period of apprenticeship, in which he was trained to minister in the tabernacle. Every aspect of the service in the tabernacle had to be exact; no mistakes were tolerated. Therefore, those who served in and around the tabernacle had to be trained to do things accurately. After a Levite had completed his five-year apprenticeship, he was qualified, at the age of thirty, to serve in the tabernacle.

verse.text: And from the age of fifty years they shall [note]1[/note]retire from the service in the work and shall serve no more.
verse.note: The word in [link]vv. 25-26[/link] concerning the retiring of the Levites indicates that what they had gained in experience through the twenty-five years of their service was still needed after the age of fifty. Because God is serious about the laws governing the tabernacle, the offerings, and the Levitical work, there was the need of some experienced ones to instruct God's people, especially the young ones, so that they would not become careless and unconsciously offend God in their service. The same need exists regarding the service in the church.

chapter.verse: But they may minister to their brothers in the Tent of Meeting, to keep the charge, but they themselves shall do no service. Thus you shall do with the Levites concerning their charges.

verse.text: Now Jehovah had spoken to Moses in the wilderness of Sinai in the [note]1[/note]first month of the second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt, saying,
verse.note: [link]Chapters 1-8[/link] of this book were spoken by God to Moses on the first day of the second month in the second year after the exodus from Egypt ([link]1:1[/link]), whereas the words in [link]9:1-14[/link] were spoken in the first month of the same year ([link]v. 1[/link]). In the second month as Moses was recording all the divine speakings, God must have charged him to write something concerning the passover, of which God had spoken to Moses in the first month. Moses' recording of God's charge concerning the passover at this juncture indicates that after fulfilling the divine requirements and partaking of the divine provisions in the first eight chapters of this book, God's people should have a corporate feast to enjoy Christ before God and with God for their mutual satisfaction. This shows the importance of keeping the passover in relation to the move of God's redeemed people with God in His activity. Similarly, because the Lord's table has much to do with God's move on earth, the New Testament believers must keep the Lord's table ([link]1 Cor. 11:23-26[/link]).

verse.text: Let the children of Israel keep the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]passover at its appointed time.
verse.note: For the details of the passover, see notes in [link]Exo. 12:1-28[/link], [link]43-51[/link]. The passover in the Old Testament was a yearly reminder to the children of Israel, whereas the Lord's table, instituted by the Lord Jesus to replace the passover (see note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 26[/link]), is a weekly reminder to the believers in Christ. Both the passover and the Lord's table remind us that we were destined to die under God's righteous judgment, but God prepared Christ to be our replacement to die for us, thus saving us from the death-judgment of God's righteousness. Furthermore, they remind us that we do not belong to ourselves but to the One who replaced us and who is now our life and life supply. Since Christ is our life and life supply, we should live by Him ([link]John 6:57[/link]).

verse.text: On the [xref]a[/xref]fourteenth day of this month [note]1[/note]at twilight, you shall keep it at its appointed time; according to all its [note]2[/note]statutes and according to all its [note]2[/note]ordinances you shall keep it.
verse.note: Lit., between the two evenings. So also in [link]vv. 5[/link] and [link]11[/link].
See note [link]6[sup]4[/sup] in Luke 1[/link].

chapter.verse: Thus Moses told the children of Israel to keep the passover.

And they kept the passover in the first [i]month,[/i] on the fourteenth day of the month, at twilight, in the wilderness of Sinai; according to all that Jehovah commanded Moses, so the children of Israel did.

verse.text: But there were certain men who were unclean through [i]contact with[/i] a [xref]a[/xref]dead person, so that they could not keep the passover on that day; so they came before Moses and before Aaron on that day.

chapter.verse: And those men said to him, Although we are unclean through [i]contact with[/i] a dead person, why must we be kept from presenting the offering of Jehovah at its appointed time among the children of Israel?
And Moses said to them, Stay [i]here[/i] so I may hear what Jehovah will command concerning you.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

Speak to the children of Israel, saying, Any one of you or your descendants who becomes unclean through [i]contact with[/i] a dead person or is on a distant journey shall still keep the passover to Jehovah.

verse.text: In the [xref]a[/xref]second month on the fourteenth day at twilight they shall keep it; they shall eat it with [xref]b[/xref]unleavened bread and bitter herbs.
They shall not leave any of it until the [xref]a[/xref]morning, nor break a [xref]b[/xref]bone of it; according to every statute of the passover they shall keep it.

But the [note]1[/note]man who is clean and is not on a journey yet refrains from keeping the passover, that person shall be cut off from his people, because he did not present Jehovah's offering at its appointed time; that man shall bear his sin.
verse.note: That an Israelite who was clean was required to keep the passover signifies that the redeemed believers are required to partake of the Lord's table ([link]1 Cor. 11:23-26[/link]). A stranger being permitted to keep the passover with the sons of Israel ([link]v. 14[/link]) signifies that the believing Gentiles have been destined to partake of the Lord's table (cf. [link]Eph. 2:11-19[/link]).

verse.text: And if a [xref]a[/xref]stranger sojourns with you and keeps the passover to Jehovah; according to the statute of the passover and according to its ordinance, so shall he do. You shall have one statute, both for the sojourner and for the native [i]born[/i] in the land.

And on the day that the tabernacle was set up, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cloud covered the tabernacle, the Tent of the Testimony; and in the evening it was like the appearance of [note]1[/note]fire over the tabernacle until morning.
verse.note: In typology the cloud signifies the Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 10:1-2[/link] and notes [link]1[sup]4[/sup][/link] and [link]2[sup]3[/sup][/link]) and the fire, for enlightening, signifies the Word of God ([link]Psa. 119:105[/link]). The Spirit and the Word are one ([link]John 6:63[/link]; [link]Eph. 6:17[/link]). Cf. note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 13[/link].

verse.text: So it was always; the [xref]a[/xref]cloud covered it [i]by day,[/i] and the appearance of fire by night.

And whenever the [note]1[/note]cloud was [xref]a[/xref]taken up from over the tent, then after that the children of Israel set out; and in the place where the cloud settled, there the children of Israel encamped.
verse.note: After the children of Israel had been formed into an army, they were ready to journey to fight for God so that He could gain the ground on earth to build up His kingdom with His house. Their moving was not up to them; it was altogether according to God's guidance. The guidance for the children of Israel in their move was both from the heavens (the cloud — [link]vv. 15-23[/link]) and from the earth (the two trumpets — [link]10:1-10[/link]).
