The guidance in the form of a cloud signifies God in the sense of God's presence, i.e., God Himself consummated to be the Spirit. This indicates that the New Testament believers should always follow the indwelling Spirit ([link]Rom. 8:4[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:16[/link], [link]18[/link], [link]25[/link]).

chapter.verse: At the commandment of Jehovah the children of Israel set out, and at the commandment of Jehovah they encamped; as long as the cloud settled upon the tabernacle, they remained encamped.
Even when the cloud extended [i]its time[/i] over the tabernacle for many days, the children of Israel kept the charge of Jehovah and did not set out.
If sometimes the cloud was upon the tabernacle a few days, according to the commandment of Jehovah they remained encamped; then at the commandment of Jehovah they set out.

If sometimes the cloud remained from evening until morning, when the cloud was taken up in the morning, they set out; or [i]if it remained[/i] a day and a night, when the cloud was taken up, they set out.

Whether it was two days or a month or a longer time that the cloud extended [i]its time[/i] over the tabernacle and settled above it, the children of Israel remained encamped and did not set out; but when it was taken up, they set out.
At the commandment of Jehovah they encamped, and at the commandment of Jehovah they set out. They kept the charge of Jehovah according to the commandment of Jehovah through Moses.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Make yourself two trumpets of [note]1[/note]silver; of [xref]a[/xref]beaten work you shall make them; and you shall use them for summoning the assembly and for the setting out of the camps.
verse.note: In typology silver signifies Christ's redemption.

verse.text: And when they [xref]a[/xref]blow them, all the assembly shall gather themselves to you at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
But if they blow [i]only[/i] one, then the [xref]a[/xref]leaders, the heads of the thousands of Israel, shall gather themselves to you.
And when you blow an [note]1[/note]alarm, the camps that are encamped on the [xref]a[/xref]east side shall set out.
verse.note: Here the sound of the trumpet was called an alarm because, in God's thought, the children of Israel were continually at war. When they moved, they moved in a fighting way (cf. [link]Exo. 12:51[/link]; [link]13:18[/link]). This signifies that the Christian walk, the Christian move, is a fighting move ([link]Eph. 6:10-20[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:18[/link]; [link]6:12a[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:7a[/link]).

verse.text: And when you blow an alarm the second time, the camps that are encamped on the [xref]a[/xref]south side shall set out. They shall blow an [xref]b[/xref]alarm for them to set out.

chapter.verse: But when the congregation is to be gathered together, you shall blow, but you shall not sound an alarm.

verse.text: And the sons of Aaron, the priests, shall [xref]a[/xref]blow the trumpets; and this shall be for you a perpetual statute throughout your generations.

And when you go to war in your land against the adversary who oppresses you, then you shall sound an [xref]a[/xref]alarm with the trumpets, so that you may be remembered before Jehovah your God and be saved from your enemies.

Also on your days of rejoicing and at your [xref]a[/xref]appointed feasts and at the beginnings of your months, you shall [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]blow the trumpets over your burnt offerings and over the sacrifices of your peace offerings; and they shall be a reminder on your behalf before your God; I am Jehovah your God.
verse.note: To blow the trumpet over our burnt offerings and the sacrifice of our peace offerings here signifies to proclaim what Christ is to God and His people. The burnt offering signifies Christ as our acceptance by God and as our living for God; the peace offering signifies Christ as our peace and enjoyment with God (see notes [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 1[/link] and [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 3[/link]). Of the five basic offerings ([link]Lev. 1-7[/link]) these two were great enjoyments to God and His people. When in the church today God's children are absolute for God and dwell together with God in peace, there is a great day, a day worthy of the blowing of trumpets.

verse.text: Now it was in the second year, in the second month, on the twentieth day of the month, that the cloud was [xref]a[/xref]taken up from over the Tabernacle of the Testimony.
And the children of Israel set out on their journeys from the wilderness of [xref]a[/xref]Sinai. Then the cloud [note]1[/note]settled down in the wilderness of [xref]b[/xref]Paran.
verse.note: Lit., tabernacled.

chapter.verse: And they set out for the first time according to the commandment of Jehovah through Moses.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And the standard of the camp of the children of Judah set out [xref]b[/xref]first according to their companies; and over the entire company was Nahshon the son of Amminadab.

chapter.verse: And over the company of the tribe of the children of Issachar was Nethanel the son of Zuar.
And over the company of the tribe of the children of Zebulun was Eliab the son of Helon.

verse.text: And the tabernacle was [xref]a[/xref]taken down; and the sons of Gershon and the sons of Merari, who [xref]b[/xref]carried the tabernacle, set out.

chapter.verse: And the standard of the camp of Reuben set out according to their companies; and over the entire company was Elizur the son of Shedeur.
And over the company of the tribe of the children of Simeon was Shelumiel the son of Zurishaddai.
And over the company of the tribe of the children of Gad was Eliasaph the son of Deuel.

verse.text: And the Kohathites, who [xref]a[/xref]carried the holy things, set out; and the tabernacle was set up before their arrival.

chapter.verse: And the standard of the camp of the children of Ephraim set out according to their companies; and over the entire company was Elishama the son of Ammihud.
And over the company of the tribe of the children of Manasseh was Gamaliel the son of Pedahzur.
And over the company of the tribe of the children of Benjamin was Abidan the son of Gideoni.
And the standard of the camp of the children of Dan, which was the rear guard of all the camps, set out according to their companies; and over the entire company was Ahiezer the son of Ammishaddai.
And over the company of the tribe of the children of Asher was Pagiel the son of Ochran.
And over the company of the tribe of the children of Naphtali was Ahira the son of Enan.
This was the order in which the children of Israel set out according to their companies, when they set out.

verse.text: And Moses said to [xref]a[/xref]Hobab the son of [xref]b[/xref]Reuel the Midianite, Moses' father-in-law, We are setting out to the place concerning which Jehovah said, I will [xref]c[/xref]give it to you. Come with us, and we will treat you well, for Jehovah has [xref]d[/xref]promised good to Israel.

chapter.verse: But he said to him, I will not go; but rather I will go to my own land and to my relatives.

verse.text: So [note]1[/note]Moses said, Please do not leave us, for you know where we can encamp in the wilderness, and you will be [note]2[/note]eyes for us.
verse.note: Lit., he.

Moses thought that his father-in-law would be a great help, but God's sovereignty would not allow any man to come in. Thus, Moses and the children of Israel had to put their trust in the Lord. This account of Moses' trusting in man is inserted here to compare man's leading with the leading of the Ark in the subsequent verses.

chapter.verse: And if you go with us, whatever good Jehovah does for us, we will do for you.

verse.text: So they set out from the [xref]a[/xref]mountain of Jehovah three days' journey, with the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Ark of the Covenant of Jehovah setting out before them three days' journey, to seek out a [xref]c[/xref]resting place for them.
verse.note: God's guidance to His people in a general way was by the cloud and the trumpets ([link]9:15-10:10[/link]), whereas His leading of His people in a particular way was through the Ark ([link]vv. 33-36[/link]), a type of the crucified and resurrected Christ in His resurrection. Hence, the unique Leader of God's people is not any man (cf. [link]vv. 29-32[/link]) but is the crucified and resurrected Christ ([link]Matt. 23:10[/link]). He is the Leader, and He leads us to the proper place of rest on the long and rugged journey of the Christian life ([link]Heb. 4:8-9[/link] and notes).[br][br]The leading of the Ark of the Covenant indicates that the leading of Christ is faithful, according to a covenant. God made a covenant with Abraham and his descendants to bring them into the good land ([link]Gen. 17:1-8[/link]; cf. note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 23[/link]). Eventually, God's covenant was placed in the Ark; thus, the Ark was called the Ark of the Covenant. Hence, the Christ who leads us into a resting place is the Christ of the covenant, the Christ of God's faithfulness (cf. [link]2 Cor. 1:19-20[/link]).

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]cloud of Jehovah was over them by day when they set out from the camp.
And when the Ark set out, Moses said,[br/][note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Rise up, O Jehovah, and let Your enemies be scattered; / And let those who hate You flee before You.
verse.note: [link]Numbers 10:35[/link] is quoted in [link]Psa. 68:1[/link]. In [link]Eph. 4:8-10[/link] Paul applied the word in [link]Psa. 68[/link] to the ascension of Christ. Hence, the rising up in this verse refers to Christ's rising up to the heavens in His ascension. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 68[/link].

verse.text: And when it came to rest, he said,[br/][note]1[/note]Return, O [note]2[/note]Jehovah, to the ten thousand thousands of Israel.
verse.note: Since the rising up in [link]v. 35[/link] refers to Christ's rising up to the heavens in His ascension (see note [link]35[sup]1[/sup][/link]), the word [i]return[/i] spoken by Moses in this verse must refer to the second coming of Christ. Moses' word in [link]vv. 35-36[/link] portrays a full view of God's economy from Christ's incarnation to be the Ark, the embodiment of the Triune God, through His ascension to His second coming.
Or, Jehovah of the ten thousands, to the thousands of Israel.

verse.text: And the people became like those who [xref]a[/xref]murmur about [i]their[/i] misfortune in the ears of Jehovah; and when Jehovah heard [i]it,[/i] His [xref]b[/xref]anger was kindled, and the [xref]c[/xref]fire of Jehovah burned among them and consumed [i]some[/i] at the outskirts of the camp.

chapter.verse: And the people cried to Moses; and Moses prayed to Jehovah, and the fire abated.

verse.text: And the name of that place was called [note]1[/note]Taberah because the fire of Jehovah had burned among them.
verse.note: Meaning [i]burning.[/i]

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]mixed multitude that was among them [xref]b[/xref]lusted exceedingly; and the children of Israel also wept again and said, Who shall give us meat to eat?
verse.note: The mixed multitude (cf. [link]Exo. 12:38[/link]) consisted of those who did not know of whom they were born or to what family they belonged. The lusting of the mixed multitude stirred up the lust of the children of Israel (cf. [link]1 Cor. 5:6[/link]).

verse.text: We remember the [note]1[/note]fish which we used to eat in [xref]a[/xref]Egypt for nothing, the cucumbers and the melons and the leeks and the onions and the garlic;
verse.note: The foods in Egypt signify the fleshly enjoyment of the world. See notes [link book="Exo." chapter="16"]3[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]13[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 16[/link].

verse.text: But now our appetite has gone; there is nothing at all but [note]1[/note]this [xref]a[/xref]manna to look at.
verse.note: Manna signifies the heavenly Christ as the daily food for God's people ([link]John 6:29-35[/link]). See notes [link book="Exo." chapter="16"]4[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 16[/link]. The people of Israel abhorred the heavenly taste of manna and lusted for the worldly taste of the Egyptian food.

verse.text: Now the manna was like [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]coriander seed, and its appearance like the appearance of bdellium.
verse.note: For the characteristics of manna, see notes [link book="Exo." chapter="16"]13[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 16[/link].

verse.text: The people went about and [xref]a[/xref]gathered [i]it[/i] and ground [i]it[/i] between two millstones or beat [i]it[/i] in a mortar; then they boiled [i]it[/i] in pots and made cakes of it; and its [xref]b[/xref]taste was like the taste of cakes [i]baked[/i] in oil.
And when the [xref]a[/xref]dew fell on the camp at night, the manna would fall with it.

chapter.verse: And Moses heard the people weeping throughout their families, each at the entrance of his tent; and the anger of Jehovah was kindled greatly, and Moses was displeased.
And Moses said to Jehovah, Why have You treated Your servant badly, and why have I not found favor in Your sight, that You have put the burden of all this people upon me?

verse.text: Did I conceive all this people? Or did I [xref]a[/xref]bring them forth, so that You should say to me, Carry them in your [xref]b[/xref]bosom, as a [xref]c[/xref]nurse carries the nursing child, to the [xref]d[/xref]land which You swore [i]to give[/i] to their fathers?

chapter.verse: From where should I get meat to give to all this people? For they weep before me, saying, Give us meat, so that we may eat!

verse.text: I am not able to bear all this people [xref]a[/xref]alone, for it is too heavy for me.
And if this is the way You deal with me, [xref]a[/xref]please kill me at once — if I have found favor in Your sight — and do not let me see my wretchedness.

So Jehovah said to Moses, Gather to Me [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]seventy, each one from the elders of Israel, whom you know are the elders of the people and their officers, and bring them to the Tent of Meeting, and have them stand there with you.
verse.note: Seventy, composed of seven times ten, is the number of completion (seven — see note [link]29[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 2[/link]) and fullness (ten — see note [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 2[/link]). God's raising up of seventy elders indicates that when He does something, He does it completely and in full.

verse.text: Then I will come down and talk with you there, and I will take of the [xref]a[/xref]Spirit who is upon you and will put [i]Him[/i] upon them; and they shall bear the [xref]b[/xref]burden of the people with you, so that you do not bear [i]it[/i] alone.

chapter.verse: And you shall say to the people, Sanctify yourselves for tomorrow, and you shall eat meat; for you have wept in the ears of Jehovah, saying, Who will give us meat to eat? For it was well with us in Egypt. Therefore Jehovah will give you meat, and you shall eat.

verse.text: You shall [xref]a[/xref]eat not one day, nor two days, nor five days, nor ten days, nor twenty days,

chapter.verse: But a whole month, until it comes out from your nostrils and becomes loathsome to you, because you have rejected Jehovah who is among you and have wept before Him, saying, Why did we ever come out of Egypt?

verse.text: But Moses said, The people, among whom I am, are [xref]a[/xref]six hundred thousand on foot; and You have said, I will give them meat so that they may eat a whole month.

chapter.verse: Will flocks and herds be slain for them, to satisfy them? Or will all the fish of the sea be gathered together for them, to satisfy them?

verse.text: And Jehovah said to Moses, Has Jehovah's hand become [xref]a[/xref]short? Now you will see whether My word will come to pass for you or not.
So Moses went out and told the people the words of Jehovah, and he gathered [xref]a[/xref]seventy, each one from the elders of the people, and set them around the tent.

And Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]came down in the cloud and spoke to him, and He took of the Spirit who was upon him, and put [i]Him[/i] upon the seventy elders. And when the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit rested upon them, they [note]1[/note]prophesied, but they did not do [i]so[/i] again.
verse.note: See note [link]29[sup]1[/sup][/link].

chapter.verse: But two men had remained in the camp, the name of the one was Eldad, and the name of the other Medad. And the Spirit rested upon them. (Now they were among those who were registered, but they had not gone out to the tent.) And they prophesied in the camp.
And a certain young man ran and told Moses and said, Eldad and Medad are prophesying in the camp.

verse.text: And Joshua the son of Nun, the attendant of Moses, one of his chosen men, answered and said, My lord Moses, [xref]a[/xref]restrain them!
But Moses said to him, Are you jealous for my sake? [xref]a[/xref]Oh that [note]1[/note]all Jehovah's people were prophets, that Jehovah would put His Spirit upon them!
verse.note: Moses desired that all the people of Israel would be prophets, those who spoke for God (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 7[/link]). This word was a great prophecy uttered by Moses. It was promoted by Paul in [link]1 Cor. 14[/link] and is fulfilled in God's New Testament economy by the prophesying of the believers in the church meetings ([link]1 Cor. 14:24[/link], [link]31[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Moses returned to the camp, he and the elders of Israel.

verse.text: And a wind went forth from Jehovah and brought [xref]a[/xref]quails from the sea and let [i]them[/i] fall beside the camp, about a day's journey on this side and a day's journey on the other side, all around the camp, and about two cubits above the surface of the earth.

chapter.verse: And the people rose up all that day and all the night and all the next day, and they gathered the quail. He who gathered least gathered ten homers. And they spread [i]them[/i] out for themselves all around the camp.

verse.text: While the meat was still between their [xref]a[/xref]teeth, before it was chewed, the [xref]b[/xref]anger of Jehovah was kindled against the people, and Jehovah struck the people with a very severe plague.
And the name of that place was called [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Kibroth-hattaavah because there they buried the people who [xref]b[/xref]lusted.
verse.note: Meaning [i]graves of lust.[/i] God's dealing with those who lusted was for the purpose of clearing up the mixed multitude, thus purifying His people.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]From Kibroth-hattaavah the people journeyed to Hazeroth, and they remained at Hazeroth.
And [xref]a[/xref]Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses because of the Cushite woman whom he had [xref]b[/xref]married (for he had married a Cushite woman).
And they said, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Has Jehovah indeed spoken only through Moses? Has He not also [xref]b[/xref]spoken through us? And Jehovah heard [i]it.[/i]
verse.note: Miriam and Aaron were Moses' blood relatives and were both prophets ([link]Exo. 4:10-16[/link]; [link]6:30-7:1[/link]; [link]15:20[/link]). Their word here indicates that, being older than Moses, they regarded themselves higher than Moses and were jealous of the greater respect that Moses received. Miriam and Aaron took Moses' apparent mistake in marrying a Cushite woman as an excuse to slander him ([link]v. 1[/link]); however, the real issue here concerned the question of who had God's oracle. Although Miriam and Aaron were used by God to speak for Him, neither was God's spokesman; only one, Moses, had the oracle of God. Being jealous of Moses, Miriam and Aaron were in rivalry with Moses in the matter of speaking for God.[br][br]In speaking against Moses, Miriam and Aaron were speaking against the deputy authority of God. God had appointed Moses to be His deputy authority, His representative authority on earth ([link]Exo. 3:10-18a[/link]; [link]7:1[/link]). According to God's governmental administration, Miriam and Aaron should have submitted themselves to Moses. But they rebelled.

verse.text: Now the man Moses was very [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]meek, more than anyone else who was on the face of the earth.
verse.note: Or, humble.

chapter.verse: And suddenly Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron and to Miriam, You three come out to the Tent of Meeting. So the three of them came out.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Then Jehovah [note]1[/note]came down in a pillar of cloud and stood at the entrance of the tent, and called Aaron and Miriam. And when they had both come forward,
verse.note: God took the slander of Miriam and Aaron seriously because this matter challenged God's authority, thus assailing God's throne.

verse.text: He said, Hear now My words:[br/]If there is a [note]1[/note]prophet among you, / I, Jehovah, will make Myself known to him in a [xref]a[/xref]vision; / I will speak with him in a [xref]b[/xref]dream.
verse.note: Or, prophet of Jehovah among you, I will make Myself known...

verse.text: My servant Moses is not so; / [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]He is faithful in all My house.
verse.note: Or, He is entrusted with all My house.

verse.text: With him I speak [xref]a[/xref]face to face, even openly, and not in riddles; / And he beholds the [xref]b[/xref]form of Jehovah.[br/]Why then were you not afraid to speak against My servant, against Moses?

chapter.verse: And the anger of Jehovah was kindled against them, and He departed.

verse.text: And when the cloud had departed from over the tent; there [xref]a[/xref]Miriam was, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]leprous, as [i]white as[/i] snow. And Aaron turned toward Miriam, and there [i]she was,[/i] leprous.
verse.note: Miriam's becoming leprous was God's governmental dealing. God punished Miriam but not Aaron because it is likely that Miriam took the lead and was the instigator in this rebellion. Moreover, because rebellion is particularly unseemly for a female, God punished Miriam to warn and alarm all the females among the children of Israel, so that they would not follow Miriam (cf. [link]1 Cor. 11:3[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:22-24[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Aaron said to Moses, Oh, my lord, please do not lay this sin upon us that we have so foolishly committed.
Please do not let her be like one dead, whose flesh is half consumed when he comes out of his mother's womb.

verse.text: And Moses cried to Jehovah, saying, [note]1[/note]Please heal her, O God, please.
verse.note: Moses' praying for Miriam is a further indication of Moses' meekness ([link]v. 3[/link]). See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link].

verse.text: And Jehovah said to Moses, If her father had just spat in her face, would she not bear her shame seven days? Let her be shut up [xref]a[/xref]outside the camp seven days, and after that she may be brought in again.

chapter.verse: So Miriam was shut up outside the camp seven days, and the people did not set out until Miriam had been brought in again.

verse.text: After that the people set out from [xref]a[/xref]Hazeroth and encamped in the wilderness of Paran.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Send men to [xref]a[/xref]spy out the [note]2[/note]land of Canaan, which I am giving to the children of Israel; one man from each of their fathers' tribes you shall send, every one a leader among them.
verse.note: God had brought the children of Israel to the border of the good land, and they could have easily crossed the border and entered into the land. But God knew their heart, and He purposely gave the word to send out the twelve spies to spy out the land ([link]vv. 1-2[/link]) in order to test them ([link]Deut. 8:2[/link]). This test exposed them to the uttermost. The entire history of the children of Israel, including the failures recorded in [link]chs. 11-14[/link], was written for the admonition of the New Testament believers ([link]1 Cor. 10:1-13[/link]).
See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link].

chapter.verse: So Moses sent them from the wilderness of Paran according to the commandment of Jehovah, all of them leading men among the children of Israel.
And these were their names: from the tribe of Reuben, Shammua the son of Zaccur;
From the tribe of Simeon, Shaphat the son of Hori;

verse.text: From the tribe of Judah, [xref]a[/xref]Caleb the son of Jephunneh;

chapter.verse: From the tribe of Issachar, Igal the son of Joseph;

verse.text: From the tribe of Ephraim, [xref]a[/xref]Hoshea the son of Nun;

chapter.verse: From the tribe of Benjamin, Palti the son of Raphu;
From the tribe of Zebulun, Gaddiel the son of Sodi;
From the tribe of Joseph, [i]that is,[/i] from the tribe of Manasseh, Gaddi the son of Susi;
From the tribe of Dan, Ammiel the son of Gemalli;
From the tribe of Asher, Sethur the son of Michael;
From the tribe of Naphtali, Nahbi the son of Vophsi;
From the tribe of Gad, Geuel the son of Machi.

verse.text: These are the names of the men whom Moses sent to spy out the land. And Moses called [note]1[/note]Hoshea the son of Nun [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Joshua.
verse.note: Meaning [i]he saved,[/i] or [i]salvation.[/i]
Meaning [i]Jehovah Savior,[/i] or [i]the salvation of Jehovah.[/i] The Greek form of the name is [i]Jesus[/i] (see note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link]).

chapter.verse: And when Moses sent them to spy out the land of Canaan, he said to them, Go up this way into the Negev, and go up into the hill country;
And see what the land is like; and whether the people who live in it are strong or weak, whether they are few or many;
And whether the land in which they dwell is good or bad; and whether the cities that they live in are like camps or with fortifications;
And whether the land is fat or lean; whether there are trees in it or not. Therefore strengthen yourselves and bring some of the fruit of the land. Now the time was the time of the first ripe grapes.

verse.text: So they went up and spied out the land from the wilderness of Zin to Rehob, near the [note]1[/note]entrance of Hamath.
verse.note: Or, Lebo-hamath.

verse.text: And when they had gone up through the Negev, they came to Hebron; and Ahiman, Sheshai, and Talmai, the descendants of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Anak, were there. (Now [xref]b[/xref]Hebron was built seven years before [xref]c[/xref]Zoan in Egypt.)
verse.note: See [link]v. 33[/link] and note.

verse.text: Then they came to the [xref]a[/xref]Valley of Eshcol, and from there they cut down a branch with a single cluster of grapes; and they carried it on a pole between two [i]of them. They[/i] also [i]cut off[/i] some of the pomegranates and some of the figs.
That place was called the Valley of [note]1[/note]Eshcol, because of the cluster which the children of Israel cut down from there.
verse.note: Meaning [i]cluster.[/i]

chapter.verse: And they returned from spying out the land at the end of forty days.

And they proceeded to come to Moses and to Aaron and to the whole assembly of the children of Israel, to the wilderness of Paran, to Kadesh; and they brought back word to them and to the whole assembly, and showed them the fruit of the land.

verse.text: And they told him and said, We came to the land into which you sent us; and it indeed flows with [xref]a[/xref]milk and honey, and this is its [xref]b[/xref]fruit.
However, the [xref]a[/xref]people who dwell in the land are strong, and the cities are fortified [i]and[/i] very large; and we also saw the descendants of Anak there.

chapter.verse: The Amalekites dwell in the land of the Negev, and the Hittites and the Jebusites and the Amorites dwell in the hill country, and the Canaanites dwell by the sea and along the Jordan.

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]Caleb quieted the people before Moses and said, Let us go up at once and possess it; for we are well able to overcome it.
But the men who went up with him said, We are [xref]a[/xref]not able to go up against the people, for they are stronger than we.

And they brought to the children of Israel an [xref]a[/xref]evil report of the land which they had spied out, saying, The land, through which we have gone to spy it out, is a land that eats up its inhabitants; and all the people that we saw in it are men of [xref]b[/xref][i]great[/i] size.
And there we saw the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Nephilim (the descendants of Anak are part of the Nephilim); and we were like grasshoppers in our own sight, and so we were in their sight.
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 6[/link]. Because the Nephilim, a mixture of fallen angels and fallen man, dwelt in the land of Canaan, God commanded the children of Israel to take over this land and to destroy every living being there so that the human race could be cleared up ([link]Deut. 7:1-2[/link]).

chapter.verse: Then the whole assembly lifted up their voice and cried, and the people wept that night.

verse.text: And all the children of Israel [xref]a[/xref]murmured against Moses and against Aaron; and the whole assembly said to them, If only we had died in the land of Egypt! Or if only we had died in this wilderness!
And why does Jehovah bring us into this land to fall by the sword? Our wives and our little ones will become plunder. Would it not be better for us to [xref]a[/xref]return to Egypt?
And they said one to another, Let us appoint a [xref]a[/xref]captain, and let us return to Egypt.
Then Moses and Aaron [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fell on their faces before the whole congregation of the assembly of the children of Israel.
verse.note: This shows their meekness.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Joshua the son of Nun and [xref]b[/xref]Caleb the son of Jephunneh, who were among those who spied out the land, [xref]c[/xref]tore their clothes.
And they spoke to the whole assembly of the children of Israel, saying, The land through which we passed to spy out is an exceedingly [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]good land.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link].

verse.text: If Jehovah is pleased with us, He will bring us into this land and give it to us, a land which flows with [xref]a[/xref]milk and honey.

Only [note]1[/note]do not rebel against Jehovah, nor should you fear the people of the land, for they are our [xref]a[/xref]bread. Their protection has been removed from them, and Jehovah is [xref]b[/xref]with us; do not fear them.
verse.note: The words [i]do not rebel against Jehovah[/i] indicate that not to believe in the Lord is to rebel against Him (cf. [link]Deut. 1:26[/link], [link]32[/link]).

verse.text: But the whole assembly said to [xref]a[/xref]stone them with stones. Then the [xref]b[/xref]glory of Jehovah appeared in the Tent of Meeting to all the children of Israel.
And Jehovah said to Moses, [note]1[/note]How long will this people despise Me? And how long will they [xref]a[/xref]not believe in Me, in spite of all the signs that I have done among them?
verse.note: As indicated by the evil report of the ten spies ([link]13:31-33[/link]) and the murmuring of the people against Moses and Aaron ([link]14:1-4[/link]), the children of Israel did not care for God but cared only for themselves. In everything and in every way they were for themselves, not for God's interests. Because of this, they did not believe in God, and they offended God to such an extent that they became abhorrent to Him. Their situation brought in God's judgment and punishment. God alone is the source of faith. If we would have faith, we must learn to care for God's interests and not for our benefit.

verse.text: I will strike them with pestilence and dispossess them, and I will make you into a [xref]a[/xref]nation greater and mightier than they.
But Moses said to Jehovah, [note]1[/note]Then the Egyptians will hear of it, for by Your [xref]a[/xref]might You brought this people up from their midst,
verse.note: Moses prayed for the people not according to his concept but according to God's word ([link]vv. 17-18[/link]). His prayer bound God according to what He had spoken and what He is.

verse.text: And they will tell the inhabitants of this land. They have heard that You, Jehovah, are in the midst of this people; for You, O Jehovah, are seen in plain sight, and Your cloud stands over them, and You go before them in a [xref]a[/xref]pillar of cloud by day and in a pillar of fire by night.

chapter.verse: Now if You put this people to death as one man, then the nations that have heard the report about You will speak, saying,

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Because Jehovah was not able to bring this people into the land which He swore [i]to give[/i] them, He has therefore slaughtered them in the wilderness.

chapter.verse: And now, I pray, let the power of the Lord be great, just as You have spoken, saying,

verse.text: Jehovah is [xref]a[/xref]slow to anger and abundant in lovingkindness, forgiving iniquity and transgression; but He will by no means clear [i]the guilty,[/i] visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children to the third and the fourth [i]generations.[/i]
[xref]a[/xref]Pardon, I pray, the iniquity of this people according to the greatness of Your lovingkindness, just as You have forgiven this people from Egypt even until now.
Then Jehovah said, I have [note]1[/note]pardoned [i]them[/i] according to your word;
verse.note: God pardoned the people according to Moses' prayer; nevertheless, their unbelief had certain negative consequences ([link]vv. 21-38[/link]). Cf. [link]Heb. 3:7-19[/link]. God forgave the sinning Israelites yet still punished them. This shows that God's forgiveness is of different kinds. One kind is forgiveness through punishment. Cf. notes [link]32[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 12[/link] and [link]34[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 18[/link].

verse.text: But as surely as I live, and as all the earth will be [xref]a[/xref]filled with the glory of Jehovah,

chapter.verse: None of those men who have seen My glory and My signs, which I did in Egypt and in the wilderness, yet have tried Me these ten times and have not listened to My voice,

verse.text: Shall see the land which I [xref]a[/xref]swore [i]to give[/i] to their fathers, nor shall any of those who despised Me see it.

Only My servant [xref]a[/xref]Caleb, because he had a different spirit and has [xref]b[/xref]fully followed Me, will I bring into the land which he entered; and his descendants shall take possession of it.

chapter.verse: Now since the Amalekites and the Canaanites dwell in the valleys, turn tomorrow, and set out into the wilderness by the way [i]that leads[/i] to the Red Sea.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,

verse.text: How long [i]shall I bear[/i] with this evil assembly, which [xref]a[/xref]murmurs against Me? I have heard the murmurings of the children of Israel, which they are making against Me.

chapter.verse: Say to them, As I live, declares Jehovah, just as you have spoken in My ears, so will I do to you.

verse.text: Your corpses shall [xref]a[/xref]fall in this wilderness, and none of you who were numbered, according to the number you counted from [xref]b[/xref]twenty years old and upward, who have murmured against Me,
Shall come into the land, in which I [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]swore to settle you, except [xref]b[/xref]Caleb the son of Jephunneh and Joshua the son of Nun.
verse.note: Lit., lifted up My hand.

verse.text: But your [xref]a[/xref]little ones, whom you said would become plunder, I will bring in, and they will know the land which you have rejected.
But as for you, your corpses shall [xref]a[/xref]fall in this wilderness.
And your children shall wander in the wilderness [xref]a[/xref]forty years, and they shall suffer for your [note]1[/note]unfaithfulness until your corpses have been consumed in the wilderness.
verse.note: Lit., fornications.

verse.text: According to the number of the days which you spied out the land, [xref]a[/xref]forty days, a year for every day, you shall bear your iniquities, forty years; and you shall know My [note]1[/note]displeasure.
verse.note: Or, opposition.

verse.text: I, Jehovah, have spoken; surely I will do this to all this evil assembly who are gathered together against Me. In this wilderness they shall be [xref]a[/xref]consumed, and there they shall die.
And the men whom Moses sent to spy out the land, who returned and made the whole assembly to murmur against him by bringing up an [xref]a[/xref]evil report against the land,

chapter.verse: That is, those men who brought up an evil report of the land, died by the plague before Jehovah.

verse.text: Only [xref]a[/xref]Joshua the son of Nun and [xref]b[/xref]Caleb the son of Jephunneh remained alive out of those men who went to spy out the land.

chapter.verse: And when Moses spoke these words to all the children of Israel, the people mourned greatly.

verse.text: And they rose up early in the morning to go up to the top of the mountain, saying, Here we are; now [xref]a[/xref]we will go up to the place which Jehovah has spoken of, for we have sinned.
But Moses said, Why do you [note]1[/note]again transgress the commandment of Jehovah? This will not succeed.
verse.note: The children of Israel were not only a rebellious people but also a stubborn people ([link]Exo. 32:9[/link]; [link]33:3[/link]; [link]Deut. 10:16[/link]; [link]Isa. 48:4[/link]). Their disobeying God here was caused by their unbelief ([link]Deut. 1:32[/link]; [link]Heb. 3:18-19[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Do not go up — for Jehovah is not among you — so that you are not struck down before your enemies.
For the Amalekites and the Canaanites are there before you, and you shall fall by the sword. Because you have [note]1[/note]turned back from following Jehovah, therefore Jehovah will not be with you.
verse.note: Before this time the children of Israel had followed the Ark, a type of the Triune God in His incarnation embodied in Christ, but from this point they gave God up and would not follow Him any longer.

verse.text: But they [xref]a[/xref]presumed to go up to the top of the mountain, even though neither the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Ark of the Covenant of Jehovah nor Moses had departed out of the midst of the camp.
verse.note: The people were to move only when the Ark moved ([link]10:33[/link]); but when God asked them to move, they did not. Now they presumed to move by themselves.

verse.text: Then the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Amalekites and the [note]1[/note]Canaanites who dwelt in that hill country came down and struck them and beat them back as far as Hormah.
verse.note: In biblical typology, the Amalekites signify the flesh, the fallen, fleshly people (see [link]Exo. 17:8[/link] and notes). The Canaanites signify human beings who have joined themselves to the evil spirits, to the satanic power of darkness in the air.

verse.text: Then Jehovah [note]1[/note]spoke to Moses, saying,
verse.note: After the failures in [link]chs. 11-14[/link], this chapter was inserted in the divine record perhaps to remind the children of Israel concerning the way to be kept in a proper relationship with God. If the children of Israel had kept the ordinances in this chapter, they would have been rescued from further turmoil (cf. [link]ch. 16[/link]).

chapter.verse: Speak to the children of Israel and say to them, When you come into the land that you are to inhabit, which I am giving you,

verse.text: And you make an offering by fire to Jehovah, a [xref]a[/xref]burnt [note]1[/note]offering or a sacrifice, to [note]2[/note]make a [xref]b[/xref]special vow or as a freewill offering or at your appointed feasts, to make a [xref]c[/xref]satisfying fragrance to Jehovah, from the herd or from the flock,
verse.note: All the offerings are types of Christ in various aspects. To present an offering to God indicates that we realize that we cannot do anything to please God; hence, we offer Christ to God as our replacement that we may be accepted by God. For the detailed significance of the offerings, see notes in [link]Lev. 1-7[/link] and [link]Lev. 23:13[/link].
Lit, be wonderful to make a vow. So also in [link]v. 8[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]The one who presents his offering shall present to Jehovah a [xref]b[/xref]meal offering of a tenth [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour mingled with a fourth of a hin of oil.
And you shall prepare wine for the [xref]a[/xref]drink offering, a fourth of a hin, with the burnt offering or for the sacrifice, for each lamb.

chapter.verse: Or for a ram you shall prepare as a meal offering two-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour mingled with a third of a hin of oil;
And for the drink offering you shall present a third of a hin of wine, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.

verse.text: And when you prepare a herd animal for a burnt offering or for a sacrifice, to make a special vow or for [xref]a[/xref]peace offerings to Jehovah,

chapter.verse: Then you shall offer with the herd animal a meal offering of three-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour mingled with half a hin of oil;
And you shall present for the drink offering half a hin of wine, an offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.
Thus shall it be done for each ox or for each ram or for each of the male lambs or goats.
According to the number that you prepare, so you shall do for every one according to their number.
All who are native shall do these things in this way, in presenting an offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.

And if a stranger sojourns with you, or one who may be among you throughout your generations, and he wants to make an offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah; just as you do, so he shall do.

verse.text: For the congregation there shall be [note]1[/note]one statute for you and for the [xref]a[/xref]stranger who sojourns [i]with you,[/i] a perpetual statute throughout your generations; as you are, so shall the sojourner be before Jehovah.
verse.note: The same statute and ordinance were for all the people of Israel and the sojourning strangers and the heathen among the people of Israel ([link]vv. 13-16[/link]). This signifies that all the heathens and strangers share Christ in the same way as the people of Israel ([link]Eph. 2:12-19[/link]; [link]3:6[/link]).

chapter.verse: One law and one ordinance shall be for you and for the stranger who sojourns with you.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to the children of Israel and say to them, When you come into the land into which I am bringing you,

verse.text: Whenever you eat of the [xref]a[/xref]bread of the land, you shall offer up a [xref]b[/xref]heave offering to Jehovah.
From the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]first of your dough you shall offer up a cake for a heave offering; as the heave offering of the threshing floor, so shall you offer it up.
verse.note: A cake of the first of the dough signifies Christ as the firstfruits ([link]1 Cor. 15:20[/link], [link]23[/link]). Such a Christ is offered in His ascension (the heave offering) to God as God's food. The cake in this verse not only refers to Christ Himself but also indicates Christ's Body, the church ([link]1 Cor. 10:17[/link]).

chapter.verse: From the first of your dough you shall give to Jehovah a heave offering throughout your generations.

verse.text: And if [note]1[/note]you [xref]a[/xref]sin unintentionally and do not observe all these commandments which Jehovah has spoken to Moses,
verse.note: Plural in Hebrew. The unintentional sin of the whole assembly of Israel signifies the unintentional sin of the church against God and man. Although such a sin was unintentional, a burnt offering, with its meal offering and its drink offering, and a sin offering were to be offered so that the whole assembly could be forgiven ([link]vv. 24-26[/link]).

chapter.verse: [i]That is,[/i] everything that Jehovah has commanded you through Moses, from the day that Jehovah gave commandment and onward throughout your generations,

verse.text: Then, if it was done unintentionally, without the knowledge of the assembly, the whole assembly shall offer one bull of the herd for a burnt offering, for a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah, with its meal offering and its drink offering, according to the ordinance, and one male goat for a [xref]a[/xref]sin offering.

And the priest shall make [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]expiation for the whole assembly of the children of Israel, and they shall be forgiven; for it was unintentional, and they have brought their offering, an offering by fire to Jehovah, and their sin offering before Jehovah for their error.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 16[/link]. God's forgiveness is based on the redemption of Christ accomplished for propitiation, without which God has no ground to forgive man ([link]Heb. 9:22[/link]) even though He has a heart to do so. Christ's propitiation affords God the way to fulfill the desire of His forgiving heart. If man takes Christ's redemptive death as his standing and asks God to forgive him, God must do it based on His righteousness, not on His mercy ([link]1 John 1:9[/link]). This is according to God's governmental administration.

chapter.verse: And the whole assembly of the children of Israel shall be forgiven, and the stranger who sojourns among them; for all the people [i]were involved[/i] unintentionally.

verse.text: And if one person [xref]a[/xref]sins unintentionally, then he shall present a female goat a year old for a sin offering.

chapter.verse: And the priest shall make expiation before Jehovah for the person who sinned unintentionally, when he sins unintentionally, to make expiation for him; and he shall be forgiven.

verse.text: You shall have one law for the one who does anything unintentionally, for one who is a native among the children of Israel and for the [xref]a[/xref]stranger who sojourns among them.
But the person who does anything with a [note]1[/note]high hand, whether a native or a sojourner, that one reviles Jehovah; and that person shall be cut off from among his people.
verse.note: To do things with a high hand is to do as one wishes without caring for others. Those who behave in this way utterly disregard both man and God.

chapter.verse: Because he has despised the word of Jehovah and has broken His commandment, that person shall be completely cut off; his iniquity shall be upon him.

verse.text: Now while the children of Israel were in the wilderness, they found a man gathering sticks on the [xref]a[/xref]Sabbath day.

chapter.verse: And those who found him gathering sticks brought him to Moses and Aaron and to the whole assembly.
And they put him in custody, because it had not been declared what should be done to him.

verse.text: And Jehovah said to Moses, The man shall surely be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]put to death; the whole assembly shall [xref]b[/xref]stone him with stones outside the camp.
verse.note: Breaking the Sabbath signifies denying God and all that He has done for us (see notes [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 2[/link] and [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 20[/link]). This results in spiritual death.

chapter.verse: So the whole assembly brought him outside the camp and stoned him to death with stones, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel and tell them to make for themselves [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fringes on the borders of their garments throughout their generations and to put on the fringe of each border a [note]2[/note]cord of blue.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link].

A cord signifies binding, and blue signifies heavenly. Hence, a cord of blue signifies that, as children of God, our conduct and behavior should be beautiful and should be under the binding of the heavenly government.

chapter.verse: And it shall be a fringe for you, so that when you see it you will remember all the commandments of Jehovah and do them, so that you do not seek after your own heart and your own eyes, according to which you committed fornication;
That you shall remember and do all My commandments and be holy to your God.

verse.text: I am [xref]a[/xref]Jehovah your God who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God; I am Jehovah your God.
Now [xref]a[/xref]Korah the son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, with [xref]b[/xref]Dathan and Abiram the sons of Eliab, and On the son of Peleth, the sons of Reuben, took [i]men[/i]
And rose up before Moses, with certain of the children of Israel, [note]1[/note]two hundred fifty leaders of the assembly, who were summoned to the meeting, well-known men.
verse.note: The rebellion in this chapter was a widespread, universal rebellion among God's people ([link]v. 19a[/link]).

verse.text: And they assembled themselves together against Moses and against Aaron, and said to them, You take too much upon yourselves, for all the assembly are [xref]a[/xref]holy, every one of them, and Jehovah is [xref]b[/xref]among them. Why then do you [note]1[/note]exalt yourselves above the congregation of Jehovah?
verse.note: This word and Moses' word in [link]vv. 9-10[/link] show that the root of this rebellion was ambition, the struggle for power and for a higher position. Ambition undermines God's plan and damages His people. Throughout the centuries many problems among Christians have been caused by ambition (cf. [link]Matt. 20:20-28[/link]; [link]3 John 9-11[/link]).

verse.text: And when Moses heard [i]this,[/i] he [xref]a[/xref]fell on his face.

And he spoke to Korah and to all his company, saying, [note]1[/note]In the morning Jehovah will make known [xref]a[/xref]who is His and who is holy, and will bring him near to Himself; even the one whom He will [xref]b[/xref]choose He will bring near to Himself.
verse.note: Although Moses was humble in falling on his face ([link]v. 4[/link]), he did not give up his God-given position as God's deputy authority ([link]vv. 5-11[/link], [link]16-18[/link]). Moses did not fight back; rather, he brought the rebels and the ones against whom they rebelled to God. As God's deputy, or delegated, authority, Moses referred this case to God as the highest authority, for His speaking, exposing, and judging. In a struggle for power the only One who can judge and expose the real situation is God Himself.

verse.text: Do this: Take [xref]a[/xref]censers for yourselves, Korah and all [note]1[/note]your company,
verse.note: Lit., his.

chapter.verse: And put fire in them, and put incense on them before Jehovah tomorrow; and the man whom Jehovah chooses, he [i]shall be[/i] holy. It is you who take too much upon yourselves, O sons of Levi!
And Moses said to Korah, Hear now, O sons of Levi:

verse.text: Is it a small thing for you that the God of Israel has [xref]a[/xref]separated you from the assembly of Israel to bring you near to Himself to do the [xref]b[/xref]service of the tabernacle of Jehovah and to stand before the assembly to minister to them?

chapter.verse: Or that He has brought you near, and all your brothers the sons of Levi with you? And do you seek the priesthood also?

verse.text: Therefore you and all your company are gathered together against Jehovah; but Aaron, [xref]a[/xref]what is he that you [xref]b[/xref]murmur against him?

chapter.verse: Then Moses sent [i]word[/i] to call Dathan and Abiram the sons of Eliab; but they said, We will not come up!

verse.text: Is it not enough that you have brought us up out of a land flowing with [xref]a[/xref]milk and honey to have us die in the wilderness, but must you also [xref]b[/xref]lord it over us?

Indeed, you have not brought us into a land flowing with [xref]a[/xref]milk and honey, nor have you given us an inheritance of fields and vineyards. [note]1[/note]Will you put out the eyes of these men? We will not come up!
verse.note: These rebels were eloquent and very stubborn.

verse.text: Then Moses became very angry and said to Jehovah, Do not [xref]a[/xref]regard their offering. I have not taken a single [xref]b[/xref]donkey from them, nor have I done harm to any of them.

chapter.verse: And Moses said to Korah, You and all your company be present before Jehovah, both you and they along with Aaron, tomorrow.
And let each of you take his censer and put incense on them, and each of you present his censer before Jehovah, two hundred fifty censers; you also and Aaron shall each [i]present[/i] his censer.
So each took his censer and put fire in them and laid incense on them, and they stood at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting with Moses and Aaron.

verse.text: Thus Korah gathered the whole assembly against them at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, and the [xref]a[/xref]glory of Jehovah appeared to the whole assembly.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Separate yourselves from among this assembly, so that I may consume them in a moment.
But they [xref]a[/xref]fell on their faces and said, O God, the God of the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]spirits of all flesh, will one man sin and You be angry with the whole assembly?
verse.note: God is the God not of people's flesh but of their spirit (cf. [link]Heb. 12:9[/link]).

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to the assembly, saying, Get away from around the dwellings of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.
Then Moses rose up and went to Dathan and Abiram, and the elders of Israel followed him.
And he spoke to the assembly, saying, Depart now from the tents of these wicked men, and touch nothing which belongs to them, or you will be swept away with all their sins.

So they got away from around the dwellings of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram, and Dathan and Abiram came out, and stood at the entrance of their tents, with their wives and their children and their little ones.

verse.text: And Moses said, By this you shall know that Jehovah has [xref]a[/xref]sent me to do all these works, for it is not of myself.

chapter.verse: If these [i]people[/i] die as all human beings die, or if what befalls all human beings befalls them, then Jehovah has not sent me.

verse.text: But if Jehovah brings about a [xref]a[/xref]new thing, and the ground opens its mouth and swallows them up with all that belongs to them, and they descend alive into [note]1[/note]Sheol, then you will understand that these men have despised Jehovah.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link].

chapter.verse: And as soon as he finished speaking all these words, the ground that was under them was split open.

verse.text: So the earth opened its mouth and [xref]a[/xref]swallowed them up, along with their households and everyone who belonged to [xref]b[/xref]Korah and all [i]their[/i] possessions.
So they and all that belonged to them [note]1[/note]descended alive into Sheol; and the earth [xref]a[/xref]closed over them, and they perished from the midst of the congregation.
verse.note: Korah and the others went down to Sheol alive. They went there directly; they did not need to die first (cf. [link]Rev. 19:20[/link]). This was something new that Jehovah brought about ([link]vv. 29-30[/link]).[br][br]According to [link]26:11[/link], the sons of Korah did not die with Korah and his company. Apparently, they did not join the rebellion but departed from it. In God's sparing Korah's descendants, we can see God's unlimited mercy and grace. One of Korah's descendants was Samuel ([link]1 Chron. 6:33-37[/link]), who became a great prophet and a Nazarite priest. Another was Heman, a grandson of Samuel, who was not only a psalmist ([link]Psa. 88[/link], title) but also a singer in the temple under David's arrangement ([link]1 Chron. 6:31-33[/link]).

chapter.verse: And all Israel who were around them fled at their outcry, for they said, The earth may swallow us up too!

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]fire came forth from Jehovah and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]consumed the two hundred fifty men who presented the incense.
verse.note: God's judgment of these 250 men signifies the judgment of the cross on all of man's service to God that is according to man's opinions, by his flesh, and in rivalry with others.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Tell [xref]a[/xref]Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest to take the censers up out of the burning and scatter the fire about; for they are holy.

The censers of those who have sinned against their own lives, let them be made into beaten plates for a [xref]a[/xref]covering of the [note]1[/note]altar, for they presented them before Jehovah and they became holy. So they shall be a sign to the children of Israel.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 27[/link].

chapter.verse: And Eleazar the priest took the bronze censers which those who were burned had offered; and they beat them out as a covering of the altar,

verse.text: [i]As[/i] a reminder to the children of Israel that no stranger who is not of the seed of [xref]a[/xref]Aaron may come near to [xref]b[/xref]burn incense before Jehovah, so that he does not become like Korah and his company, just as Jehovah had spoken to him through Moses.
But on the next day the whole assembly of the children of Israel [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]murmured against Moses and against Aaron, saying, You have caused the people of Jehovah to die.
verse.note: The murmuring of the people against Moses and Aaron proves that their rebellious nature had not been subdued. See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

verse.text: But when the assembly gathered against Moses and against Aaron, they looked toward the Tent of Meeting, and there the [xref]a[/xref]cloud was, covering it; and the [xref]b[/xref]glory of Jehovah appeared.

chapter.verse: And Moses and Aaron came to the front of the Tent of Meeting.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Get away from the midst of this assembly that I might consume them in a moment. And they [xref]b[/xref]fell upon their faces.

And Moses said to Aaron, Take the censer and put [xref]a[/xref]fire in it from the altar, and lay incense [i]on it,[/i] and carry it quickly to the assembly, and make [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]expiation for them. For wrath has gone forth from Jehovah; the plague has begun.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 16[/link].

chapter.verse: And Aaron took [i]it[/i] as Moses had said and ran into the midst of the assembly. And indeed the plague had begun among the people. So he put on the incense and made expiation for the people.

verse.text: And he stood between the dead and the living, and the plague was [xref]a[/xref]stopped.
Now those who [xref]a[/xref]died by the plague were fourteen thousand seven hundred, besides those who died on account of Korah.

chapter.verse: So Aaron returned to Moses at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting when the plague had been stopped.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, and take from them [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rods, one for each father's house, twelve rods from all their leaders according to their fathers' houses; you shall write everyone's name upon his rod.
verse.note: A rod signifies authority (cf. [link]Rev. 2:26-27[/link]; [link]19:15[/link]).

verse.text: And you shall write Aaron's name upon the [xref]a[/xref]rod of Levi, for there shall be one rod for the head [i]of each[/i] of their fathers' houses.
And you shall place them in the Tent of Meeting before the [note]1[/note]Testimony, where I [xref]a[/xref]meet with you.
verse.note: The testimony is the Ten Commandments in the Ark, which typifies Christ and was the place where God met with His people (see notes [link]34[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 16[/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 25[/link]). This signifies that everything had to be brought into the presence of God to allow God to make the real situation clear by speaking the truth to all the people through His vindication.

verse.text: And the rod of the man whom I [xref]a[/xref]choose shall bud, and I will put a stop to the murmurings of the children of Israel against Me, which they [xref]b[/xref]murmur against you.

chapter.verse: So Moses spoke to the children of Israel. And every one of their leaders gave him a rod, one rod for each leader according to their fathers' houses, twelve rods, with the rod of Aaron among their rods.
And Moses placed the rods before Jehovah in the Tent of the Testimony.

verse.text: And on the next day Moses went into the Tent of the Testimony, and there was the rod of Aaron for the house of Levi: it had [note]1[/note]budded; it even put forth buds and produced blossoms and bore ripe [xref]a[/xref]almonds.
verse.note: A rod is a piece of dead wood that has not only been cut but is also dried up. Yet such a dead and dried-up piece of wood budded! A bud is something organic, something of life. The budding rod of Aaron typifies not a dead Christ but the resurrected Christ, the budding Christ, who not only buds but also blossoms and bears fruit to maturity. Such a Christ imparts life to others ([link]John 12:24[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]). Today He is still budding, and we are the fruit, the almonds, of His budding.[br][br]Since the rebellion of Korah and his company in [link]ch. 16[/link] was related to the priesthood ([link]16:3[/link], [link]8-10[/link]), the budding of Aaron's rod was a vindication indicating that Aaron was the one accepted by God as having authority in the God-given ministry of the priesthood.

chapter.verse: And Moses brought out all the rods from before Jehovah to all the children of Israel, and they looked; and each one took his rod.

verse.text: Then Jehovah said to Moses, [note]1[/note]Put back the rod of Aaron before the Testimony to be kept as a [xref]a[/xref]sign against the rebels, so that you may put an end to their murmurings against Me, and they not die.
verse.note: The budding rod was placed in the Ark along with the hidden manna and the testimony of God, the law ([link]Exo. 16:32-34[/link]; [link]Deut. 10:5[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:4[/link]). All three items are types of Christ. The three items placed in the Ark in the Holy of Holies also refer to the three of the Divine Trinity: the hidden manna in the golden pot refers to God the Father as the divine source of all supply ([link]John 6:32[/link]), the budding rod signifies Christ as the resurrection ([link]John 11:25[/link]), and the tablets of the law refer to the Spirit of life as the inner law ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]). Thus, the Holy of Holies is the dwelling place of God in His Divine Trinity. When we enter into the Holy of Holies, i.e., into our regenerated spirit (see note [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 10[/link]), we enter into God and meet the Father as the source of supply, the Son as the resurrection, and the Spirit as the law of life.

chapter.verse: And Moses did [i]so;[/i] just as Jehovah commanded him, so he did.

verse.text: And the children of Israel spoke to Moses, saying, Alas, we [note]1[/note]die out; we perish; all of us perish.
verse.note: The children of Israel should have been subdued by God's threefold judgment on the rebels in [link]ch. 16[/link] and by God's vindication in this chapter. However, they still complained. This shows the perverseness of the rebellious nature of fallen mankind (cf. [link]Rev. 20:7-9[/link]). It is no wonder that none of these children of Israel, except Joshua and Caleb, were permitted to enter into the promised land ([link]14:28-30[/link]).

chapter.verse: Everyone who comes near, who comes near to the tabernacle of Jehovah, dies. Are we to completely die out?

verse.text: Then Jehovah [note]1[/note]said to Aaron, You and your sons and your father's household with you shall [xref]a[/xref]bear the iniquity of the sanctuary; and you and your sons with you shall bear the [note]2[/note]iniquity of your priesthood.
verse.note: After the rebellion in [link]ch. 16[/link], which was an attack on the priesthood of Aaron and his household, a definite word was given in this chapter regarding the service of the Levites and the priesthood of Aaron and his sons and also regarding the reward ([link]v. 31[/link]) they received as the compensation for their service. The reward given to the priests was a strong vindication of the priesthood in addition to the vindication by the budding rod in [link]ch. 17[/link].

The priesthood was a service to offer all kinds of offerings and sacrifices to God, all of which were types of different aspects of the rich Christ. Thus, it was a very important and serious matter. The priests were required to fulfill their charge without making mistakes so that their priestly service would not have any iniquity.

verse.text: And your brothers also, the tribe of [note]1[/note]Levi, the tribe of your father, bring near with you, so that they may be joined to you and [xref]a[/xref]minister to you, while you and your sons with you are before the Tent of the Testimony.
verse.note: The service of the Levites was to take care of the Tent of Meeting, the Tabernacle of the Testimony ([link]vv. 1a[/link], [link]2a[/link], [link]3-4[/link], [link]6[/link]). In taking care of the tabernacle and its contents, the Levites did not serve God directly; rather, they served the priesthood and the priests, who served God directly.

verse.text: And they shall keep your charge and the charge of all the [xref]a[/xref]tent, but they shall [xref]b[/xref]not come near to the furnishings of the sanctuary and to the altar, so that they do not die, neither they nor you.

chapter.verse: And they shall be joined to you and keep the charge of the Tent of Meeting for all the service of the tent, but a stranger shall not come near to you.

verse.text: And you shall keep the charge of the [note]1[/note]sanctuary and the charge of the [note]1[/note]altar, so that there may be no more wrath upon the children of Israel.
verse.note: The whole tabernacle was the sanctuary, which typifies Christ and also the church (see note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 25[/link]). The altar, which was outside the sanctuary, signifies the cross of Christ ([link]Heb. 13:10[/link]). Therefore, the sanctuary and the altar typify Christ with the church and His cross.

verse.text: And I Myself have taken your brothers the Levites from among the children of Israel. They are a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gift to you, given to Jehovah, to do the service of the Tent of Meeting.
verse.note: The Levites were a gift to Aaron and his sons, a gift that had first been given to God. The children of Israel gave their firstborn to God as a gift, and these were replaced by the Levites ([link]3:12-13[/link] and note [link]12[sup]1[/sup][/link]). God then gave the Levites, who had been given to Him, as a gift to the priests.

verse.text: But you and your sons with you shall attend to your priesthood for everything concerning the altar and [xref]a[/xref]within the veil, and you shall carry out your service. I give you the [xref]b[/xref]priesthood as a service of [note]1[/note]gift, but the stranger who comes near shall be put to death.
verse.note: The priesthood, as the highest service rendered by God's people to God, was a great gift given by God to Aaron and his sons. Moreover, the reward given to the priests for their service was superior to that given to the Levites. This might have been a primary reason that Korah was ambitious to seek the priesthood ([link]16:10[/link]).

verse.text: Then Jehovah spoke to Aaron, And I Myself have given you charge of My heave offerings, even all the holy things of the children of Israel; I have given them to you because of the [xref]a[/xref]anointing, and to your sons, as a perpetual statute.

This shall be yours of the most holy things, [note]1[/note][i]kept[/i] from the fire. Every offering of theirs, even every [xref]a[/xref]meal [note]2[/note]offering of theirs and every [xref]b[/xref]sin offering of theirs and every [xref]c[/xref]trespass offering of theirs, which they shall render to Me, shall be [note]3[/note]most holy for you and for your sons.
verse.note: All the portions of the sons of Israel were offered to God through fire for His enjoyment. God kept some parts of the offerings from the fire that they might become the portion of the priests. This means that the priests enjoyed what God enjoyed, all of which typify Christ. God's delight, enjoyment, and satisfaction is the Son of God, Jesus Christ ([link]Matt. 3:17[/link]). Hence, both God and His serving ones, the priests, enjoy the same portion — the all-inclusive Christ.
For the significance of all the offerings, see notes in [link]Lev. 1-7[/link].
Because the offerings kept from the fire were God's food ([link]28:2[/link]), they were to be most holy to the priests.

verse.text: As the most holy things you shall [xref]a[/xref]eat it; every [note]1[/note]male shall eat it; it shall be holy to you.
verse.note: Signifying those who are spiritually stronger (cf. [link]1 Pet. 3:7[/link]). The enjoyment of Christ makes us stronger, and this affords us the capacity to enjoy Christ in a stronger way (cf. [link]Eph. 3:16-18[/link]).

verse.text: This also is yours, the [xref]a[/xref]heave offering of their gift, even all the [xref]b[/xref]wave offerings of the children of Israel. I have given them to [xref]c[/xref]you and to your [note]1[/note]sons and to your [note]1[/note]daughters with you, as a perpetual statute; everyone who is clean in your house may [xref]d[/xref]eat it.
verse.note: The heave offering (the ascended Christ) and wave offering (the resurrected Christ) were given not only to the priests but also to the sons (the stronger ones) and daughters (the weaker ones) of the priests. This indicates that as long as we belong to the priestly family, whether we are strong or weak, we can enjoy such a Christ. See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: All the [note]1[/note]best of the [xref]a[/xref]oil, and all the [note]1[/note]best of the new wine and of the grain, their [xref]b[/xref]firstfruits that they give to Jehovah, I have given to you.
verse.note: Lit., fat. So throughout this chapter. The fat of the oil signifies Christ's best part, which was for God, and the best of the new wine and of the grain signify the Christ who was poured out to God (cf. [link]Phil. 2:17[/link]). The firstfruits ([link]vv. 12-13[/link]) signify the resurrected Christ ([link]1 Cor. 15:20[/link]).

chapter.verse: The firstfruits of all that is in their land, which they bring to Jehovah, shall be yours; everyone who is clean in your house may eat it.

verse.text: Everything [xref]a[/xref]devoted in Israel shall be yours.

Everything that [xref]a[/xref]opens the womb of all flesh, which they present to Jehovah, whether human or animal, shall be yours; nevertheless the firstborn of human beings you shall surely [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]redeem, and the firstborn of unclean animals you shall redeem.
verse.note: Since each firstborn son did not belong to his parents, the parents were to redeem him at a cost ([link]v. 16[/link]).

verse.text: And those who are to be redeemed from a month old you shall redeem, according to your estimation, for [xref]a[/xref]five shekels of silver, according to the shekel of the sanctuary, which is twenty gerahs.

But the [xref]a[/xref]firstborn of a cow or the firstborn of a sheep or the firstborn of a goat you shall not redeem; they are holy. You shall sprinkle their blood upon the altar and burn their fat as an offering by fire for a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.
But their flesh shall be yours; like the breast of the [xref]a[/xref]wave offering and like the right thigh, it shall be yours.

All the [xref]a[/xref]heave offerings of the holy things, which the children of Israel offer to Jehovah, I have given to you and to your sons and your daughters with you, as a perpetual statute. It is a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]covenant of salt forever before Jehovah for you and for your descendants with you.
verse.note: See note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in Lev. 2[/link].

verse.text: And Jehovah said to Aaron, [xref]a[/xref]You shall have [note]1[/note]no inheritance in their land, nor shall you have any portion among them; I am your [xref]b[/xref]portion and your inheritance among the children of Israel.
verse.note: Neither the priests nor the Levites ([link]vv. 23b[/link], [link]24b[/link]) had any inheritance or any portion in the land of Israel. God Himself was their portion and their inheritance among the sons of Israel ([link]Deut. 10:9[/link]; [link]18:2[/link]; [link]Josh. 13:33[/link]; [link]Ezek. 44:28[/link]). Not only was God's food their portion — God Himself was their portion and their inheritance. Because God was their portion and inheritance, they did not need any other portion or inheritance. Cf. notes [link]18[sup]6[/sup] in Acts 26[/link] and [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Col. 1[/link].

verse.text: And to the children of Levi I have now given every [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]tithe in Israel for an inheritance in return for their service which they carry out, the service of the Tent of Meeting.
verse.note: I.e., ten percent. The tithe was to be offered to God for the Levites and was considered the Levites' inheritance ([link]v. 24[/link]).

chapter.verse: From now on the children of Israel shall not come near the Tent of Meeting, so that they do not incur sin and die.

verse.text: But the Levites shall do the [xref]a[/xref]service of the Tent of Meeting, and they shall bear their iniquity; it shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations. And among the children of Israel they shall have no inheritance.

chapter.verse: For the tithe of the children of Israel, which they offer as a heave offering to Jehovah, I have given to the Levites for an inheritance; therefore I have said to them, Among the children of Israel they shall have no inheritance.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Moreover you shall speak to the Levites and say to them, When you take from the children of Israel the tithe which I have given you from them as your inheritance, then you shall offer up a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]heave offering from it for Jehovah, a [xref]b[/xref]tithe of the tithe.
verse.note: The tithe from the Levites was considered a heave offering, which typifies the ascended Christ. This thought corresponds to the Lord's word in [link]Matt. 6:19-20[/link], where we are told to "store up for yourselves treasures in heaven" rather than on earth. To store up treasures in heaven is to "send" our money to heaven, and to do this is to "heave up" our money (cf. [link]Phil. 4:18[/link]).

chapter.verse: And your heave offering shall be reckoned to you as though it were the grain of the threshing floor and the fullness of the wine press.

verse.text: Thus you shall also offer a heave offering to Jehovah from all your tithes, which you receive from the children of Israel; and from it you shall give [xref]a[/xref]Jehovah's heave offering to [note]1[/note]Aaron the priest.
verse.note: The tithe from the people was given to the Levites ([link]vv. 21[/link], [link]26a[/link]), and the tithe of the tithe ([link]v. 26b[/link]) from the Levites was given to Aaron the priest to be offered to God as a heave offering. This became God's food, a portion of which was also the food of the priests. Thus, the Levites lived on the tithe from the people, and God and the priests lived on the tithe from the Levites.[br][br]God and His people, including the serving ones, were one large family. In this family God the Father as the source gave the good land to His children, who then had to work the land. Eventually, they reaped a harvest, which was to be enjoyed by both God and all the people. They were to bring a portion of the produce to the serving ones, and the serving ones were to offer a portion of what they received to God. In this way, God and His serving ones shared the tithes and lived together. The good land is a type of the all-inclusive Christ (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link]). God's food is the riches of Christ, typified by the produce of the good land, and this produce comes through our labor. We need to labor on Christ and experience Christ. Then Christ will be the produce not only for our satisfaction but also for God's satisfaction.

chapter.verse: Out of all your gifts you shall offer every heave offering of Jehovah, from all the best of it, the sanctified portion of it from them.

Therefore you shall say to them, When you heave from it the best of it, then it shall be reckoned to the Levites as though it were the produce of the threshing floor and the produce of the wine press.

verse.text: And you may [xref]a[/xref]eat it in every place, you and your households, for it is your [note]1[/note]reward in return for your service in the Tent of Meeting.
verse.note: The reward, or compensation, given to Aaron and his sons as the priests ([link]18:8-20[/link]) and to the serving Levites ([link]vv. 21-32[/link]) altogether typifies Christ. In type, the priests and the Levites had no portion other than Christ. Christ was everything to them. Our service to God in the New Testament is not in the realm of material things; therefore, our reward is not in that realm. The only reward, the only compensation, for our priestly and Levitical service is Christ as everything to us (cf. [link]Phil. 3:7-14[/link]).

chapter.verse: And you shall bear no sin by reason of it, when you have heaved from it the best of it. But you shall not profane the holy things of the children of Israel, so that you do not die.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,

verse.text: This is the statute of the law which Jehovah has commanded, saying, Tell the children of Israel to bring you a [note]1[/note]red [xref]a[/xref]heifer without defect, in which is no blemish [i]and[/i] upon which a [xref]b[/xref]yoke has never come.
verse.note: The heifer, the principal component of the water for impurity ([link]v. 9[/link]), signifies the redeeming Christ. The color red signifies the likeness of the flesh of sin, which is for the bearing of man's sin outwardly. The heifer being without defect signifies that although Christ was in the likeness of the flesh of sin, He did not have the sinful nature ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link] and note 3). That the heifer was without blemish indicates that Christ was perfect (see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, in Exo. 12[/link]). The heifer having never been under a yoke signifies that Christ was never used by anyone, especially by or for God's enemy, Satan (cf. [link]Exo. 12:5[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: And you shall give it to Eleazar the priest, and someone shall bring it [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]outside the camp and slaughter it in his presence.
verse.note: Christ was crucified outside the camp ([link]Heb. 13:12-13[/link]), on Calvary, a small mount outside the city of Jerusalem ([link]Matt. 27:33[/link] and note).

verse.text: And Eleazar the priest shall take some of its blood with his finger and [xref]a[/xref]sprinkle its blood toward the front of the Tent of Meeting seven times.
And the heifer shall be [xref]a[/xref]burned in his sight; its skin and its flesh and its blood, with its dung, shall be burned.
And the priest shall take [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cedar wood and hyssop and scarlet [i]strands,[/i] and cast [i]them[/i] into the midst of the burning of the heifer.
verse.note: Cedar wood signifies Christ in His dignified humanity, hyssop signifies Christ in His humbled humanity, and scarlet signifies redemption in its highest significance (see note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in Lev. 14[/link]). The high and dignified Christ and the lowly and humbled Christ in His redemption were elements for the composition of the water for impurity ([link]v. 9[/link]).

verse.text: Then the priest shall [xref]a[/xref]wash his clothes and bathe his flesh in water, and afterward he shall come into the camp; but the priest shall be unclean until the evening.
