And he who burns [note]1[/note]the heifer shall wash his clothes in water and bathe his body in water, and shall be unclean until the evening.
verse.note: Lit., it.

verse.text: And a man who is clean shall gather up the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ashes of the heifer and place [i]them[/i] outside the camp in a clean place, and it shall be kept for the assembly of the children of Israel as [xref]b[/xref]water for [note]2[/note]impurity; it is a sin offering.
verse.note: Ashes signify Christ reduced to nothing ([link]Mark 9:12[/link]). These ashes were kept for the water for impurity; it was a purification of sin, or a sin offering.

The impurity in this chapter does not refer to sin but to death ([link]vv. 11[/link], [link]13-16[/link]). Death issues from sin, and sin is the root of death ([link]Rom. 5:12[/link]). From the sin of rebellion ([link]chs. 11-14[/link] and [link book="Num."]16[/link]), death became prevailing among the children of Israel ([link]16:49[/link]). Thus, there was the need for the water for impurity. Only the working of Christ's redemption, through His dignified and humbled humanity, with His death and the Spirit of His resurrection ([link]v. 17[/link] and note), could heal and cleanse the situation from the uncleanness of death.

chapter.verse: And he who gathers the ashes of the heifer shall wash his clothes and be unclean until the evening. And it shall be a perpetual statute to the children of Israel and to the stranger who sojourns among them.

verse.text: One who touches the [xref]a[/xref]dead body of any human being shall be unclean seven days.

He shall [xref]a[/xref]purify himself with it on the [note]1[/note]third day and on the [note]1[/note]seventh day, and then he shall be clean; but if he does not purify himself on the third day and on the seventh day, he shall not be clean.
verse.note: In typology, the third day signifies resurrection, and the seventh day signifies completion.

verse.text: Whoever touches a dead person, the body of a human being who has died, and does not purify himself, [xref]a[/xref]defiles the tabernacle of Jehovah; and that person shall be cut off from Israel. Because the [xref]b[/xref]water for impurity was not sprinkled upon him, he shall be unclean; his uncleanness is still on him.

chapter.verse: This is the law when a man dies in a tent: Anyone who comes into the tent and everyone who is in the tent shall be unclean seven days.
And every open vessel, which has no covering tied down on it, is unclean.
And whoever in the open field touches one who has been slain with a sword or a dead body or a human bone or a grave shall be unclean seven days.

verse.text: And for the unclean they shall take of the [xref]a[/xref]ashes of the burning of the sin offering, and [note]1[/note]running water shall be added to them in a vessel;
verse.note: Lit., living. The living water here signifies the Holy Spirit in the resurrection of Christ ([link]John 7:37-39[/link] and notes [link]38[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]39[sup]1[/sup][/link]). In the water for impurity, there is the efficacy of Christ's redemption with the washing power of the Spirit of His resurrection.

verse.text: And a clean person shall take [xref]a[/xref]hyssop, and dip [i]it[/i] in the water, and [xref]b[/xref]sprinkle [i]it[/i] on the tent and on all the furnishings and on the persons who were there, or on the one who touched the bone or the one slain or the one who died or the grave.

And the clean person shall [xref]a[/xref]sprinkle on the unclean on the third day and on the seventh day, and on the seventh day he shall purify him. And he shall wash his clothes and bathe [i]himself[/i] in water and shall be clean in the evening.

But the man who shall be unclean and does not purify himself, that person shall be cut off from the midst of the congregation, because he has defiled the sanctuary of Jehovah; the [xref]a[/xref]water for impurity has not been sprinkled on him; he is unclean.

chapter.verse: So it shall be a perpetual statute for them. And he who sprinkles the water for impurity shall wash his clothes, and he who touches the water for impurity shall be unclean until evening.
And whatever the unclean [i]person[/i] touches shall be unclean; and the person who touches [i]it[/i] shall be unclean until evening.

verse.text: Then the children of Israel, the whole assembly, came to the wilderness of Zin in the first month, and the people stayed at Kadesh; and [xref]a[/xref]Miriam [note]1[/note]died there and was buried there.
verse.note: See note [link]28[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And there was [xref]a[/xref]no [note]1[/note]water for the assembly, and they gathered themselves together against Moses and against Aaron.
verse.note: The trouble in [link]vv. 2-13[/link] was caused by the shortage of water, which typifies the Spirit of life ([link]John 7:37-39[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:2[/link]). In type, this shows that whenever God's people are short of the Spirit of life, they will have problems (cf. note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 16[/link]). When God's people have an abundance of the Spirit, their problems among themselves and with God are solved.

chapter.verse: And the people contended with Moses and spoke, saying, If only we had expired when our brothers expired before Jehovah!
Why then have you brought the congregation of Jehovah into this wilderness for us and our livestock to die there?

verse.text: Why then did you bring us up out of Egypt, to bring us to this wretched place? It is not a [xref]a[/xref]place of grain or figs or vines or pomegranates, and there is not even water to drink.
And Moses and Aaron went from before the congregation to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting and [xref]a[/xref]fell upon their faces, and the [xref]b[/xref]glory of Jehovah appeared to them.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Take the [xref]a[/xref]rod, and gather the assembly, you and Aaron your brother, and speak to the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]rock before their eyes, so that it yields its [note]1[/note]water. Thus you shall bring forth water for them out of the rock and give the assembly and their livestock something to [xref]c[/xref]drink.
verse.note: The rock in this chapter typifies the crucified and resurrected Christ ([link]1 Cor. 10:4b[/link]), and the water that flowed from the rock typifies the Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 10:4a[/link]) as the living water that flowed out of the crucified Christ ([link]John 19:34[/link] and note). In [link]Exo. 17[/link] Moses struck the rock with his rod, and water flowed out for the people to drink (see notes [link book="Exo." chapter="17"]6[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]6[sup]3[/sup] in Exo. 17[/link]). According to Paul's word in [link]1 Cor. 10:4[/link] (see note [link book="1 Cor." chapter="10"]4[sup]2[/sup][/link] there), this rock was a spiritual rock that followed God's people in their journey through the wilderness. This signifies that Christ has been crucified to become a rock that follows His people. This following rock is the resurrected Christ as the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]), who is always with the church to supply His believers with the water of life.[br][br]Since Christ has been crucified and the Spirit has been given, there is no need for Christ to be crucified again, i.e., no need to strike the rock again, that the living water may flow. In God's economy Christ should be crucified only once ([link]Heb. 7:27[/link]; [link]9:26-28a[/link]). To receive the living water from the crucified Christ, we need only to "take the rod" and "speak to the rock." To take the rod is to identify with Christ in His death and apply the death of Christ to ourselves and our situation. To speak to the rock is to speak a direct word to Christ as the smitten rock, asking Him to give us the Spirit of life (cf. [link]John 4:10[/link]) based on the fact that the Spirit has already been given. If we apply the death of Christ to ourselves and ask Christ in faith to give us the Spirit, we will receive the living Spirit as the bountiful supply of life ([link]Phil. 1:19[/link]).

verse.text: And Moses took the [xref]a[/xref]rod from before Jehovah, as He had commanded him.

And Moses and Aaron gathered the congregation together before the rock, and he [xref]a[/xref]said to them, Listen now, you [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]rebels: Shall we bring forth water for you out of this rock?
verse.note: Here Moses condemned the people as rebels, but Moses was the one who rebelled against God's word ([link]v. 24[/link]; [link]27:14[/link]).

verse.text: Then Moses lifted up his hand and [xref]a[/xref]struck the rock with his rod twice; and abundant water came forth, and the assembly and their livestock drank.

And Jehovah said to Moses and Aaron, Because you did not believe in Me, to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sanctify Me in the sight of the children of Israel, therefore you shall not bring this congregation [xref]b[/xref]into the land which I have given them.
verse.note: To sanctify God is to make Him holy, i.e., separate from all the false gods; to fail to sanctify God is to make Him common. In being angry with the people ([link]v. 10[/link]) and in wrongly striking the rock twice ([link]v. 11[/link]), Moses failed to sanctify God. In being angry when God was not angry, Moses did not represent God rightly in His holy nature, and in striking the rock twice, he did not keep God's word in His economy (see note [link]8[sup]1[/sup][/link], par. 2). Thus, Moses offended both God's holy nature and His divine economy. Because of this, even though he was intimate with God and may be considered a companion of God ([link]Exo. 33:11[/link]), Moses lost the right to enter the good land.[br][br]In all that we say and do concerning God's people, our attitude must be according to God's holy nature, and our actions must be according to His divine economy. This is to sanctify Him. Otherwise, in our words and deeds we will rebel against Him and offend Him.

verse.text: These are the waters of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Meribah, where the children of Israel contended with Jehovah, and He was sanctified among them.
verse.note: Meaning [i]contention.[/i]

verse.text: Now Moses sent messengers from [xref]a[/xref]Kadesh to the king of [note]1[/note]Edom: Thus says your brother Israel, You know all the hardship that has befallen us;
verse.note: Edom consisted of the descendants of Esau, the brother of Jacob ([link]Gen. 36:1[/link]). The children of Israel were descendants of Jacob. Thus, there was a close relationship between Israel and Edom. In typology Israel may signify our spirit, and Edom may signify our flesh. Israel's attempt to get help from Edom ([link]vv. 14-17[/link], [link]19[/link]) signifies that we may sometimes try to help our spirit by depending on our flesh. Just as Edom refused to help Israel ([link]vv. 18[/link], [link]20-21[/link]), our flesh will never help our spirit (cf. [link]Gal. 5:16-17[/link]). We should be those who are in the spirit and who do not try to get help from the flesh ([link]Phil. 3:3[/link]).

verse.text: How our fathers went down to [xref]a[/xref]Egypt, and we [xref]b[/xref]dwelt in Egypt a long time; and the Egyptians [xref]c[/xref]ill-treated us and our fathers;
And when we [xref]a[/xref]cried to Jehovah, He heard our voice and sent an [xref]b[/xref]Angel and brought us forth out of Egypt; and now we are in Kadesh, a city on the edge of your border.

Please [xref]a[/xref]let us pass through your land. We will not pass through field or through vineyard, nor will we drink water from any well; we will go along the King's Highway, not turning aside to the right or to the left, until we pass through your territory.
But Edom said to him, You shall not pass through [note]1[/note]my territory, or else I will come out against you with the sword.
verse.note: Lit., me.

chapter.verse: Then the children of Israel said to him, We will go up by the highway, and if I and my livestock drink some of your water, then I will pay its price. Allow me only this one thing, to pass through on foot.
However he said, You shall not pass through. And Edom came out against him with a large number of people and with a mighty hand.

verse.text: So Edom [xref]a[/xref]refused to give Israel passage through his territory, and Israel turned away from him.
Now when they [xref]a[/xref]journeyed from Kadesh, the children of Israel, the whole assembly, came to Mount Hor.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron at Mount Hor, on the border of the land of Edom, saying,

verse.text: Aaron shall be [xref]a[/xref]gathered to his people, for he shall not enter into the land which I have given to the children of Israel, because you [xref]b[/xref]rebelled against My word at the waters of Meribah.

chapter.verse: Take Aaron and Eleazar his son, and bring them up Mount Hor;

verse.text: And strip Aaron of his [xref]a[/xref]garments and put them upon Eleazar his son; so Aaron will be gathered [i]to his people,[/i] and will die there.

chapter.verse: So Moses did just as Jehovah had commanded, and they went up Mount Hor in the sight of the whole assembly.

verse.text: And when Moses had stripped Aaron of his garments and put them on Eleazar his son, Aaron [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]died there on the top of the mountain. Then Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain.
verse.note: On their journey the children of Israel had a number of failures. The book of Numbers shows us that the result of those failures was death, not only of the common Israelites ([link]11:1[/link], [link]33-34[/link]; [link]14:36-37[/link], [link]45[/link]; [link]16:32-33[/link]; [link]25:3-9[/link]) but also of Miriam ([link]20:1[/link]), Aaron ([link]20:23-29[/link]), and Moses ([link]27:12-14[/link]). This should be a warning to us to be careful concerning failures because failures result in death, and some even in physical death (cf. [link]Acts 5:1-11[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 11:27-30[/link]; [link]1 John 5:16[/link]).

verse.text: And when the whole assembly saw that Aaron had expired, all the house of Israel wept for Aaron [xref]a[/xref]thirty days.

And when the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Canaanite, the king of [note]2[/note]Arad, who dwelt in the Negev, heard that Israel was coming by the way of Atharim, he fought against Israel and took some of them captive.
verse.note: In the typology of the Old Testament, Canaan has two aspects: on the positive side Canaan, a land of riches ([link]Deut. 8:7-10[/link] and note [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link]), typifies the all-inclusive Christ with His unsearchable riches ([link]Col. 1:12[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:8[/link]), and on the negative side, it signifies the aerial part, the heavenly part, of the dark kingdom of Satan. As the ruler of this world ([link]John 12:31[/link]) and as the ruler of the authority of the air ([link]Eph. 2:2[/link]), Satan has his authority ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]) and his angels ([link]Matt. 25:41[/link]), who are his subordinates as principalities, powers, and rulers of the darkness of this world ([link]Eph. 6:12[/link]). Hence, he has his kingdom ([link]Matt. 12:26[/link]), the authority of darkness ([link]Col. 1:13[/link]). The Canaanites typify the fallen angels, the rebellious angels who follow Satan ([link]Rev. 12:4[/link], [link]7[/link]), who have become the powers, rulers, and authorities in Satan's kingdom (cf. [link]Dan. 10:13[/link], [link]20[/link]). The fighting of the children of Israel against the Canaanites that they might possess and enjoy the good land typifies the spiritual warfare of the church as a whole, including all the members, against "the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenlies" ([link]Eph. 6:12[/link]) that the saints may enjoy Christ as the all-inclusive land. The church must be such a corporate warrior, fighting against Satan's aerial forces so that God's people may gain more of Christ for the building up of the Body of Christ, establishing and spreading the kingdom of God so that Christ can come back to inherit the earth.

The kings of Arad, of the Amorites ([link]v. 21[/link]), and of Bashan ([link]v. 33[/link]) were the "gate guards" on the east of the Jordan, guarding the land of Canaan, the kingdom of darkness, for Satan. In order for the children of Israel to enter into the good land, they had to pass through the territory controlled by these kings and had to fight against them, destroy them, and take over their territory. This signifies that in order to enjoy the unsearchably rich Christ, the church must defeat and take over the territory of the enemies signified by these kings. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And Israel made a [xref]a[/xref]vow to Jehovah and said, If You will indeed deliver this people into my hand, then I will [xref]b[/xref]utterly destroy their cities.
And Jehovah listened to the voice of Israel and delivered up the Canaanites, and they utterly destroyed them and their cities. Thus the name of the place was called [note]1[/note]Hormah.
verse.note: Meaning [i]destruction.[/i]

verse.text: Then they journeyed from Mount Hor by the way to the Red Sea, to go [xref]a[/xref]around the land of Edom; and [note]1[/note]the people became impatient on the way.
verse.note: Lit., the soul of the people became short. In [link]ch. 20[/link] the children of Israel's contending for water was fair because it came from the people's thirst. In this chapter their contending was not fair, because it came from the people's impatience. God did not punish the people in [link]ch. 20[/link], but He did punish them in this chapter.

verse.text: And the people spoke against God and against Moses, Why have you brought us up out of Egypt to die in the wilderness? For there is no food and there is no water; and our soul loathes this [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]light bread.
verse.note: Or, contemptible, worthless.

verse.text: Then Jehovah sent fiery [xref]a[/xref]serpents among the people, and they bit the people, so that many people of Israel died.

chapter.verse: And the people came to Moses and said, We have sinned, because we have spoken against Jehovah and against you; pray to Jehovah, that He may take away the serpents from us. So Moses prayed for the people.

verse.text: Then Jehovah said to Moses, Make a fiery [i]serpent,[/i] and set it on a [note]1[/note]pole; and everyone who is bitten, when he sees it, shall live.
verse.note: Or, standard. So also in [link]v. 9[/link]. The pole, or standard, here signifies the cross of Christ.

verse.text: And Moses made a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bronze serpent and set it on the pole; and if a serpent had bitten any man, when he [xref]b[/xref]looked at the bronze serpent, he lived.
verse.note: Bronze signifies judgment. The bronze serpent is a type of the Lord Jesus, who was crucified in the likeness of the flesh of sin as our Substitute and Replacement that we might "look at" (believe into) Him and have eternal life ([link]John 3:14-15[/link] and notes; [link]Rom. 8:3[/link] and note 3).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And the children of Israel journeyed and encamped at Oboth.

chapter.verse: And they journeyed from Oboth and encamped at Iye-abarim in the wilderness which faces Moab toward the sunrise.

verse.text: From there they journeyed and encamped in the valley of [xref]a[/xref]Zered.

From there they [xref]a[/xref]journeyed and encamped on the other side of the Arnon, which is in the wilderness that comes out of the border of the Amorites; for the Arnon is the border of Moab, between Moab and the Amorites.

chapter.verse: Therefore it is said in the Book of the Wars of Jehovah,[br/]Waheb in Suphah, / And the valleys of the Arnon,
And the slope of the valleys / That inclines toward the seat of Ar / And leans toward the border of Moab.

verse.text: And from there [i]they journeyed[/i] to [note]1[/note]Beer; that is the well where Jehovah said to Moses, Gather the people together, and I will give them [xref]a[/xref]water.
verse.note: Meaning [i]a well.[/i] The rock in [link]20:8[/link] and [link]Exo. 17:5-6[/link] typifies Christ crucified (smitten) on the cross by God so that the living water, the consummated Spirit of the processed Triune God, might flow out into us, whereas the well at Beer typifies Christ within us ([link]John 4:11-12[/link], [link]14[/link]). The digging of the well ([link]v. 18[/link]) signifies the digging away of the "dirt," the barriers in our heart — our mind, emotion, will, and conscience — so that the Spirit as the living water may spring up within us and flow freely.

chapter.verse: Then Israel sang this song:[br/]Spring up, O well! Sing to it!

verse.text: The well, which the [note]1[/note]leaders sank, / Which the [note]1[/note]nobles of the people dug, / With the scepter, with their staffs.[br/]And from the wilderness [i]they journeyed[/i] to Mattanah;
verse.note: Those who seek after the Spirit and take the lead to dig the well are noble and are leaders.

chapter.verse: And from Mattanah to Nahaliel, and from Nahaliel to Bamoth;

verse.text: And from Bamoth to the valley that is in the land of Moab, to the top of [xref]a[/xref]Pisgah, which looks down upon the desert.
And Israel [xref]a[/xref]sent messengers to Sihon the king of the [note]1[/note]Amorites, saying,
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Let me pass through your land. We will not turn aside into field or into vineyard; we will not drink water from any well. We will go by the King's Highway until we have passed through your territory.

[xref]a[/xref]But Sihon would not allow Israel to pass through his territory. And Sihon gathered all his people together and went out against Israel into the wilderness, and he came to Jahaz and fought against Israel.

And Israel [xref]a[/xref]struck him with the edge of the sword and took possession of his land from the Arnon to the Jabbok, as far as the children of Ammon; for the border of the children of Ammon was strong.

chapter.verse: And Israel took all these cities, and Israel settled in all the cities of the Amorites, in Heshbon and in all her villages.
For Heshbon was the city of Sihon the king of the Amorites, who had fought against the former king of Moab and taken all his land out of his hand, as far as the Arnon.
Therefore those who speak in proverbs say,[br/]Come to Heshbon; let it be built, / And let the city of Sihon be established.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]For fire has gone forth from Heshbon, / A flame from the city of Sihon; / It has consumed Ar of Moab / [note]1[/note]And swallowed up the high places of the Arnon.
verse.note: According to the Septuagint; the Hebrew text reads, The lords of the high places of the Arnon.

chapter.verse: Woe to you, O Moab! / You have perished, O people of Chemosh; / He has given his sons as fugitives, / And his daughters [i]have gone[/i] into captivity, / To an Amorite king, Sihon.

verse.text: We have shot at them; / Heshbon is ruined as far as Dibon, / And we have laid waste as far as Nophah, / [note]1[/note]Fire [i]spreads[/i] as far as Medeba.
verse.note: According to the Septuagint; the Hebrew text reads, Which.

chapter.verse: Thus Israel settled in the land of the Amorites.

verse.text: And Moses sent [i]some[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]spy out Jazer. And they captured its villages and dispossessed the Amorites who were there.
And they turned and went up on the way [i]that leads[/i] to Bashan; and [xref]a[/xref]Og the king of [note]1[/note]Bashan went out against them, he and all his people, for battle at Edrei.
verse.note: Bashan, mentioned in [link]Psa. 22:12[/link]; [link]68:15[/link], [link]22[/link]; [link]135:11[/link]; and [link]136:20[/link], is a mountain standing in opposition to God's dwelling place. Thus, Bashan is a type of the satanic authority in the air. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup][/link].

chapter.verse: And Jehovah said to Moses, Do not fear him, for I have given him and all his people and his land into your hand; and you shall do to him as you did to Sihon the king of the Amorites, who was dwelling at Heshbon.
So they struck him and his sons and all his people until there was no survivor left to him, and they possessed his land.

verse.text: And the children of Israel [xref]a[/xref]journeyed and encamped in the plains of Moab beyond the Jordan at Jericho.
And [xref]a[/xref]Balak the son of Zippor saw all that Israel had done to the Amorites.

chapter.verse: And Moab was very afraid of the people because they were many, and Moab was distressed because of the children of Israel.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Moab said to the elders of [note]1[/note]Midian, This multitude will now lick up all that is around us, as the ox licks up the grass of the field. Now Balak the son of Zippor was king of Moab at that time.
verse.note: Moab was a son born of Lot and one of his daughters through incest ([link]Gen. 19:30-38[/link]). Hence, Moab represents the fruit of fleshly lust. Midian was very close to the children of Ishmael, who represents the flesh, in contrast to Isaac, who represents that which is born of the Spirit (cf. [link]Gal. 4:22-23[/link], [link]28-29[/link]). Thus, Midian also signifies the flesh.

verse.text: And he sent messengers to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Balaam the son of Beor, to Pethor, which is by the [note]2[/note]River, to the land of the children of his people, to call him, saying, There is a people here who have come out from Egypt; now they cover the surface of the land and have settled over against me.
verse.note: Balaam was a Gentile prophet of God (see note [link]15[sup]3[/sup] in 2 Pet. 2[/link]). After Israel defeated the three kings on the east of the Jordan ([link]21:1-3[/link], [link]21-35[/link]), Satan changed his mode of fighting against Israel and took a religious way.
I.e., the Euphrates.

verse.text: Now, therefore, please come; [xref]a[/xref]curse this people for me, since they are mightier than I. Perhaps I may be able to strike them and drive them out of the land, for I know that whomever you bless is blessed and whomever you curse is cursed.

chapter.verse: So the elders of Moab and the elders of Midian departed with fees for divination in their hand, and they came to Balaam and spoke to him the words of Balak.

verse.text: And he said to them, Spend tonight here, and I will bring back word to you as [note]1[/note]Jehovah speaks to me. And the rulers of Moab stayed with Balaam.
verse.note: Balaam's asking God whether he should go with the messengers or not was self-deception. If we seek the Lord's will but are actually inclined to carry out our own desires, we may deceive ourselves, even as Balaam deceived himself. We should seek the Lord's will without having any other desire but to know His will and to do it.

chapter.verse: And God came to Balaam and said, Who are these men with you?
And Balaam said to God, Balak the son of Zippor, the king of Moab, has sent [i]word[/i] to me, [i]saying,[/i]

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]There is a people who came out of Egypt, and they cover the surface of the land. Now come; curse them for me; perhaps I will be able to fight against them and drive them out.
And God said to Balaam, You shall not go with them; you shall not [note]1[/note]curse the people, for they are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blessed.
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 12[/link].

chapter.verse: So Balaam rose up in the morning and said to the rulers from Balak, Go to your land, for Jehovah has refused to let me go with you.
And the rulers of Moab rose up and went to Balak and said, Balaam refuses to come with us.
So Balak yet again sent rulers, more numerous and more honorable than these.
And they came to Balaam and said to him, Thus says Balak the son of Zippor, Please let nothing hinder you from coming to me,
For I will indeed honor you greatly; and whatever you say to me I will do. Please come therefore; curse this people for me.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And Balaam answered and said to the servants of Balak, Even if Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I could not go beyond the word of Jehovah my God, to do less or more.

chapter.verse: Now you therefore please stay here tonight also, so that I may know what more Jehovah might speak to me.

verse.text: And God came to Balaam at night and said to him, Since the men have come to call you, rise up; [note]1[/note]go with them, but only what I speak to you shall you do.
verse.note: Because Balaam wanted to do so, God allowed him to go with the rulers of Moab. It was Balaam's will to go, not God's (cf. [link]v. 22[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Balaam rose up in the morning and saddled his donkey and went with the rulers of Moab.

verse.text: And God's anger was kindled because he was going, and the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Angel of Jehovah took His stand in the way as an adversary against him. Now he was riding on his donkey, and his two servants were with him.
verse.note: The Angel of Jehovah here was Jehovah Himself (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 3[/link]), who came in to deal directly with this greedy prophet ([link]2 Pet. 2:15[/link]).

chapter.verse: And when the donkey saw the Angel of Jehovah standing in the way with His drawn sword in His hand, the donkey turned aside out of the way and went into the field. And Balaam struck the donkey to turn her back into the way.
Then the Angel of Jehovah stood in a narrow path between the vineyards, with a wall on this side and a wall on that side.
And when the donkey saw the Angel of Jehovah, she pressed herself against the wall and crushed Balaam's foot against the wall. So he struck her again.
And the Angel of Jehovah went further and stood in a narrow place, where there was no way to turn either to the right or to the left.
And when the donkey saw the Angel of Jehovah, she lay down under Balaam. Then Balaam's anger was kindled, and he struck the donkey with his staff.

verse.text: And Jehovah opened the mouth of the [xref]a[/xref]donkey, and she said to Balaam, What have I done to you, that you have struck me these three times?

chapter.verse: And Balaam said to the donkey, Because you have mocked me! If I had a sword in my hand, I would have killed you by now.
And the donkey said to Balaam, Am I not your donkey on which you have ridden all your life to this day? Have I ever been accustomed to do so to you? And he said, No.

verse.text: Then Jehovah opened the eyes of Balaam, and he saw the [xref]a[/xref]Angel of Jehovah standing in the way with His drawn sword in His hand, and he bowed his head and fell on his face.

chapter.verse: And the Angel of Jehovah said to him, Why have you struck your donkey these three times? I am here, having come out as an adversary, because your way was unrestrained before Me.
And the donkey saw Me and turned aside before Me these three times. If she had not turned aside from Me, I would surely have killed you just now and let her live.
And Balaam said to the Angel of Jehovah, I have sinned, for I did not know that You were standing in the way against me. Now then, if it displeases You, I will turn back.
And the Angel of Jehovah said to Balaam, Go with the men; but you shall speak only the word that I shall speak to you. So Balaam went with the rulers from Balak.
And when Balak heard that Balaam was coming, he went out to meet him at the city of Moab, which is on the border of the Arnon, at the farthest point of the border.

verse.text: And Balak said to Balaam, Did I not send [i]word[/i] urgently to you to call you? Why did you not come to me? Am I not indeed able to [xref]a[/xref]honor you?
And Balaam said to Balak, Here I am; I have come to you now. Am I able to speak anything at all? [xref]a[/xref]The word that God puts in my mouth, that I shall speak.

chapter.verse: And Balaam went with Balak, and they came to Kiriath-huzoth.
And Balak sacrificed oxen and sheep, and sent [i]them[/i] to Balaam and to the rulers who were with him.

verse.text: And in the morning Balak took Balaam and brought him up to [note]1[/note]Bamoth-baal, and he saw from there the [xref]a[/xref]edge of the people.
verse.note: Or, the high places of Baal. These were the places where people worshipped the idol of Baal.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Then Balaam said to Balak, Build me seven altars here, and have seven bulls and seven rams ready for me here.
And Balak did just as Balaam had spoken. And Balak and Balaam [note]1[/note]offered up a bull and a ram on [i]each[/i] altar.
verse.note: It was not clear to whom Balak and Balaam offered — to Jehovah or to Baal ([link]22:41[/link] and note). Balaam worshipped in God's way, but he mixed the worship of God with the worship of an idol. This kind of mixture in worship can be found in Roman Catholicism.

chapter.verse: And Balaam said to Balak, Stand near your burnt offering, and I will go; perhaps Jehovah will come to meet me; and whatever He shows me I will tell you. And he went to a bare height.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And God met Balaam, and he said to Him, I have prepared the seven altars, and I have offered up a bull and a ram on [i]each[/i] altar.

chapter.verse: And Jehovah put a word in Balaam's mouth and said, Return to Balak, and you shall speak this.
When he returned to him, there he was, standing beside his burnt offering, he and all the rulers of Moab.

verse.text: And he took up his [note]1[/note]parable and said,[br/]From Aram Balak brought me, / The king of Moab from the mountains of the East. / Come, [xref]a[/xref]curse Jacob for me; / And come, denounce Israel!
verse.note: Or, couplet. Balaam's parable in [link]vv. 7-10[/link] was actually a God-inspired prophecy.

verse.text: How shall I curse whom God has [xref]a[/xref]not cursed? / And how can I denounce whom Jehovah has not denounced?
For from the top of the rocks I see him, / And from the hills I behold him. / Here is a people who live [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]alone / And do not reckon themselves among the nations.
verse.note: This word indicates that the children of Israel were a holy, sanctified people, a people set apart from the nations. The same is true of the church ([link]1 Cor. 3:17[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:4[/link]; [link]5:27[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:9[/link]).

verse.text: Who can [xref]a[/xref]count the [note]1[/note]dust of Jacob, / Or number the fourth part of Israel? / Let [note]2[/note]me die the death of the upright, / And let my latter end be like theirs!
verse.note: Balaam's word in [link]v. 10a[/link] was a blessing of abundant increase, and his word in [link]v. 10b[/link] was a word of great blessing and appreciation.
Lit., my soul.

chapter.verse: And Balak said to Balaam, What have you done to me? I took you to curse my enemies, but now you have altogether blessed [i]them.[/i]

verse.text: And he answered and said, [xref]a[/xref]Shall I not take care to speak what Jehovah puts in my mouth?
[xref]a[/xref]And Balak said to him, Come now with me to another place from which you may see them. You will see only the outside edge of them and not see them all; then curse them for me from there.
So he took him into the field of Zophim, to the top of [xref]a[/xref]Pisgah, and built seven altars and offered up a bull and a ram on [i]each[/i] altar.

chapter.verse: And he said to Balak, Stand here near your burnt offering while I meet [i]Jehovah[/i] there.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And Jehovah met Balaam and put a word in his mouth and said, Return to Balak, and you shall speak this.

chapter.verse: When he came to him, there he was, standing beside his burnt offering, and the rulers of Moab with him. And Balak said to him, What has Jehovah spoken?
And he took up his parable and said,[br/]Arise, O Balak, and hear; / Listen to me, O son of Zippor:

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]God is not a man, that He should [note]1[/note]lie, / Nor a son of man, that He should repent. / Has He said, and will He not do it? / Or has He spoken, and will He not establish it?
verse.note: Or, fail.

verse.text: Now I have received [i]a word[/i] to bless; / Since He has [xref]a[/xref]blessed, then I cannot reverse it.

He has not beheld [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]iniquity in Jacob, / Nor has He seen trouble in Israel; / [xref]b[/xref]Jehovah their God is with them, / And the shout of a [note]2[/note]king is among them.
verse.note: This word was spoken not according to the human view but according to the divine view. In the sight of God, Israel is without fault. In themselves God's people have many defects, but in God's redemption and in Christ they have no defects. When God looks at His people, He does not see them according to what they are in themselves but according to what they are in Christ (cf. [link]2 Cor. 5:16-17[/link]).
Ultimately, this king refers to Christ.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]God is the One who brought them forth out of Egypt; / [note]1[/note]He has as it were the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]horns of the wild ox.
verse.note: Referring to Israel. Alternatively, the text can be translated, He is for them like the horns of a wild ox. So also in [link]24:8[/link].

The reference to the horns of a wild ox and the reference to the lion and the lioness in [link]v. 24[/link] indicate that the church is victorious ([link]Rom. 8:37[/link]; [link]16:20[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:11[/link]).

verse.text: Surely there is no enchantment against Jacob, / Nor is there any divination against Israel. / Now it shall be said of Jacob / And of Israel, What has God [xref]a[/xref]wrought!
See, a people rises up like a lioness, / And like a [xref]a[/xref]lion they lift themselves up. / They shall not lie down until they eat the prey / And drink the blood of the slain.

chapter.verse: And Balak said to Balaam, Neither curse them at all, nor bless them at all.

verse.text: But Balaam answered and said to Balak, Did I not tell you, saying, [xref]a[/xref]All that Jehovah speaks, that I must do?
[xref]a[/xref]And Balak said to Balaam, Come now, I will take you to another place; perhaps it will please God that you may curse them for me from there.

chapter.verse: And Balak took Balaam to the top of Peor, which looks down upon the desert.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And Balaam said to Balak, Build me seven altars here, and have seven bulls and seven rams ready for me here.

chapter.verse: And Balak did just as Balaam had said, and he offered up a bull and a ram on [i]each[/i] altar.

verse.text: And when Balaam saw that it pleased Jehovah to bless Israel, he did [xref]a[/xref]not go as at the other times to meet with enchantments, but he set his face toward the wilderness.
And Balaam lifted up his eyes and saw Israel dwelling according to their tribes, and the [xref]a[/xref]Spirit of God came upon him.
[xref]a[/xref]And he took up his parable and said,[br/]Balaam the son of Beor declares, / And the man whose eye is [note]1[/note]opened declares;
verse.note: Or, true. So also in [link]v. 15[/link].

verse.text: He declares, he who hears the words of God, / Who sees the vision of the [xref]a[/xref]All-sufficient One, / Falling down, but having his eyes uncovered:
[xref]a[/xref]How [note]1[/note]fair are your tents, O Jacob, / Your tabernacles, O Israel!
verse.note: Or, good. Balaam's first parable reveals that Israel is holy ([link]23:9[/link]), the second, that Israel is perfect ([link]23:21[/link]), and the third, that Israel is beautiful, as indicated by the word [i]fair[/i] here. This will be the actual situation of Israel in the millennium. God promised that the descendants of Abraham would be a blessing to all the nations ([link]Gen. 12:2-3[/link]). Eventually, the Jews will be fully blessed by God, and they will be a blessing to the entire human race ([link]Isa. 2:2-3[/link]; [link]Zech. 8:20-23[/link]). Balaam's parables also indicate that in its standing the church is holy, in the sight of God the church is perfect, and in appearance the church is beautiful, fair (cf. [link]Eph. 5:27[/link]).

verse.text: Like [note]1[/note]valleys they are spread forth, / Like [xref]a[/xref]gardens beside a river, / Like [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]aloes which Jehovah has planted, / Like cedars beside [xref]c[/xref]water.
verse.note: Or, palm trees. The word concerning valleys and gardens here and concerning water flowing from buckets in [link]v. 7[/link] reveals figuratively that the church has valleys ([link]Rev. 2:9-10[/link]), that the church is like a garden ([link]1 Cor. 3:9b[/link]), and that in the church there is an abundance of water ([link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]; cf. [link]John 7:38-39[/link]). These are some of the riches concerning the church.

Aloe is a plant known for its healing effect. The Lord Jesus was buried with aloes ([link]John 19:39[/link]). After the Lord's coming back, Israel will be a healing to the nations, and that healing will be a great blessing ([link]Isa. 2:2-3[/link]; [link]Zech. 8:20-23[/link]).

verse.text: Water shall flow from his buckets, / And his seed shall be in many waters, / And his [note]1[/note]king shall be higher than [xref]a[/xref]Agag, / And his kingdom shall be exalted.
verse.note: Balaam's word here is a prophecy that eventually has its fulfillment in Christ.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]God is the One who brought him forth out of Egypt; / He has as it were the [note]1[/note]horns of the wild ox. / He shall eat up the nations, his adversaries, / And shall break their bones in pieces, / And shatter [i]them[/i] with his arrows.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 8-9a[/link], see notes on [link]23:22[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]He couches; he lies down like a lion / And like a lioness; who will rouse him up? / [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Blessed is everyone who blesses you, / And cursed is everyone who curses you.
verse.note: Instead of cursing God's people, Balaam, speaking on behalf of God, altogether blessed them. To bless a person is to speak well of him, to speak positively concerning him ([link]Eph. 1:3[/link] and notes 1 and 4). The more we praise the Lord for His people and speak well of them in faith, the more we put ourselves under God's blessing. Those who speak positively concerning the church receive the blessing. Those who speak negatively put themselves under a curse.

verse.text: Then Balak's anger was kindled against Balaam, and he struck his hands together. And Balak said to Balaam, I called you to [xref]a[/xref]curse my enemies, but now you have altogether blessed [i]them[/i] these three times.
Therefore now flee to your place! I said I would greatly [xref]a[/xref]honor you, but now Jehovah has kept you away from honor.
[xref]a[/xref]And Balaam said to Balak, Did I not also speak to your messengers whom you sent to me, saying,

chapter.verse: Even if Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I could not go beyond the word of Jehovah, to do either good or bad from my own heart? What Jehovah speaks, that I will speak.
And now therefore, I am going to my people. Come, let me give you counsel as to what this people will do to your people in the last days.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And he took up his parable and said,[br/]Balaam the son of Beor declares, / And the man whose eye is opened declares;

He declares, he who hears the words of God / And obtains the knowledge of the [xref]a[/xref]Most High, / Who sees the vision of the [xref]b[/xref]All-sufficient One, / Falling down, but having his eyes uncovered:

I see Him, but not now; / I behold Him, but not near. / There shall [note]1[/note]come forth a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Star out of Jacob, / And a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Scepter shall rise out of Israel, / And He shall crush the corners of [xref]c[/xref]Moab / And break down all the sons of Sheth.
verse.note: Lit., march forth, tread.

Both the Star and the Scepter refer to Christ. The Star is the heavenly Christ, and the Scepter is Christ as the One with power and authority. The greatest blessing to the children of Israel is Christ. As the Star and the Scepter, Christ will be the almighty One with all-inclusive power and authority.[br][br]Balaam's first three parables concern the church, which is sanctified, perfect, and beautiful (see note [link]5[sup]1[/sup][/link]), whereas his fourth parable contains a prophecy concerning Christ. The church is sanctified, perfect, and beautiful when it is full of Christ. Christ is the content, the constituent, and every part of the church as the new man ([link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]).

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Edom shall be dispossessed — / Seir, His [note]1[/note]enemies, shall also be dispossessed — / While Israel does valiantly.
verse.note: The enemies here are Christ's enemies. These enemies will be destroyed, but because of Christ, Israel will remain. This prophecy, as the New Testament indicates ([link]Rom. 11:25-32[/link]), will be fully fulfilled in the millennium.

verse.text: And One from Jacob shall have dominion / And destroy the remnant from [note]1[/note]the city.
verse.note: Or, Ir.

verse.text: And he looked on [note]1[/note]Amalek and took up his parable and said,[br/][xref]a[/xref]Amalek was the first of the nations, / But his latter end [i]shall come[/i] to destruction.
verse.note: In [link]vv. 20-24[/link] Balaam prophesied concerning other peoples. These prophecies reveal that God is over all. All the nations are under His control and His reign for the fulfillment of His purpose ([link]Dan. 2:31-45[/link]; [link]4:17[/link], [link]26[/link]; [link]5:21c[/link]; [link]Acts 17:26[/link]). He rules over the nations that His economy may be accomplished among the nations through Israel.

chapter.verse: And he looked on the Kenites and took up his parable and said,[br/]Strong is your dwelling place, / And your nest is set in the rock.

verse.text: Nevertheless Kain shall be burned / Until [xref]a[/xref]Asshur carry you away captive.

chapter.verse: And he took up his parable and said,[br/]Alas, who shall live when God does this?

verse.text: But ships [i]shall come[/i] from the coast of [xref]a[/xref]Kittim, / And they shall afflict Asshur and shall afflict Eber; / And he also [i]shall come[/i] to destruction.

chapter.verse: And Balaam rose up and went back to his place, and Balak also went his way.

verse.text: While Israel dwelt in Shittim, the people began to commit [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fornication with the daughters of Moab.
verse.note: Unable to defeat Israel militarily, politically, or through the use of religion, Balak, under the evil counsel of Balaam ([link]31:16[/link]; [link]Rev. 2:14[/link]), induced Israel to fall into fornication and idolatry ([link]vv. 1-3a[/link]). Fornication destroys the person of the God-created man, and idolatry insults the divine person of God. According to the record of the Bible, fornication and idolatry go together ([link]Acts 15:29[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 10:7-8[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:5[/link]).[br][br]God's view of Israel, revealed in Balaam's parables ([link]chs. 23-24[/link]), is altogether positive; but according to their actual situation and condition in their adamic nature, the children of Israel were fallen and sinful, a people of fornication and idolatry. The situation is the same with the believers in Christ. On the one hand, in Christ we are a heavenly people ([link]Eph. 2:6[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:20a[/link]; [link]Col. 3:1-3[/link]); on the other hand, in ourselves we are a fallen and sinful people, worthy to be judged by God ([link]Rom. 7:18[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:1-3[/link]).

verse.text: For they invited the people to the sacrifices of their gods, and the people [xref]a[/xref]ate and bowed down to their gods.
And Israel joined itself to [xref]a[/xref]Baal-peor, and the anger of Jehovah was kindled against Israel.
And Jehovah said to Moses, Take all the leaders of the people and [xref]a[/xref]hang them up to Jehovah before the sun, so that the fierce anger of Jehovah may turn away from Israel.
And Moses said to the judges of Israel, Each of you [xref]a[/xref]slay his men who have joined themselves to Baal-peor.

Just then one of the children of Israel came and brought a [xref]a[/xref]Midianite woman to his brothers in the sight of Moses and in the sight of the whole assembly of the children of Israel, while they were weeping at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
And when [xref]a[/xref]Phinehas the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, saw it, he rose up from the midst of the assembly and took a spear in his hand,

chapter.verse: And he went after the man of Israel into the tent and pierced both of them, the man of Israel and the woman through her stomach. So the plague among the children of Israel was stopped.

verse.text: And those who died by the [note]1[/note]plague were [xref]a[/xref]twenty-four thousand.
verse.note: The plague was a purification of God's people, a sifting that dealt with the mixture among them (cf. [link]11:4[/link]). Since the history of Israel is a complete type of the church ([link]1 Cor. 9:24-10:11[/link]), the mixture among the children of Israel is a type of the mixture in the church (cf. [link]Acts 4:32-5:11[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:20[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 2:17-21[/link]; [link]4:10[/link], [link]14-15[/link]). God uses the failure and turmoil among His people to purify them from mixture. God also uses the frustrations suffered by His chosen and redeemed people as a means to humble them and test them in their journey with Him ([link]Deut. 8:2[/link]). The punishment in this chapter was the last purification of the children of Israel before they entered into the good land.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Phinehas the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, has turned My wrath away from the children of Israel, in that he was jealous with My [xref]a[/xref]jealousy among them, so that I did not consume the children of Israel in My jealousy.
Therefore say, I now give him My [xref]a[/xref]covenant of peace;
And it shall be to him and to his seed after him the covenant of an [xref]a[/xref]everlasting priesthood, because he was jealous for his God and made expiation for the children of Israel.

chapter.verse: Now the name of the slain man of Israel, who was slain with the Midianite woman, was Zimri the son of Salu, a leader of a father's household among the Simeonites.
And the name of the Midianite woman who was slain was Cozbi the daughter of Zur, head of the people of a father's household in Midian.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Harass the [xref]a[/xref]Midianites and strike them;

chapter.verse: For they have harassed you with their deception with which they have deceived you in the matter of Peor and in the matter of Cozbi, the daughter of the prince of Midian, their sister, who was slain on the day of the plague in the matter of Peor.
Now after the plague Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Eleazar the son of Aaron the priest, saying,

verse.text: Take the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sum of the whole assembly of the children of Israel, from [note]2[/note]twenty years old and upward, by their [note]2[/note]fathers' households, all who are able to go forth for military service in Israel.
verse.note: The renumbering of God's people in this chapter took place immediately after the purification by the plague on the fornicators and idolaters ([link]25:9[/link]). The first numbering had taken place in the wilderness of Sinai ([link]1:1-2[/link]); the renumbering took place in the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]63[/link]), i.e., at the entrance to the good land. The first numbering was for the formation of the army ([link]1:3[/link]); the renumbering was for the inheriting of the land, signifying the enjoyment of Christ, through fighting ([link]v. 53[/link]).
See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: So [note]1[/note]Moses and Eleazar the priest spoke with them in the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho, saying,
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

chapter.verse: [i]Take the sum of the people,[/i] from twenty years old and upward, as Jehovah commanded Moses. Now the children of Israel, who came forth out of the land of Egypt were:

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Reuben, the firstborn of Israel; the sons of Reuben: [i]of[/i] Hanoch, the family of the Hanochites; of Pallu, the family of the Palluites;

chapter.verse: Of Hezron, the family of the Hezronites; of Carmi, the family of the Carmites.
These are the families of the Reubenites, and those who were numbered of them were forty-three thousand seven hundred thirty.
And the sons of Pallu: Eliab.

verse.text: And the sons of Eliab: Nemuel and Dathan and Abiram. These are the [xref]a[/xref]Dathan and Abiram, who were [xref]b[/xref]called by the assembly, who contended against Moses and against Aaron in the company of Korah, when they contended against Jehovah;
[xref]a[/xref]And the earth opened its mouth and swallowed them up together with Korah, when that company died, when the fire consumed two hundred fifty men; and they became a [xref]b[/xref]sign.
But the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Korah did [note]1[/note]not die.
verse.note: See note [link]33[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 16[/link].

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Simeon according to their families: of Nemuel, the family of the Nemuelites; of Jamin, the family of the Jaminites; of Jachin, the family of the Jachinites;

chapter.verse: Of Zerah, the family of the Zerahites; of Shaul, the family of the Shaulites.
These are the families of the Simeonites, twenty-two thousand two hundred.

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Gad according to their families: of Zephon, the family of the Zephonites; of Haggi, the family of the Haggites; of Shuni, the family of the Shunites;

chapter.verse: Of Ozni, the family of the Oznites; of Eri, the family of the Erites;
Of Arod, the family of the Arodites; of Areli, the family of the Arelites.
These are the families of the sons of Gad according to those who were numbered of them, forty thousand five hundred.

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Judah: Er and Onan; but Er and Onan [xref]b[/xref]died in the land of Canaan.

chapter.verse: And the sons of Judah according to their families were: of Shelah, the family of the Shelanites; of Perez, the family of the Perezites; of Zerah, the family of the Zerahites.
And the sons of Perez were: of Hezron, the family of the Hezronites; of Hamul, the family of the Hamulites.
These are the families of Judah according to those who were numbered of them, seventy-six thousand five hundred.

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Issachar according to their families: [i]of[/i] Tola, the family of the Tolaites; of Puvah, the family of the Punites;

chapter.verse: Of Jashub, the family of the Jashubites; of Shimron, the family of the Shimronites.
These are the families of Issachar according to those who were numbered of them, sixty-four thousand three hundred.

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Zebulun according to their families: of Sered, the family of the Seredites; of Elon, the family of the Elonites; of Jahleel, the family of the Jahleelites.

chapter.verse: These are the families of the Zebulunites according to those who were numbered of them, sixty thousand five hundred.

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Joseph according to their families: Manasseh and Ephraim.
The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Manasseh: of Machir, the family of the Machirites; and Machir begat Gilead; of Gilead, the family of the Gileadites.

chapter.verse: These are the sons of Gilead: [i]of[/i] Iezer, the family of the Iezerites; of Helek, the family of the Helekites;
And [i]of[/i] Asriel, the family of the Asrielites; and [i]of[/i] Shechem, the family of the Shechemites;
And [i]of[/i] Shemida, the family of the Shemidaites; and [i]of[/i] Hepher, the family of the Hepherites.

verse.text: Now [xref]a[/xref]Zelophehad the son of Hepher had no sons, but daughters, and the names of the [note]1[/note]daughters of Zelophehad were Mahlah and Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
verse.note: The numbering of some of the daughters ([link]vv. 33[/link], [link]46[/link]) was for the inheriting of the land ([link]27:1-11[/link]).

chapter.verse: These are the families of Manasseh; and those who were numbered of them were fifty-two thousand seven hundred.

verse.text: These are the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Ephraim according to their families: of Shuthelah, the family of the Shuthelahites; of Becher, the family of the Becherites; of Tahan, the family of the Tahanites.

chapter.verse: And these are the sons of Shuthelah: of Eran, the family of the Eranites.
These are the families of the sons of Ephraim according to those who were numbered of them, thirty-two thousand five hundred. These are the sons of Joseph according to their families.

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Benjamin according to their families: of Bela, the family of the Belaites; of Ashbel, the family of the Ashbelites; of Ahiram, the family of the Ahiramites;

chapter.verse: Of Shephupham, the family of the Shuphamites; of Hupham, the family of the Huphamites.
And the sons of Bela were Ard and Naaman: [i]of Ard,[/i] the family of the Ardites; of Naaman, the family of the Naamites.
These are the sons of Benjamin according to their families; and those who were numbered of them were forty-five thousand six hundred.

verse.text: These are the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Dan according to their families: of Shuham, the family of the Shuhamites. These are the families of Dan according to their families.

chapter.verse: All the families of the Shuhamites, according to those who were numbered of them, were sixty-four thousand four hundred.

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Asher according to their families: of Imnah, the family of the Imnites; of Ishvi, the family of the Ishvites; of Beriah, the family of the Berites.

chapter.verse: From the sons of Beriah: of Heber, the family of the Heberites; of Malchiel, the family of the Malchielites.
And the name of the daughter of Asher was Serah.
These are the families of the sons of Asher according to those who were numbered of them, fifty-three thousand four hundred.

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Naphtali according to their families: of Jahzeel, the family of the Jahzeelites; of Guni, the family of the Gunites;

chapter.verse: Of Jezer, the family of the Jezerites; of Shillem, the family of the Shillemites.
These are the families of Naphtali according to their families; and those who were numbered of them were forty-five thousand four hundred.

verse.text: These are those who were numbered of the children of Israel, [xref]a[/xref]six hundred one thousand seven hundred thirty.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: To these the land shall be [xref]a[/xref]divided for an inheritance according to the number of names.

You shall [xref]a[/xref]increase the larger [i]group's[/i] inheritance, and you shall reduce the smaller [i]group's[/i] inheritance. Each shall be given their inheritance according to those who were numbered of them.
But the land shall be apportioned by [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lot; they shall inherit [i]it[/i] according to the names of the tribes of their fathers.
verse.note: The distributing of the land by lot ([link]vv. 55-56[/link]) was according to the blessing under God's sovereignty (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Josh. 14[/link]), whereas the distributing of the land according to the number of people ([link]vv. 53-54[/link]) was a matter of human responsibility. Therefore, the distribution of the land depended both on human responsibility and on divine sovereignty.

chapter.verse: According to the lot their inheritance shall be apportioned among the larger and the smaller [i]groups.[/i]

verse.text: And these are those who were numbered of the [xref]a[/xref]Levites according to their families: of Gershon, the family of the Gershonites; of Kohath, the family of the Kohathites; of Merari, the family of the Merarites.

These are the families of Levi: the family of the Libnites, the family of the Hebronites, the family of the Mahlites, the family of the Mushites, the family of the Korahites. And [xref]a[/xref]Kohath begot Amram.
And the name of Amram's wife was [xref]a[/xref]Jochebed, the daughter of Levi, who was born to Levi in Egypt; and she bore to Amram Aaron and Moses and their [xref]b[/xref]sister Miriam.
And to Aaron were born [xref]a[/xref]Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Nadab and Abihu died when they offered strange fire before Jehovah.
verse.note: See [link]Lev. 10:1-2[/link] and notes.

verse.text: And those who were numbered of them were [xref]a[/xref]twenty-three thousand, every male from a month old and upward, for they were [xref]b[/xref]not numbered among the children of Israel, because [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]no inheritance was given to them among the children of Israel.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 18[/link].

chapter.verse: These are those who were numbered by Moses and Eleazar the priest, who numbered the children of Israel in the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho.

verse.text: But among these there was [note]1[/note]not one of those [xref]a[/xref]numbered by Moses and Aaron the priest, who had numbered the children of Israel in the wilderness of Sinai.
verse.note: With the exception of Caleb and Joshua ([link]v. 65[/link]), all those in the first numbering, including Moses and Aaron, were not included in the renumbering.

verse.text: For Jehovah had said of them, They shall surely die in the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness. And not one of them was left, except [xref]b[/xref]Caleb the son of Jephunneh and Joshua the son of Nun.

Then the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]daughters of Zelophehad the son of Hepher, the son of Gilead, the son of Machir, the son of Manasseh, of the [note]2[/note]families of Manasseh the son of Joseph came near. And these are the names of his daughters: Mahlah, Noah, and Hoglah, and Milcah and Tirzah.
verse.note: The five daughters of Zelophehad typify all the believers in Christ, who are females, weaker ones ([link]1 Pet. 3:7[/link]), in the sight of God. Hence, their request ([link]v. 4[/link]) is for us all. In order to keep their father's name and his inheritance within their tribe, the daughters of Zelophehad took the way of fellowship by contacting their stronger kinsmen ([link]v. 4[/link]). The same principle applies to the keeping of the enjoyment of Christ by the weaker believers in the church life.

In the Bible inheritance is determined according to genealogy, according to the source of life and the fellowship of life. The fact that the daughters of Zelophehad were of one of the families of Manasseh the son of Joseph indicates that they were in the life and the fellowship of life of the proper origin. This indicates that in order to inherit Christ as our good land, we must have the proper origin of life; i.e., we must be born of God to be His children ([link]John 1:12-13[/link]).[br][br]The father's family signifies the church ([link]Eph. 2:19[/link]). If we would enjoy Christ as our inheritance, participating in His riches, we must also have the church life. If we give up the church life with the fellowship of life, we will spontaneously lose our right to inherit the enjoyment of Christ.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And they stood before Moses and before Eleazar the priest and before the leaders and the whole assembly at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, saying,

Our father died in the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness, and he was not among the company of those who gathered themselves together against Jehovah in the company of [xref]b[/xref]Korah; but he died in his own sin, and he had no sons.
Why should our father's name be taken away from among his family because he had no son? Give us a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]possession among our father's brothers.
verse.note: In typology, the desire of the daughters of Zelophehad to possess their father's inheritance signifies the desire to inherit God's grace, i.e., to inherit Christ as the grace given to us by God ([link]Col. 1:12[/link]; [link]John 1:17[/link]). Such a regard for the divine inheritance is pleasing to God.

chapter.verse: And Moses brought their case before Jehovah.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: The daughters of Zelophehad speak rightly. You shall surely give them the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]possession of an inheritance among their father's brothers; and you shall cause the [xref]b[/xref]inheritance of their father to pass to them.
verse.note: The five daughters were given an inheritance among their father's brothers, provided that they did not marry outside their tribe ([link]36:2-3[/link], [link]6-7[/link]). Likewise, in Christ we have the right to inherit the divine things. However, we should not marry outside our "tribe," i.e., outside Christ and the church (cf. [link]2 Cor. 6:14[/link]).

verse.text: And you shall speak to the children of Israel, saying, [note]1[/note]If a man dies and has no son, then you shall cause his inheritance to pass to his daughter.
verse.note: In typology, the good land signifies Christ (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link]), and the inheritance of the good land signifies our enjoyment of Christ. The statute of judgment in [link]vv. 8-11[/link] typifies that the possession of the enjoyment of Christ is based on the relationship in life. In order to execute our right to enjoy Christ, we must be in the church, signified by the father's household ([link]26:2[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:19[/link]), with the relationship in life, the fellowship of life, among the saints ([link]1 John 1:1-3[/link]).

chapter.verse: And if he does not have a daughter, then you shall give his inheritance to his brothers.
And if he has no brothers, then you shall give his inheritance to his father's brothers.

verse.text: And if his father has no brothers, then you shall give his inheritance to his [xref]a[/xref]relative nearest to him among his family, and he shall possess it. And it shall be a statute of judgment for the children of Israel, as Jehovah commanded Moses.
[xref]a[/xref]And Jehovah said to Moses, Go up to this mountain of the Abarim and see the land which I have given to the children of Israel.
And when you have seen it, you also shall be [xref]a[/xref]gathered to your people, just as Aaron your brother was [xref]b[/xref]gathered,

Because you [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rebelled against My word in the wilderness of Zin, in the strife of the assembly, [i]and failed[/i] to [note]1[/note]sanctify Me at the waters before their eyes. (These are the waters of [note]2[/note]Meribah-kadesh, in the wilderness of Zin.)
verse.note: See notes [link book="Num." chapter="20"]10[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 20[/link]. Although Moses could not enter into the good land because of his failure ([link]Deut. 3:23-27[/link]), he will nevertheless be in the millennial kingdom ([link]Matt. 16:28-17:4[/link]).
Meaning [i]the strife of Kadesh.[/i]

chapter.verse: And Moses spoke to Jehovah, saying,

verse.text: Let Jehovah, the [xref]a[/xref]God of the [note]1[/note]spirits of all flesh, appoint a man over the assembly,
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

verse.text: Who will go out before them and who will come in before them, and who will lead them [xref]a[/xref]out and who will bring them in; so that the assembly of Jehovah will not be like [xref]b[/xref]sheep which have no [note]1[/note]shepherd.
verse.note: Moses was concerned not for himself but for God's people, realizing that after his death they would need a shepherd.
verse.xref: Deut. 31:2; Josh. 14:11; 1 Sam. 18:13; 1 Kings 3:7; 2 Chron. 1:10; Acts 1:21

verse.text: And Jehovah said to Moses, Take [xref]a[/xref]Joshua the son of Nun, a man in whom is the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit, and [xref]c[/xref]lay your hand upon him;

chapter.verse: And set him before Eleazar the priest and before the whole assembly, and give him a charge in their sight.
And you shall put some of your honor upon him, so that the whole assembly of the children of Israel may obey him.

verse.text: And he shall stand before Eleazar the priest, and he shall inquire for him by the judgment of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Urim before Jehovah. At his word shall they go out and at his word they shall come in, both he and all the children of Israel with him, even the whole assembly.
verse.note: When God brought His people into the wilderness, He spoke to them through Moses ([link]12:6-8a[/link]); but Joshua, Moses' successor, was to receive guidance not from God by His direct speaking but by the Urim and the Thummim on the breastplate worn by Eleazar the priest (see notes [link book="Exo." chapter="28"]30[sup]1[/sup][/link] through [link]30[sup]3[/sup] in Exo. 28[/link]). God's government among His people was a matter not of autocracy or democracy but of theocracy, carried out through the coordination of the high priest, who received God's instructions, and the leader, who executed these instructions. After Moses, throughout the generations in the Old Testament the divine government depended on the two persons of the high priest and the leader, the only exception being the time when David served as both the leader and the priest wearing the ephod ([link]1 Sam. 23:9[/link]; [link]30:7[/link]). When the children of Israel came back from captivity, a later Joshua was the high priest, and Zerubbabel, a royal descendant, was the leader ([link]Hag. 1:1[/link]). See note [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 16[/link].[br][br]At the end of this chapter the children of Israel had become a new people formed into a new army with a new theocracy.

chapter.verse: And Moses did as Jehovah commanded him, and he took Joshua and set him before Eleazar the priest and before the whole assembly.

verse.text: And he [note]1[/note]laid his hands upon him and gave him a charge just as Jehovah had spoken through Moses.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]4[/sup] in 1 Tim. 4[/link].

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Command the children of Israel and say to them, My offering, My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]food for My offerings by fire of a [xref]b[/xref]satisfying fragrance to Me, you shall be careful to present to Me at its appointed time.
verse.note: God's food consists of the offerings offered to Him by His people, which typify different aspects of Christ (see notes in [link]Lev. 1-7[/link]), who is the reality of and replacement for all the Old Testament offerings ([link]Heb. 10:5-9[/link]). Christ is God's daily food ([link]vv. 3-8[/link]), weekly food ([link]v. 9[/link]), monthly food ([link]vv. 11-15[/link]), and yearly food ([link]28:16-29:38[/link]). Thus, God's food is related to the daily, weekly, monthly, and yearly life of His people.

verse.text: And you shall say to them, [xref]a[/xref]This is the offering by fire which you shall present to Jehovah: two male lambs a year old without blemish each day as a continual burnt offering.
One lamb you shall offer in the morning, and the other lamb you shall offer [note]1[/note]at twilight;
verse.note: Lit., between the two evenings.

verse.text: Also a tenth of an ephah of fine flour for a [note]1[/note]meal offering, mingled with the fourth of a hin of beaten oil.
verse.note: Although the burnt offering was to be wholly and absolutely burned for God's satisfaction ([link]Lev. 1:9[/link], [link]13[/link]), it was accompanied by a meal offering, a large portion of which was for the priests ([link]Lev. 2:3[/link], [link]10[/link]). This indicates that when we serve God, offering Christ to Him as His food, God shares a portion of His food with us. First, we enjoy Christ as the One given to us by God. Having experienced Christ, we present Him to God as His food, and then God shares with us a portion of the Christ we have offered to Him. In this way we enjoy the all-inclusive Christ in mutuality with God.

chapter.verse: It is a continual burnt offering, which was set up on Mount Sinai for a satisfying fragrance, an offering by fire to Jehovah.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And its [note]1[/note]drink offering shall be the fourth of a hin for the one lamb; in the sanctuary you shall pour out a drink offering of strong drink to Jehovah.
verse.note: See note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in Lev. 23[/link].

chapter.verse: And the other lamb you shall offer at twilight; you shall offer [i]it[/i] with the meal offering and its drink offering as in the morning, an offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.
And on the Sabbath day two male lambs a year old without blemish, and two-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour for a meal offering, mingled with oil, and its drink offering —
This is the burnt offering of every Sabbath, besides the continual burnt offering and its drink offering.

verse.text: And at the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]beginnings of your months [xref]b[/xref]you shall present a burnt offering to Jehovah: two bulls of the herd and one ram, seven male lambs a year old without blemish;
verse.note: The monthly new moon signifies a new beginning in Christ with light in the darkness ([link]Col. 2:16-17[/link]).

chapter.verse: And three-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour for a meal offering, mingled with oil, for each bull; and two-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour for a meal offering, mingled with oil, for the one ram;
And a tenth [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour mingled with oil for a meal offering for each lamb for a burnt offering, a satisfying fragrance, an offering by fire to Jehovah.

verse.text: And their [xref]a[/xref]drink offerings shall be half a hin of wine for a bull, and a third of a hin for the ram, and a fourth of a hin for a lamb. This is the burnt offering of each month throughout the months of the year.
Also one male goat for a [note]1[/note]sin offering to Jehovah shall be offered in addition to the continual burnt offering and its drink offering.
verse.note: Although God has nothing to do with sin, the serving ones were sinful and needed redemption in order to be qualified to serve God. Hence, the monthly burnt offering had to include a male goat for a sin offering.

verse.text: And in the [xref]a[/xref]first month on the fourteenth day of the month shall be Jehovah's [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Passover.
verse.note: For the annual feasts, see notes in [link]Lev. 23[/link].

verse.text: And on the fifteenth day of this month shall be a feast; seven days [xref]a[/xref]unleavened bread shall be eaten.
[xref]a[/xref]On the first day there shall be a holy convocation; you shall do no work of labor;

chapter.verse: But you shall present an offering by fire, a burnt offering to Jehovah: two bulls of the herd and one ram and seven male lambs a year old; they shall be without blemish for you;
And you shall offer their meal offering of fine flour mingled with oil: three-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] for a bull and two-tenths for a ram;
You shall offer one-tenth for each lamb of the seven lambs;
And one male goat as a sin offering, to make expiation for you.
You shall offer these besides the burnt offering of the morning, which is for a continual burnt offering.

In this way you shall offer daily, for seven days, the food of the offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah; it shall be offered besides the continual burnt offering and its drink offering.

verse.text: And on the [xref]a[/xref]seventh day you shall have a holy convocation; you shall do no work of labor.

Also in the day of the [xref]a[/xref]firstfruits, when you present a new meal offering to Jehovah in your [xref]b[/xref][i]Feast of[/i] Weeks, you shall have a holy convocation; you shall do no work of labor;

chapter.verse: But you shall present a burnt offering for a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah: two bulls of the herd, one ram, seven male lambs a year old;
And their meal offering of fine flour mingled with oil: three-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] for each bull, two-tenths for one ram,
One-tenth for each lamb of the seven lambs;
And one male goat, to make expiation for you.
Besides the continual burnt offering and its meal offering, you shall offer them (they shall be without blemish for you) and their drink offerings.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Now in the seventh month, on the first day of the month, you shall have a holy convocation; you shall do no work of labor. It is a day of blowing [i]of trumpets[/i] for you.

chapter.verse: And you shall offer a burnt offering for a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah: one bull of the herd, one ram, seven male lambs a year old without blemish;
And their meal offering of fine flour mingled with oil: three-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] for the bull, two-tenths for the ram,
And one-tenth for each lamb of the seven lambs;
And one male goat as a sin offering, to make expiation for you;

Besides the burnt offering of the new moon and its meal offering, and the continual burnt offering and its meal offering, and their drink offerings, according to their ordinance, for a satisfying fragrance, an offering by fire to Jehovah.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And on the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]tenth day of this seventh month you shall have a holy convocation, and you shall afflict your souls; you shall not do any work.
verse.note: This was the Day of Expiation ([link]Lev. 23:27[/link]).

chapter.verse: And you shall present a burnt offering to Jehovah [i]for[/i] a satisfying fragrance: one bull of the herd, one ram, seven male lambs a year old; they shall be without blemish for you;
And their meal offering of fine flour mingled with oil: three-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] for the bull, two-tenths for the one ram,
One-tenth for each lamb of the seven lambs;
One male goat as a sin offering; besides the sin offering of expiation and the continual burnt offering and its meal offering, and their drink offerings.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And on the fifteenth day of the seventh month you shall have a holy convocation; you shall do no work of labor, and you shall hold a feast to Jehovah seven days.

chapter.verse: And you shall present a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah: thirteen bulls of the herd, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old; they shall be without blemish;
And their meal offering of fine flour mingled with oil: three-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] for each bull of the thirteen bulls, two-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] for each ram of the two rams,
And one-tenth [i]of an ephah[/i] for each lamb of the fourteen lambs;
And one male goat for a sin offering; besides the continual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.
And on the second day: twelve bulls of the herd, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old without blemish;
And their meal offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, by their number according to the ordinance;
And one male goat for a sin offering; besides the continual burnt offering and its meal offering, and their drink offerings.
And on the third day: eleven bulls, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old without blemish;
And their meal offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, by their number according to the ordinance;
And one male goat for a sin offering; besides the continual burnt offering and its meal offering and its drink offering.
And on the fourth day: ten bulls, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old without blemish;
Their meal offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, by their number according to the ordinance;
And one male goat for a sin offering; besides the continual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.
And on the fifth day: nine bulls, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old without blemish;
