And their meal offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, by their number according to the ordinance;
And one male goat for a sin offering; besides the continual burnt offering and its meal offering and its drink offering.
And on the sixth day: eight bulls, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old without blemish;
And their meal offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, by their number according to the ordinance;
And one male goat for a sin offering; besides the continual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offerings.
And on the seventh day: seven bulls, two rams, fourteen male lambs a year old without blemish;
And their meal offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, by their number according to the ordinance;
And one male goat for a sin offering; besides the continual burnt offering, its meal offering, and its drink offering.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]On the eighth day you shall have a solemn assembly; you shall do no work of labor,

chapter.verse: But you shall present a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah: one bull, one ram, seven male lambs a year old without blemish;
Their meal offering and their drink offerings for the bull, for the ram, and for the lambs by their number according to the ordinance;
And one male goat for a sin offering; besides the continual burnt offering and its meal offering and its drink offering.

verse.text: These you shall offer to Jehovah in your appointed [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]feasts, besides your vows and your freewill offerings, for your burnt offerings and for your meal offerings and for your drink offerings and for your peace offerings.
verse.note: According to their dispensational fulfillment, the seven annual feasts are related to the enjoyment of Christ by God's people for the fulfillment of God's eternal economy (see note [link]44[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 23[/link]). The more God's people enjoy Christ and experience Christ, the more they fulfill God's economy, and the more they are able to offer Christ to God as food. Thus, Christ is God's food in the way of fulfilling God's eternal economy. In [link]Num. 28-29[/link] there are three sections: the section pertaining to the daily life of God's people (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 28[/link]), the section pertaining to the church (from the Feast of Passover to the Feast of Pentecost, i.e., Weeks), and the section pertaining to the future of Israel (from the Feast of the Blowing of Trumpets to the Feast of Tabernacles). Each section is for the fulfillment of God's eternal economy. Because Christ is everything for the fulfillment of God's economy, in each section He is God's food, God's satisfaction, served to God by His people and enjoyed with God by them. For eternity Christ will be God's satisfaction, and for eternity we will enjoy the Christ who satisfies God.

chapter.verse: And Moses spoke to the children of Israel according to all that Jehovah had commanded Moses.
And Moses spoke to the heads of the tribes of the children of Israel, saying, This is what Jehovah has commanded:

verse.text: When a man vows a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]vow to Jehovah or [xref]b[/xref]swears an oath to bind himself by pledge, he shall [xref]c[/xref]not break his word; he shall do according to all that proceeds out of his mouth.
verse.note: It is our duty, our responsibility, to present the offerings to God ([link]chs. 28-29[/link]), whereas vows are voluntary. If we simply fulfill God's requirements, we have not yet come up to the highest standard. In addition to carrying out our duty and responsibility to fulfill God's requirements, God wants us to make a vow to Him, volunteering ourselves in a definite and particular way ([link]Lev. 27[/link]; [link]Num. 6[/link]). The higher our vow is, the more the Lord will use us to fulfill His economy.

verse.text: But when a [note]1[/note]woman vows a vow to Jehovah or binds [i]herself[/i] by pledge in her [note]1[/note]father's house in her youth,
verse.note: Here the woman signifies a believer, and the father signifies God the Father. In the sight of God, all believers are females ([link]2 Cor. 11:2[/link]). The final decision concerning any vow we make to God will be decided by the Father ([link]vv. 3-5[/link]).

chapter.verse: And her father hears of her vow or her pledge by which she has bound herself, and her father is silent with respect to her; then all her vows will stand, and any pledge by which she has bound herself will stand.
But if her father disallows her on the day he hears, none of her vows or of her pledges by which she has bound herself will stand; and Jehovah will forgive her because her father disallowed her.

verse.text: And if she gets married, while her [xref]a[/xref]vows are upon her or the rash utterance of her lips by which she has bound herself,
And her [note]1[/note]husband hears [i]of it[/i] and is silent with respect to her on the day he hears it, then her vows will stand and her pledges by which she has bound herself will stand.
verse.note: The husband here signifies Christ the Lord ([link]Rom. 7:2-4[/link]). As believers, we all have God as our Father and Christ as our Lord. As females who are in the house of our Father and who have Christ as our Husband, we do not have the right to make the final decision concerning our vows. The final decision should be made either by God the Father or by Christ the Lord. This indicates that in relation to God the Father and Christ the Lord, the believers have lost their rights. Neither before God the Father nor before Christ the Lord do we have any rights (cf. [link]Rom. 1:1[/link] and note 2, par. 1).

chapter.verse: But if, on the day her husband hears [i]of it,[/i] he disallows her, then he makes void her vow which is upon her and the rash utterance of her lips by which she has bound herself; and Jehovah will forgive her.
But the vow of a widow or of a divorced woman, everything by which she has bound herself, will stand against her.
And if she vowed in her husband's house or bound herself by a pledge with an oath,
And her husband heard [i]of it[/i] and was silent with respect to her and did not disallow her, then all her vows will stand and any pledge by which she has bound herself will stand.

But if her husband made them null and void on the day he heard of it, then whatever proceeded out of her lips concerning her vows or concerning the pledging of herself will not stand; her husband has made them void, and Jehovah will forgive her.
As for every vow and every binding oath to afflict herself, her husband may establish it or her husband may make it void.

But if her husband is completely silent with respect to her from day to day, then he establishes all her vows or all her pledges which are upon her; he has established them because he was silent with respect to her on the day he heard it.
But if he makes them null and void [i]some time[/i] after he has heard of it, then he shall bear her iniquity.
These are the statutes which Jehovah commanded Moses, between a man and his wife, [i]and[/i] between a father and his daughter [i]while[/i] in her youth in her father's house.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Thoroughly avenge the children of Israel on the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Midianites; afterward you will be [xref]b[/xref]gathered to your people.
verse.note: In typology, the Midianites signify the filthiness of the lust of the flesh, which is related to the devil Satan and the world ([link]1 John 2:16a[/link]; [link]5:19[/link]). The Midianites were descendants of Abraham, born of his second wife, Keturah. Hence, by nature they were close to the Israelites in the flesh ([link]Gen. 25:1-2[/link]). The Midianites were united with the Moabites, the descendants of Lot born through incest in the lust of the flesh ([link]Num. 22:3-4[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]Gen. 19:30-38[/link]). Furthermore, the Midianites were one with the Ishmaelites, the descendants of Abraham by the flesh, who sold Joseph into Egypt ([link]Gen. 37:27-28[/link], [link]36[/link]). The Midianites were also connected with the Amalekites, the descendants of Esau ([link]Judg. 6:3[/link], [link]33[/link]; [link]Gen. 36:12[/link]). Finally, the Midianites produced Balaam, who ensnared the children of Israel in fornication and idolatry ([link]Num. 22:7[/link]; [link]31:16[/link]).[br][br]By ensnaring the sons of Israel in fornication and idolatry, the Midianites offended Israel to the uttermost, with the result that more than twenty thousand lives were lost. God would not forget that, and He charged Moses to avenge Israel on the Midianites.

chapter.verse: And Moses spoke to the people, saying, Arm men from among you for the war, that they may come upon Midian to execute Jehovah's vengeance on Midian.
A thousand from each tribe, of all the tribes of Israel, you shall send to the war.
So out of the thousands of Israel, a thousand for each tribe were committed, twelve thousand armed for war.

verse.text: And Moses sent them, a thousand for each tribe, to the war, and Phinehas the son of Eleazar the priest with them, to the war, with the [xref]a[/xref]vessels of the sanctuary and the trumpets for the alarm in his hand.
And they warred against Midian, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses; and they [xref]a[/xref]killed every male.

[xref]a[/xref]And they killed the kings of Midian in addition to [i]the others[/i] slain among them: Evi and Rekem and Zur and Hur and Reba, the five kings of Midian; also [xref]b[/xref]Balaam the son of Beor they slew with the sword.

chapter.verse: And the children of Israel took captive the women of Midian and their little ones, and all their cattle and all their livestock and all their goods they plundered.
And all their cities in which they had settled and all their encampments, they burned with fire.
And they took all the spoil and all the booty, both of man and of beast.

verse.text: And they brought the captives and the [xref]a[/xref]booty and the spoil to Moses and to Eleazar the priest and to the assembly of the children of Israel, to the camp in the plains of Moab, which was beside the Jordan at Jericho.

chapter.verse: And Moses and Eleazar the priest and all the leaders of the assembly went out to meet them outside the camp.

verse.text: And Moses became angry with the officers of the company, the captains of thousands and the captains of hundreds, who came from [xref]a[/xref]service in the war.
And Moses said to them, Have you [xref]a[/xref]kept all the women alive?

It was [xref]a[/xref]these who caused the children of Israel, through the counsel of [xref]b[/xref]Balaam, to act unfaithfully against Jehovah in the matter of Peor, so that the [xref]c[/xref]plague came upon the assembly of Jehovah.

chapter.verse: Now therefore kill every male among the little ones, and kill every woman who has known a man by lying with him.
But all the little ones among the women, who have not known a male by lying with him, keep alive for yourselves.

verse.text: And you, encamp outside the camp seven days, everyone who has killed any person and everyone who has touched any slain; [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]purify yourselves on the [note]2[/note]third day and on the [note]2[/note]seventh day, you and your captives.
verse.note: All the matters in [link]vv. 13-24[/link] concerning the purging and purifying of the captives and the spoil indicate that everything related to God must be clean, having been purged, purified, or washed.
See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 19[/link].

chapter.verse: And you shall purify for yourselves every garment and every article of skin and everything made of goats' [i]hair[/i] and every article of wood.
And Eleazar the priest said to the men of war who had gone to the battle, This is the statute of the law which Jehovah has commanded Moses:
Only the gold and the silver, the bronze, the iron, the tin, and the lead,

verse.text: Everything that can go into the fire, you shall pass through the [xref]a[/xref]fire, and it will become clean; but it shall be purified with the [xref]b[/xref]water for impurity; and everything that cannot go into the fire you shall pass through the water.
And you shall [xref]a[/xref]wash your [note]1[/note]clothes on the seventh day, and you shall be clean; and afterward you may come into the camp.
verse.note: Our clothing signifies our behavior ([link]Isa. 64:6[/link]). The washing of our clothes signifies the washing of our behavior and of all that we are.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
You and Eleazar the priest and the heads of the fathers' [i]households[/i] of the assembly, take the sum of the booty that was captured, both of man and of beast,

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]halve the booty between those skilled in war who went out to battle and the whole assembly.
And levy a tribute to Jehovah from the men of war who went out to battle: [xref]a[/xref]one living thing out of five hundred, of the persons and of the cattle and of the donkeys and of the flock;
Take it from their half and give it to [note]1[/note]Eleazar the priest, for [xref]a[/xref]Jehovah's heave offering.
verse.note: Because Eleazar the priest was one with Jehovah, whatever was given to Jehovah as a tribute by the fighters went to Eleazar the priest. What was given to Eleazar became a heave offering. This signifies that the tribute was put into ascension for a memorial before Jehovah and that this eventually became the high priest's portion.

chapter.verse: And of the children of Israel's half, you shall take one seized out of fifty, of the persons, of the cattle, of the donkeys, and of the flocks, from all the beasts, and give them to the Levites, who keep the charge of the tabernacle of Jehovah.

verse.text: And Moses and Eleazar the priest did just as Jehovah [note]1[/note]commanded Moses.
verse.note: This chapter portrays a beautiful picture of one accord among God's people. Everything was done according to Jehovah's commandment given through Moses, and none of the people expressed any opinion or made any proposal. The one accord was the factor that led to Israel's victory over the Midianites.

chapter.verse: Now the booty that was left from the spoil, which the men of war had taken, was six hundred seventy-five thousand sheep,
And seventy-two thousand cattle,
And sixty-one thousand donkeys,
And thirty-two thousand persons in all, the women who had not known lying with a male.
And the half which was the portion of those who went out to war was in number three hundred thirty-seven thousand five hundred sheep.
And Jehovah's tribute of the sheep was six hundred seventy-five.
And the cattle were thirty-six thousand, of which Jehovah's tribute was seventy-two.
And the donkeys were thirty thousand five hundred, of which Jehovah's tribute was sixty-one.
And the human beings were sixteen thousand, of whom Jehovah's tribute was thirty-two persons.
And Moses gave the tribute, Jehovah's heave offering, to Eleazar the priest, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
And of the children of Israel's half, which Moses had separated from the men who had gone to war,
That is, the assembly's half, was three hundred thirty-seven thousand five hundred sheep,
And thirty-six thousand cattle,
And thirty thousand five hundred donkeys,
And sixteen thousand persons —

Now Moses took from the children of Israel's half, one drawn out of every fifty, both of man and of beast, and gave them to the Levites, who kept the charge of the tabernacle of Jehovah, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
And the officers who were over the thousands of the army, the captains of thousands and the captains of hundreds, approached Moses.
And they said to Moses, Your servants have taken the sum of the men of war who are under our charge, and not a man is missing from us;

verse.text: And we have presented Jehovah's offering, what every man has obtained, articles of gold, armlets and bracelets, signet rings, earrings and pendants, to make [note]1[/note]expiation for our souls before Jehovah.
verse.note: The officers were sensitive and knowledgeable, realizing that there was something concerning them that was not right or fitting and that they needed to make expiation for themselves before God so that their situation with God could be appeased.

chapter.verse: And Moses and Eleazar the priest took the gold from them, all kinds of wrought articles.
And all the gold of the heave offering which they offered up to Jehovah, from the captains of thousands and from the captains of hundreds, was sixteen thousand seven hundred fifty shekels.
The men of war had taken booty, each for himself.

verse.text: So Moses and Eleazar the priest took the gold from the captains of thousands and of hundreds, and brought it into the Tent of Meeting as a [xref]a[/xref]memorial for the children of Israel before Jehovah.

[note]1[/note]Now the children of Reuben and the children of Gad had a very great abundance of livestock. And when they saw the land of Jazer and the land of Gilead, that the place was indeed a place for livestock,
verse.note: The prearrangement of the distribution of the good land shown in the last five chapters of this book typifies the sharing of the enjoyment of the rich Christ. At this point God's chosen and redeemed people, after being formed into a priestly army to fight for God and to journey with God, were prepared by God to possess the good land, a type of the all-inclusive Christ as the portion allotted by God to the believers in Christ (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link]).

chapter.verse: The children of Gad and the children of Reuben came and spoke to Moses and to Eleazar the priest and to the leaders of the assembly, saying,
Ataroth and Dibon and Jazer and Nimrah and Heshbon and Elealeh and Sebam and Nebo and Beon,

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]land which Jehovah struck before the assembly of Israel, is a land for livestock, and your servants have livestock.
And they said, If we have found favor in your sight, let this [note]1[/note]land be given to your servants for a possession; do not make us [note]2[/note]cross over the Jordan.
verse.note: The request of the two tribes, Reuben and Gad, to receive what God had promised ([link]vv. 1-5[/link]) was not wrong; however, they were not right in wanting to receive this according to their choice as to what was the best. Eventually, their land was the first part of the land of Israel to be taken over by the Gentile invaders from the east ([link]1 Chron. 5:25-26[/link]). In spiritual matters it is much better not to act according to our choice but to leave matters in the hand of the Lord and let Him do according to His choice (cf. [link]Gen. 13:5-18[/link]).

The land requested by Reuben and Gad could be reached without crossing the river Jordan, which signifies the old man not being dealt with and buried (see notes on [link]Josh. 3:16-4:12[/link]). Only after our old man has been dealt with and buried ([link]Rom. 6:3-6[/link]) are we in a position to possess the all-inclusive Christ as the good land for our enjoyment.

chapter.verse: And Moses said to the children of Gad and to the children of Reuben, Shall your brothers go to war, while you stay here?
Now why would you discourage the heart of the children of Israel from crossing over into the land which Jehovah has given them?

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Your fathers did this when I sent them from Kadesh-barnea to see the land.

chapter.verse: When they went up to the valley of Eshcol and saw the land, they discouraged the heart of the children of Israel from going into the land which Jehovah had given them.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And Jehovah's anger was kindled in that day, and He swore, saying,

chapter.verse: Surely none of the men who came up out of Egypt, from twenty years old and upward, shall see the land which I swore [i]to give[/i] to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, because they have not fully followed Me;

verse.text: Except Caleb the son of Jephunneh the Kenizzite and Joshua the son of Nun, because they have [xref]a[/xref]fully followed Jehovah.

And Jehovah's anger was kindled against Israel, and He made them wander in the wilderness [xref]a[/xref]forty years, until the whole generation which had done evil in the sight of Jehovah was consumed.

chapter.verse: And now you have risen up in your fathers' place, a brood of sinful men, to further increase the burning anger of Jehovah toward Israel.
For if you turn away from following Him, He will yet again leave them in the wilderness; and you will destroy this entire people.
And they came near to him and said, We will build sheepfolds here for our livestock and cities for our little ones;

verse.text: But we ourselves will be [xref]a[/xref]armed [i]and[/i] ready to go before the children of Israel until we have brought them to their place, while our little ones dwell in the fortified cities because of the inhabitants of the land.

chapter.verse: We will not return to our houses until each one of the children of Israel has inherited his inheritance.

verse.text: For we will not inherit with them on the other side of the Jordan and further on, because our inheritance has come to us on this side of the Jordan [xref]a[/xref]eastward.

chapter.verse: And Moses said to them, If you will do this thing, if you will arm yourselves before Jehovah for battle,

verse.text: And all of your armed men will cross over the Jordan before Jehovah until He has [xref]a[/xref]driven out His enemies from before Him,

And the land is subdued before Jehovah, then afterward you shall return and be free of [note]1[/note]obligation toward Jehovah and toward Israel; and this land shall be yours for a possession before Jehovah.
verse.note: The obligation here was due to the fact that Reuben and Gad had their own choice regarding their portion of the land ([link]vv. 1-5[/link]). In serving the Lord, we need to learn to give up our own choice in order to avoid obligating ourselves to God and to His people.

verse.text: But if you will not do so, then you have sinned against Jehovah; and know that your [xref]a[/xref]sin will find you out.

chapter.verse: Build for yourselves cities for your little ones and folds for your sheep, and do what has proceeded out of your mouth.
And the children of Gad and the children of Reuben spoke to Moses, saying, Your servants will do as my lord commands.
Our little ones, our wives, our livestock, and all our cattle will be there in the cities of Gilead;
But your servants will cross over, everyone who is armed for war before Jehovah for battle, as my lord says.
So Moses gave command concerning them to Eleazar the priest and to Joshua the son of Nun and to the heads of the fathers' [i]houses[/i] of the tribes of the children of Israel.

And Moses said to them, If the children of Gad and the children of Reuben cross over the Jordan with you, everyone who is armed for battle before Jehovah, and the land is subdued before you, then you shall give them the land of Gilead as a possession.
But if they do not cross over armed with you, they shall have possessions among you in the land of Canaan.
And the children of Gad and the children of Reuben answered, saying, As Jehovah has said to your servants, so will we do.
We will cross over armed before Jehovah into the land of Canaan, and the possession of our inheritance [i]will remain[/i] with us beyond the Jordan.

verse.text: And Moses gave to them, to the children of Gad and to the children of [xref]a[/xref]Reuben and to the half-tribe of Manasseh the son of Joseph, the kingdom of Sihon the king of the Amorites and the kingdom of Og the king of Bashan, the land according to its cities with [i]their[/i] territories, the cities of the surrounding land.

chapter.verse: And the children of Gad built Dibon and Ataroth and Aroer
And Atroth-shophan and Jazer and Jogbehah
And Beth-nimrah and Beth-haran as fortified cities, and folds for sheep.
And the children of Reuben built Heshbon and Elealeh and Kiriathaim
And Nebo and Baal-meon — [i]their[/i] names being changed — and Sibmah, and they gave [i]other[/i] names to the cities which they built.
And the children of Machir the son of Manasseh went to Gilead and took it and dispossessed the Amorites who were in it.

verse.text: And Moses gave [xref]a[/xref]Gilead to Machir the son of Manasseh, and he dwelt in it.
And [xref]a[/xref]Jair the son of Manasseh went and took its villages and called them [note]1[/note]Havvoth-jair.
verse.note: Meaning [i]the village of Jair.[/i]

chapter.verse: And Nobah went and took Kenath and its towns, and called it Nobah after his own name.

verse.text: These are the [note]1[/note]journeys of the children of Israel, when they went forth out of the land of Egypt by their companies under the direction of Moses and Aaron.
verse.note: The forty-two stations in this chapter typify forty-two generations, from Abraham to Christ ([link]Matt. 1:17[/link] and note 1, par. 3). The goal of the forty-two stations was the good land, and the goal of the forty-two generations was Christ. The correspondence here indicates that God's intention is to bring all His people into the good land, which typifies Christ (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link]), as the goal. In the Old Testament God's people journeyed and then arrived at the goal, but in the New Testament we, the believers, having been baptized into Christ ([link]Rom. 6:3[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]), are already in the goal ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; [link]Col. 2:6[/link] and note).

chapter.verse: And Moses wrote down the places that they went out from for their journeys according to the commandment of Jehovah; and these are their journeys according to the places they went out from.

verse.text: Now they journeyed from [xref]a[/xref]Rameses in the first month, on the fifteenth day of the first month. On the day after the passover the children of Israel went out [note]1[/note]boldly in the sight of all the Egyptians,
verse.note: Lit., with a high hand.

verse.text: While the Egyptians were burying those whom Jehovah had [xref]a[/xref]struck down among them, all their firstborn; on their [xref]b[/xref]gods Jehovah also executed judgments.
And the children of Israel journeyed from Rameses and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Succoth.
And they journeyed from Succoth and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Etham, which is at the edge of the wilderness.
And they journeyed from Etham and turned back to [xref]a[/xref]Pi-hahiroth, which faces Baal-zephon; and they encamped before Migdol.

And they journeyed from [note]1[/note]Pi-hahiroth and passed through the [xref]a[/xref]midst of the sea into the wilderness, and they went three days' journey in the wilderness of Etham and encamped at [xref]b[/xref]Marah.
verse.note: According to many MSS and some ancient versions; the Hebrew text reads, before Hahiroth.

verse.text: And they journeyed from Marah and came to [xref]a[/xref]Elim. And in Elim there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees, and they encamped there.

chapter.verse: And they journeyed from Elim and encamped by the Red Sea.

verse.text: And they journeyed from the Red Sea and encamped in the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness of Sin.

chapter.verse: And they journeyed from the wilderness of Sin and encamped at Dophkah.
And they journeyed from Dophkah and encamped at Alush.

verse.text: And they journeyed from Alush and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Rephidim, and there was no water for the people to drink there.
And they journeyed from Rephidim and encamped in the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness of Sinai.
And they journeyed from the wilderness of Sinai and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Kibroth-hattaavah.
And they journeyed from Kibroth-hattaavah and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Hazeroth.
And they journeyed from [xref]a[/xref]Hazeroth and encamped at Rithmah.

chapter.verse: And they journeyed from Rithmah and encamped at Rimmon-perez.
And they journeyed from Rimmon-perez and encamped at Libnah.
And they journeyed from Libnah and encamped at Rissah.
And they journeyed from Rissah and encamped at Kehelathah.
And they journeyed from Kehelathah and encamped at Mount Shepher.
And they journeyed from Mount Shepher and encamped at Haradah.
And they journeyed from Haradah and encamped at Makheloth.
And they journeyed from Makheloth and encamped at Tahath.
And they journeyed from Tahath and encamped at Terah.
And they journeyed from Terah and encamped at Mithkah.
And they journeyed from Mithkah and encamped at Hashmonah.

verse.text: And they journeyed from Hashmonah and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Moseroth.

chapter.verse: And they journeyed from Moseroth and encamped at Bene-jaakan.
And they journeyed from Bene-jaakan and encamped at Hor-haggidgad.

verse.text: And they journeyed from Hor-haggidgad and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Jotbathah.

chapter.verse: And they journeyed from Jotbathah and encamped at Abronah.

verse.text: And they journeyed from Abronah and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Ezion-geber.
And they journeyed from Ezion-geber and encamped in the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness of Zin, that is, Kadesh.
And they journeyed from Kadesh and encamped in [xref]a[/xref]Mount Hor at the edge of the land of Edom.

And Aaron the priest went up onto Mount Hor at the commandment of Jehovah and [xref]a[/xref]died there in the fortieth year after the children of Israel had come out of the land of Egypt, in the fifth month, on the first [i]day[/i] of the month.

chapter.verse: And Aaron was one hundred twenty-three years old when he died on Mount Hor.

verse.text: And the Canaanite, the [xref]a[/xref]king of Arad, who was dwelling in the Negev in the land of Canaan, heard of the coming of the children of Israel.
And they journeyed from [xref]a[/xref]Mount Hor and encamped at Zalmonah.

chapter.verse: And they journeyed from Zalmonah and encamped at Punon.

verse.text: And they journeyed from Punon and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Oboth.
And they journeyed from Oboth and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Iye-abarim on the border of Moab.
And they journeyed from Iyim and encamped at [xref]a[/xref]Dibon-gad.

chapter.verse: And they journeyed from Dibon-gad and encamped in Almon-diblathaim.

verse.text: And they journeyed from Almon-diblathaim and encamped in the mountains of the [xref]a[/xref]Abarim before Nebo.
And they journeyed from the mountains of the Abarim and encamped in the [xref]a[/xref]plains of Moab beside the Jordan at Jericho.
And they encamped beside the Jordan from Beth-jeshimoth as far as [xref]a[/xref]Abel-shittim in the plains of Moab.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses in the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them, [xref]a[/xref]When you pass over the Jordan into the land of Canaan,

You shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]drive out all the inhabitants of the land from before you, and you shall [xref]b[/xref]destroy all their figured [i]stones[/i] and destroy all their molten images and demolish all their high places;
verse.note: God has ordained Christ to be our portion for our enjoyment ([link]Col. 1:12[/link]), but we must cooperate with God's ordination by driving out everything within us that is other than God and Christ. We must destroy all the idols within us and not leave any ground within us for the worship of idols ([link]1 John 5:21[/link] and note 3, par. 1). Only then can we have the genuine enjoyment of Christ. See notes [link book="Exo." chapter="23"]23[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]31[sup]3[/sup] in Exo. 23[/link].

chapter.verse: And you shall take possession of the land and dwell in it, for to you I have given the land to possess it.

verse.text: And you shall inherit the land by [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lot according to your families; to the larger you shall give a larger inheritance, and to the smaller you shall give a smaller inheritance. Wherever the lot falls to anyone, that shall be his. You shall inherit according to the [note]1[/note]tribes of your fathers.
verse.note: The children of Israel were to inherit the land according to their tribes and by lot. See note [link]55[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 26[/link].

verse.text: But if you do not drive out the inhabitants of the land from before you, then those whom you let remain of them will become as splinters in your eyes and as [xref]a[/xref]thorns in your sides, and they will trouble you in the land in which you are dwelling.
And just as I thought to do to them, [xref]a[/xref]so will I do to you.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Command the children of Israel and say to them, When you come into the land of Canaan, this is the land that shall fall to you for an inheritance, the land of Canaan according to its [xref]a[/xref]borders.
[xref]a[/xref]And your southern section shall be from the wilderness of Zin along the side of Edom, and your southern border shall begin from the end of the [note]1[/note]Salt Sea on the east.
verse.note: I.e., the Dead Sea.

chapter.verse: And your border shall turn about south to the ascent of Akrabbim and pass on to Zin, and it shall go out to the south of Kadesh-barnea, even going out to Hazar-addar; then it shall pass on to Azmon.

verse.text: Then the border shall turn from Azmon to the [xref]a[/xref]brook of Egypt, and it shall go out to the sea.
And for the [xref]a[/xref]western border you shall have the [note]1[/note]Great Sea and its coast; this shall be your western border.
verse.note: I.e., the Mediterranean Sea.

chapter.verse: And this shall be your northern border: From the Great Sea you shall mark out a line for yourselves to Mount Hor.

verse.text: From Mount Hor you shall mark out a line to the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]entrance of Hamath; and the [xref]b[/xref]border shall go out to Zedad;
verse.note: Or, Lebo-hamath.

chapter.verse: And the border shall go out to Ziphron, and it shall go out to Hazar-enan. This shall be your northern border.

verse.text: And you shall mark out your [xref]a[/xref]eastern border from Hazar-enan to Shepham;
And the border shall go down from Shepham to Riblah on the east side of Ain; and the border shall go down and reach the [note]1[/note]slope on the east of the [note]2[/note]Sea of Chinnereth;
verse.note: Or, shoulder.
I.e., the Sea of Galilee.

verse.text: And the border shall go down to the [note]1[/note]Jordan, and it shall go out to the Salt Sea. This shall be your land according to its borders all around.
verse.note: The best part of the good land is surrounded by two seas — the Mediterranean Sea and the Dead Sea — and a river — the Jordan. These two seas and this river all signify the death of Christ. This indicates that the enjoyment of Christ is closely related to His death. The enjoyment of Christ must be in the sphere, the territory, of His death (cf. [link]Phil. 3:7-11[/link]).[br][br]That the good land rose up from the waters that bordered it on either side indicates that it is an elevated, uplifted land. This signifies the resurrected and ascended Christ, the heavenly Christ, who has entered into us in His resurrection ([link]John 20:22[/link]) and whose riches we enjoy in His ascension ([link]Eph. 2:6[/link]; [link]Col. 3:1-4[/link]).

verse.text: And Moses commanded the children of Israel, saying, This is the land which you shall inherit by [xref]a[/xref]lot, which Jehovah has commanded to give to the nine tribes and to the half-tribe.

For the tribe of the children of Reuben according to their fathers' households and the tribe of the children of Gad according to their fathers' households and the half-tribe of Manasseh have [xref]a[/xref]received their inheritance.
The two tribes and the half-tribe have received their inheritance [note]1[/note]beyond the Jordan at Jericho eastward, toward the sunrise.
verse.note: The land given to the two and a half tribes, the land which was according to their choice, could be reached without crossing the Jordan (see notes [link book="Num." chapter="32"]5[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]5[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 32[/link]) and thus was not actually a part of the land of Canaan (cf. [link]35:14[/link]). This indicates that, in type, it was outside the death of Christ. Our self-choice is likewise outside the death of Christ and therefore has nothing to do with the real enjoyment of the rich Christ. If we do not pass through the death of Christ, we cannot enter into the realm of His resurrection and ascension to enjoy Him as the heavenly, elevated One (cf. [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:10-11[/link]; [link]Col. 3:1-4[/link]).

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: These are the names of the men who shall divide the land to you for inheritance: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Eleazar the priest and [note]1[/note]Joshua the son of Nun.
verse.note: Eleazar and Joshua both typify Christ, as our Priest ([link]Heb. 4:14[/link]) and as our Leader ([link]Heb. 4:8[/link] and note 1).

chapter.verse: And you shall take one leader from each tribe to divide the land for inheritance.
And these are the names of the men: For the tribe of Judah, Caleb the son of Jephunneh.
And for the tribe of the children of Simeon, Shemuel the son of Ammihud.
For the tribe of Benjamin, Elidad the son of Chislon.
And for the tribe of the children of Dan, a leader, Bukki the son of Jogli.
For the children of Joseph: For the tribe of the children of Manasseh, a leader, Hanniel the son of Ephod.
And for the tribe of the children of Ephraim, a leader, Kemuel the son of Shiphtan.
And for the tribe of the children of Zebulun, a leader, Elizaphan the son of Parnach.
And for the tribe of the children of Issachar, a leader, Paltiel the son of Azzan.
And for the tribe of the children of Asher, a leader, Ahihud the son of Shelomi.
And for the tribe of the children of Naphtali, a leader, Pedahel the son of Ammihud.
These are those whom Jehovah commanded to divide the inheritance to the children of Israel in the land of Canaan.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses in the plains of Moab by the Jordan at Jericho, saying,

verse.text: Command the children of Israel to give to the [xref]a[/xref]Levites some of the inheritance of their possession, cities to dwell in; and you shall give to the Levites pasture lands around their cities.

chapter.verse: And the cities shall be for them to dwell in, and their pasture lands shall be for their cattle and for their livestock and for all their animals.

verse.text: And the pasture lands of the cities which you shall give to the Levites shall be from the city wall and outward, a thousand [xref]a[/xref]cubits all around.

chapter.verse: And you shall measure from the outside of the city on the east side two thousand cubits and on the south side two thousand cubits and on the west side two thousand cubits and on the north side two thousand cubits, with the city in the center. This shall be their pasture lands for the cities.

verse.text: And the cities which you shall give to the Levites shall be the six [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cities of refuge, which you shall give for the manslayer to flee to; and besides them you shall give forty-two cities.
verse.note: The cities of refuge typify the all-inclusive Christ as the embodiment of the redeeming God, into whom mistaken sinners can flee for refuge. Christ was delivered by God into the hands of sinners ([link]Acts 2:23[/link]; [link]Rom. 4:25[/link]), who mistakenly put Him to death ([link]Luke 23:34[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 2:8[/link]). If any sinner repents, God will regard him as a mistaken sinner and will forgive him ([link]Luke 24:47[/link]; [link]Acts 2:38[/link]). Such a one may flee into Christ. But if anyone refuses the gospel and does not repent, God will regard him as a willful sinner, one who is destined to perish ([link]v. 16[/link]; [link]John 3:16-18[/link]).[br][br]There were six cities of refuge, three on each side of the Jordan ([link]v. 14[/link]). The number six signifies mistake-making man, who was created by God on the sixth day ([link]Gen. 1:26-27[/link], [link]31[/link]). The number three signifies the Triune God as the refuge for the man who makes mistakes. The number two (the two sets of three cities each) signifies a testimony standing in the universe, testifying and declaring to the universe that the Triune God is living on earth among human beings to be their city of refuge.

verse.text: All the cities which you shall give to the Levites shall be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]forty-eight cities, they and their pasture lands.
verse.note: The number forty-eight is composed of six (the natural man created by God on the sixth day) multiplied by eight (resurrection). The forty-eight cities given to the Levites signify the natural man, who became fallen, being brought into resurrection through the Levitical service. The Levitical service was a service to the priesthood, and the goal of the priesthood was to bring fallen man back to God in resurrection. The number of cities given to the Levites thus signifies the purpose of the Levitical service.[br][br]The number forty-eight is also composed of four (also signifying man as God's creature — [link]Ezek. 1:5[/link]) multiplied by twelve (the number of perfection and completion in God's eternal administration). Hence, the number forty-eight indicates that man, who was created by God, will be perfected and completed in the eternal administration of God.

verse.text: And concerning the [note]1[/note]cities which you shall give from the possession of the children of Israel, from the larger [i]tribe[/i] you shall take a [xref]a[/xref]larger [i]number,[/i] and from the smaller [i]tribe[/i] you shall take a smaller [i]number;[/i] each one, according to its inheritance which they will inherit, shall give some of its cities to the Levites.
verse.note: The forty-eight cities given to the Levites were to be scattered among Israel, changing Jacob's curse on Levi in [link]Gen. 49:7[/link] into a blessing.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them, When you cross the Jordan into the land of Canaan,

verse.text: Then you shall designate for yourselves cities to be your [xref]a[/xref]cities of refuge, so that the manslayer who kills any person unintentionally may flee there.

chapter.verse: And the cities shall be for you as a refuge from the avenger, so that the manslayer may not die unless he stands before the assembly for judgment.
And the cities which you shall give shall be your six cities of refuge.

verse.text: You shall give [xref]a[/xref]three cities across the Jordan, and you shall give three cities in the land of Canaan; they shall be cities of refuge.

For the children of Israel and for the [note]1[/note]stranger and for the [note]1[/note]sojourner among them, these six cities shall be for refuge, so that anyone who kills a person unintentionally may flee there.
verse.note: That the cities of refuge were to be not only for the children of Israel but also for the strangers and sojourners among them signifies that the Triune God as the refuge for mistake-making man is for all mankind. Furthermore, the distribution of the six refuge cities in different places indicates that Christ, the embodiment of the Triune God, is near and available. The Triune God has spread among men, to the very place where we are, to be a city of refuge for all those who make mistakes.

verse.text: But if he struck him with an instrument of iron, and he died, he is a murderer; the [note]1[/note]murderer shall surely be [xref]a[/xref]put to death.
verse.note: The cities of refuge were not for the murderers, those who killed with an intent ([link]vv. 16-21[/link]). Adam sinned without intent, and we, the descendants of Adam, have sinned in the same way (cf. [link]Rom. 7:15-24[/link]). Therefore, in the sight of God we are those who sin without intent, and He considers our sinning as being without intent. See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link], par. 1.

chapter.verse: And if he struck him with a stone in hand, by which one could die, and he did die, he is a murderer; the murderer shall surely be put to death.
Or if he struck him with a wooden object in hand, by which one could die, and he did die, he is a murderer; the murderer shall surely be put to death.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]avenger of blood himself shall put the murderer to death; when he encounters him, he shall put him to death.

chapter.verse: And if he pushed him out of hatred or threw [i]something[/i] upon him while lying in wait, and he died,
Or in enmity struck him with his hand, and he died, the one who struck him shall surely be put to death; he is a murderer. The avenger of blood shall put the murderer to death when he encounters him.
But if he pushed him suddenly without enmity, or threw upon him anything without lying in wait,
Or [i]came upon him[/i] with any stone, by which [i]someone[/i] could die, without seeing [i]him[/i] and dropped it upon him, and he died, when he was not his enemy and did not seek his harm,

verse.text: Then the assembly shall [xref]a[/xref]judge between the slayer and the avenger of blood according to these ordinances.

And the assembly shall deliver the manslayer out of the hand of the avenger of blood, and the assembly shall return him to his city of refuge to which he had fled; and he shall dwell in it until the death of the [note]1[/note]high priest, who was [xref]a[/xref]anointed with the holy oil.
verse.note: The high priest here signifies Christ ([link]Heb. 4:14[/link]), who died for our sins. Spiritually, the Old Testament saints had to remain in the city of refuge until Christ died; no ransom could have released them before the time of Christ's death ([link]v. 32[/link]). This was a refuge prior to direct salvation. In the Old Testament time Christ had not yet died, and those who fled into Him as their refuge had to wait there until He came and died on the cross. For the Old Testament saints, therefore, the refuge was like the sheepfold in [link]John 10:1[/link] (see note 2 there).[br][br]Since Christ, our High Priest, has died, He is the refuge, not in the Old Testament sense but in the New Testament sense, to all His believers. This refuge is a matter of direct salvation. Before Christ's death He was the refuge for the Old Testament saints, but now, after His death, He is our direct salvation. We who enter into Christ today may do so with the assurance that He has already died and that our sins have already been forgiven ([link]Eph. 1:7[/link]; [link]Col. 2:13[/link]).

chapter.verse: But if the manslayer shall at any time go beyond the boundary of his city of refuge to which he has fled,
And the avenger of blood finds him outside the boundary of his city of refuge and the avenger of blood slays the manslayer, he shall not have [i]guilt for[/i] blood,
Because he should have remained in his city of refuge until the death of the high priest; but after the death of the high priest the manslayer shall return to the land of his possession.
And these things shall be for a statute of judgment to you throughout your generations in all your dwellings.

verse.text: Whoever kills a person, the murderer shall be slain upon the testimony of [xref]a[/xref]witnesses; but one witness shall not testify against any person so that he die.

chapter.verse: Moreover you shall not take a ransom for the life of a murderer who is guilty of death, but he shall surely be put to death.
And you shall not take a ransom for one who has fled to his city of refuge, so that he may return to live in the land before the death of the [i]high[/i] priest.

verse.text: Thus you shall not pollute the land in which you are, for blood [xref]a[/xref]pollutes the land. And no expiation can be made for the land for the blood that is shed in it, except by the [xref]b[/xref]blood of the one who shed it.
And you shall not defile the land in which you are dwelling, in the midst of which I [xref]a[/xref]tabernacle; for I Jehovah tabernacle in the [xref]b[/xref]midst of the children of Israel.

And the heads of the fathers' [i]households[/i] of the family of the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Gilead, the son of Machir, the son of Manasseh, of the families of the sons of Joseph, came near and spoke before Moses and before the leaders, the heads of the fathers' [i]households[/i] of the children of Israel;

And they said, Jehovah commanded my lord to give the land for inheritance by [xref]a[/xref]lot to the children of Israel, and my lord was commanded by Jehovah to give the inheritance of [xref]b[/xref]Zelophehad our brother to his daughters.

But if they [note]1[/note]are married to one of the sons of the [i]other[/i] tribes of the children of Israel, then their inheritance will be taken away from the inheritance of our fathers and will be added to the inheritance of the tribe to which they belong; so it will be taken away from the lot of our inheritance.
verse.note: Lit., become wives for. So throughout this chapter.

verse.text: And when the [xref]a[/xref]jubilee of the children of Israel takes place, then their inheritance will be added to the inheritance of the tribe to which they belong; so their inheritance will be taken away from the inheritance of the tribe of our fathers.

chapter.verse: Then Moses commanded the children of Israel according to the word of Jehovah, saying, The tribe of the sons of Joseph speaks correctly.

verse.text: This is what Jehovah commands concerning the daughters of Zelophehad, saying, Let them be [note]1[/note]married to whom they think best; only into the family of the tribe of their father they shall marry.
verse.note: God allowed the daughters to marry according to their taste but only within the family of the tribe of their father. This indicates that although the Lord gives us freedom, this freedom must be exercised within the limit, the boundary, of God's regulation (cf. [link]Gal. 5:13[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]So an inheritance of the children of Israel shall not go around from tribe to tribe, for each one of the children of Israel shall [note]1[/note]cling to the inheritance of the tribe of his fathers.
verse.note: This signifies that as our inheritance Christ is not transferable and that we should cling to Him as this inheritance. In principle, for a believer to marry an unbeliever is to make Christ as the inheritance transferable (cf. [link]2 Cor. 6:14[/link]). Cf. note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 27[/link].

verse.text: And every [xref]a[/xref]daughter who possesses an inheritance in any tribe of the children of Israel shall [note]1[/note]marry into one of the family of the tribe of her father, so that each one of the children of Israel may possess the inheritance of his fathers.
verse.note: The marriage of Mary, the mother of the Lord Jesus, to Joseph may be a marriage that fulfilled this statute (see note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link]). Thus, the statute in this chapter was actually ordained by God for Christ's incarnation. All Scripture reveals Christ and is a record concerning Christ, either directly or indirectly ([link]Luke 24:27[/link], [link]44[/link]). The cities of refuge in [link]ch. 35[/link] are a type of Christ, and the settlement of the problem regarding the inheritance in [link]ch. 36[/link] is related to Christ. If Christ had not been incarnated, He could not have become the cities of refuge for the human race. Thus, in a very real sense, the refuge cities in [link]ch. 35[/link] depend on the statute in [link]ch. 36[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]So an inheritance shall not go around from one tribe to another tribe, for each one of the tribes of the children of Israel shall cling to his own inheritance.

chapter.verse: Just as Jehovah had commanded Moses, so the daughters of Zelophehad did;

verse.text: That is, Mahlah, Tirzah, and Hoglah, and Milcah and Noah, the daughters of [xref]a[/xref]Zelophehad, were married to their uncles' sons.

chapter.verse: They married into the families of the sons of Manasseh the son of Joseph, and their inheritance remained in the tribe of the family of their father.

verse.text: These are the commandments and the ordinances which Jehovah commanded through Moses to the children of Israel in the plains of Moab by the [note]1[/note]Jordan at Jericho.
verse.note: The books of Exodus, Leviticus, and Numbers portray in typology God's need for a people to be saved and to go on with Him to enjoy His Christ, to receive His revelation, and to be built up with Him as the processed Triune God, that they may be formed into a priestly army to journey with Him and to fight with Him. These books also show that God's people need to be disciplined by passing through certain difficulties and undergoing different kinds of frustrations. In [link]Exo. 12-14[/link] Israel as God's people was redeemed from God's judgment by the passover and saved from Egypt by the saving power of the Triune God. Then, they enjoyed the heavenly provision and the divine care in their initial journey in the wilderness ([link]Exo. 15-17[/link]). In [link]Exo. 19-40[/link] and [link]Lev. 1-27[/link] they received the divine revelation and training in knowing God, in being built up together with God as His dwelling on earth for His expression and testimony, and in the building up of the priesthood for the divine service. All this took place at the foot of Mount Sinai, where the people were given the law as a portrait of what God is in His attributes. The book of Numbers records how God's chosen and redeemed people were formed into a priestly army to journey with God and to fight with God for His interest on earth ([link]chs. 1-4[/link]; [link]9:15-10:36[/link]; [link]12:16[/link]; [link]20:1-21:35[/link]; [link]31:1-54[/link]; [link]33:1-49[/link]). In Numbers the children of Israel also passed through various frustrations, trials, and disciplinings for their purification. Eventually, in [link]ch. 32[/link] and in [link]33:50-36:13[/link] God's people received the prearrangement for the distribution of the promised good land. After all the foregoing, God's chosen and redeemed people were ready to cross the Jordan, enter Canaan, consume its inhabitants, and possess the good land promised by the faithful God ([link]Josh. 1:2-3[/link]). With the exception of Joshua and Caleb, those who were qualified to take possession of the land were the younger ones, the second generation of those who had come out of Egypt. This younger generation had received the benefit of all that the first generation had experienced. With a rich inheritance and strong background, they were qualified to be formed into an army to fight with God and for God for the accomplishing of His economy. This history of Israel is a full type of the history of the church in its accomplishing of God's eternal economy in the mystical union with the all-inclusive Christ, who is the embodiment of the processed and dispensing Triune God ([link]1 Cor. 5:6-8[/link]; [link]10:1-13[/link]; [link]Heb. 3:7-4:13[/link]).
